CD Projekt Red created a  masterpiece.   There is no way I'll be able to give this game justice by posting my opinion in this review, but I'll do my best to outline some of the key elements that made The Witcher 3 one of the best, if not the best, game I've ever played.  CDPR went to enormous lengths to create meaningful interactions everywhere you turn in The Witcher 3. Not only is this game packed to the brim with rich story, but all of the diolague serves a purpose and will keep you engaged. Not once did the diolague feel forced. It took 44 hours for me to beat the main story line with limited secondary quest participation (without the DLC's), an incredible value for 40 bucks.   The character development is unlike any other game I've ever played. I found myself making decisions based off of what I thought the characters would want because I just wanted everything to turn out well for them. Even the charater of monsters and creatures you have few encounters with is gripping.   (Shout out to my boy Bart)    I have seen some complaints about how combat feels/plays out, and I agree when playing on a low difficulty setting. Playing through the game on a higher difficulty does test your ability to appropriately use light attacks, counter attacks, blocking, and magic. I was satisfied after defeating a foe, and when I lost I was able to analyze what I could have done differently and replan an attack.   The vision of the artists and writers came together seamlessly for this title. They truly produced a masterwork that will exceed the expectations of many people considering purchasing this game.  In a time where developers are shoveling incomplete Alpha games with microtransactions in our faces at AAA title prices, CD Projekt Red is proof that the future of gaming is a bright one.    This game is a 10.

Truely the pinnacle of video gaming. CD Projekt Red has every right to be proud of their work.  Here's to hoping for many years to come from them!

When I first bought TW3 I was extremely disappointed with it. Two of my favorite games are Dragon Age: Inquisition and TESV: Skyrim. I was ready to try TW3 because I had heard that it was better than both Skyrim and Inquisition, but I was just bored and didn't find it to be fun at all. It lacked some things that are what made me enjoy DA:I and Skyrim as much as I did such as character customization, play style, creating your character's personality, and the overall situation that the world is in that you have to deal with. I figured that I was pretty much done with it, and I left a negative review speaking my opinion of the game and why I didn't like it. After recieving a vicious comment on the review of some random person calling me an idiot for having an opinion, I removed the review and started an entirely new game. I don't know what happened, but after starting a new game and really getting into the world and not focusing on only gameplay I was pleasantly surprised. After spending a lot of time playing TW3, I can say that it is equally as good as DA:I, but not quite as good as Skyrim (many people disagree but that's just my opinion). I like the combat system in TW3 more than DA:I's or Skyrim's, but I like DA:I's story and world more than TW3's, and the freedom that you have over your character in Skyrim. All 3 games have pros and cons, but if you enjoy either DA or TES, then you're sure to enjoy this one. I guess that I have to thank the jerk that roasted me because he/she was he one whoconvinced me to give it another chance. Sorry if this review was unorganized or random at parts, I kind of just speak without planning it out before hand.

I think this might be the best single-player game I've played. The story-telling in this game is ♥♥♥♥ing magnificent, you just can't help being grown attached to the characters, and in my opinion, this is what makes this game so good. I've had some trouble with the handling of the game, for example the horse movement isn't really superb and it can be clunky at times but the combat system is fantastic, yet, all of this doesn't matter. If you came for a game which is focused about gameplay and movement and such then this isn't a game for you (not to say that the feel of the game is bad, it's suprisingly good) but this isn't what the game's about. If you want a game which has a great story with fantastic voice actors, storytelling, characters and a deep story at that then you should get this game, full price or not, this game is definitely worth it. The story keeps you focused in the game, I don't think I skipped one cutscene! You find books and such that you can read to know more about the lore of the game, you can do side-missions which will also give you a better background on what had happend before and of course, there are witcher contracts which aren't really related. The main focus of this game is the story, it can keep you playing the game non-stop for hours at times just to know more and progress more.  Honestly, if you're looking for a story-driven game with one of the best storytellings which every act you do will affect your ending (well, not any, but most) then get this game right now. I give this game a solid 9.9/10 (9.9 for the horse mechanics, sorry), I think this tops every single player game I played, definitely GOTY.

I was never a fan of the Witcher games. Part 1 was too tedious to get into (a lot of people had that problem), and part 2 threw so many names, events and political intrigue in your face within 10 minutes that I ended up not even finishing it initially. I gave part 3 a try and, eh, it's the best game I've ever played?   Like, this isn't an exaggeration. I've played a boatload of games. RPGs, mostly. None of them come even close to this. It's the immersion that really gets me. Especially the sound. There's nothing quite like hearing the wind roll in, leaves rustling louder and louder, until a storm hits you. The stupendously great graphical engine helps too, of course.   As for the quests, of which the game contains about an estimated 23 thousand or something, they're actually fun. Not a single quest will ever feel lazy, or tacked on. Even something that starts off as a simple fetch quest always has a little twist at some point, leaving the player to make a decision, big or small. Even walking into a pawn shop to sell some of your junk can open a quest, it's nuts.   Then there's the monster hunts, which make you feel like a crossever between the brothers Winchester, Sherlock Holmes and freakin' Sir Galahad. Tracking down the beast step by step, figuring out what it is, where it is, and how to efficiently kill it. It's fun. Like, really fun.  I liked this game so much I actually went back to Witcher 2 and found myself finishing it and enjoying it quite a bit. The fact that I remembered a lot for Witcher 3 actually helped me understand most of the characters and events from that game a lot better. Let's call it non-linear storytelling.  But yeah, conclusion, 10/10. I want to come up with critique but I genuinely can't.

Ah, the Witcher 3. What can you say about a game that already has 50 thousand reviews? Nothing new, most likely, but here's my two cents anyways:  It. Is. Gorgeous. It looks like art on my screen, it's simply lovely. It may not technically be the prettiest game you'll play but everything you see is done with such a consistent and balanced approach to quality that it wraps up as an exceptionally attractive game to look at.   The writing, what can I say about the writing? It is, in my opinion, 10/10. Superb characters, with memorable plights and stories to get caught up in. You'll love some, hate some, find many annoying and others still you'll wish there was more to do with them given how interesting they are. There is a deep, frightening and engrossing world to get lost in, with particular attention paid to believeable settings. The lore is fantastic, and the story is grim and ultimately is one of my favorite RPG stories of all time - and the DLC is disgustingly good, damn near better than the core content. Which is astounding to be able to say.  The ability you have as a player to shape the world you move through and the ends of your stories and characters is something that you have to play to see. There are so many subtle touches, little things to tie everything you do to your story. The flexibility of the game, given that it is based on and driven by a linear storyline (having originated as a series of Polish novels) is remarkable. There are no black-and-white lines here. You are not going to be smacked in the face with Paragon points or a little bar telling you how evil you have made Geralt become. As like life, these things are found in the people around you and the way they react to you. It's marvellous.  However, the Witcher 3 has some of the dryest and dullest combat you will come across. It's actually pretty disapointing how boring fights that should be awesome are just plain snooze-inducing. The combat just is not built very well at all, and I know that many will disagree with me, but the magic isn't impressive or even particularly useful in many cases. The alchemy is useful but crafting has been simplified significantly, so much so that it feels deliberately game-y now, which I found to be a confusing design choice in a game with such an obvious focus on immersing the player in another world. Gathering materials is boring and tedious. Crafting, and pretty much everything in the game, is buried in a nonsensical amount of menus and sub-menus. Equipment upgrades feel more-or-less worthless as besides the aesthetics, nothing but the damage number matters.   I firmly believe this game is an overall masterpiece in the realm of interactive fiction, an accoomplishment that everyone even slightly interested in can enjoy. I recommend it because the story and characters are par-none. Better than anything else I have played in recent memory. But it is not perfect, nor is it completely above reproach, so be warned - the gameplay itself is not terribly engaging and the combat is boring, even when you're fighting monsters that should make your heart race. In my opinion, ultimately this game will absolutely be worth it to you if you're looking for a world to explore, less so for gameplay to master.

Already completed the base game from GOG, bought the GOTY here since it was cheaper than buying the expansions on GOG thanks to regional pricing. So currently on my second run of the game and I have to say it is one of the best games I've played. Seeing the changes in gameplay and character interactions when player makes different choices continues to impress me. Even secondary quests and monster contracts are quite fun and crafted very well. Excellent score, visuals and characters make its many GOTY titles well deserved.  At first I hated the skilling system, now I don't hate it but at the same time I think they could've gone with something better. Also one other minor complaint of mine is how the game doesn't at times give enough hints about failable quests, a small alert saying this quest would fail would have been nice but this is not a deal breaker in any way. Pros    Combat has been highly improved over the W2 one    Revamped alchemy system which removes the need to constantly brew them, liked this change    Well written quests and characters    Great soundtrack    Choices which go beyond good or evil often with surpising outcomes  Cons    Customization is a bit limited, would've been nice to be able to customize armor color for one    Directions on map can be very misleading at times    Monster trophy bonuses are a bit disappointing in terms of variation    Main characters disappear once game is complete, would've been nice to keep them in world with minor interaction options with them like say playing gwent, doctor or what not  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)   Overall I'd say that this is definitely a game to be played and has more than enough content both in terms of quality & quantity for its asking price.

Alright, so, this game has become one of my favorites of all time, if not THE favorite of all time, after my first playthrough. I'm going to see how well it holds up after completing it, soon. So, let's begin the list of reasons why I love this game.  1) It sticks to the key points in the story it originated from. I read the books first, before i ever played this game, and there is no describing how happy it makes me when the characters are chatting and they bring up the story of Dandilion and the Djinn from The Last Wish. I wont go any further into it because additional tidbits involve semi-spoilers, but if you read the books, the game is that much more wonderful. Conversely, you by no means have to have read the books, or even played the previous games, to understand what's going on in this one. Sure, it helps for background stuff, but you'll still understand everything going on at all times,   (except maybe the unicorn)   so dont let that stop you from this amazing experience.  2) The story itself is wonderful, in my opinion. The level of depth and detail to each character is so amazingly well done to the point where you can get reads of their opinions from the body language during a dialog scene, and you almost always have the ability to steer the conversation how you want it to go, defuse a situation or make it worse, start a blood fued or end one, etc etc.. The voice acting, too, is quite spectacular, and characters lips and faces are some of the most expressive I've seen to date.  There is one part in the story, for instance, where you listen a lady sing (she's part of a performing group) and it is hands down the best singing I've heard from a video game ever. As someone who went to an internationally acclaimed school of music for his voice, it was a fantastic experience. Shortly after that, someone is greviously injured, and the person who loves them looks at you and says 'Geralt, find them. Find whoever did this... and kill them.' with such emotion that I wanted to shed a tear in sympathy and was furious as hell at the same time. This is also the only game that I've enjoyed or gotten a great benefit out of 99% of the side quests in it, instead of doing them for the xp or something.  For instance,    I felt good after I helped an old lady find her best frying pan.    I took the moral high ground and didnt take money after bringing someone the news that their loved on was dead, and got a reputation as a decent person, instead of a vile witcher, in that area.    Abandoned villages can be repopulated, meaning more blacksmiths, armorers, herbalists, etc.  3) The actual gameplay, combat and movement and such, is very well done. On the two easiest difficulties, you can be pretty confident, maybe a bit more care is needed once you get to big boss type stuff. But as soon as you go higher in difficulty, you feel very mortal in a very dangerous world.  Each monster belongs to a class of some sort (ie necrophage, hybrid, spirit, etc) and each has a general weakness, like oils, but every single monster has a different attack pattern and/or ability, and usually a spell weakness that can be exploited. No cookie cutter formula here. You have to be able to anticipate the attack, dodge or roll out of the way the right way, and then know how much time you have to hit it before it strikes again. Feels like the glorious offspring of skyrim's open world and dark souls-esque combat, for a good reference point.  The world you fight these monsters in is, in a word, GORGEOUS. Each continent feels distinctly different, each area has it's own clothing style and accent, and every single bit of scenery is vivid and wonderful. As an aside, the clothing and armor in this game is a world apart from anything else I've seen. As you journey, you can unlock different sets of 'Witcher Gear' which grow more powerful as you upgrade them, AS WELL AS change their appearance. For instance, I played with the Cat School gear, and it starts out as a short sleeve shirt with a hard vest, then a light longsleeve with padding, then chainmail on the sleeves, etc etc. Really gives you the feeling that your armor is evolving with your character, and you're improving it and refining it as you grow more accustomed to it. And it stand out as clothes instead of a body suit, unlike most every other game I can think of. There are some times that hitboxes and models can be a bit buggy (geralt can jump/float up a slant sometimes), and the occasional body bounces a bit further than it probably should, but it is honestly more funny than annoying, as it happens so rarely.   So, in conclusion, the story is 10/10, the gameplay is 9.9 out of 10, the world design and depth is 10/10, and the only regret I have after playing it through is I'll never get to experience playing it for the first time again. Such a wonderful journey.   also, dont forget to check out the (at this time) like 14 free dlc things that are all great.

Phenomenal! Beautiful/huge multi-region open world, with incredible concern to details, mature/excellent gameplay and storyline, pleasant music, really a lot of content. The grand finale of The Witcher stories and one of the best games I ever played! Definitely game of the year of 2015.

The Witcher 3 is a final journey in the game series based on A. Sapkowski's books. You don't have to read them before playing to fully enjoy it, as the game has its own encyclopedia of people, monsters and other things. The in-game books also tell you a lot about the lore. You don't have to play the previous games either. Although their events take place before Wild Hunt, the game tells you enough info about them to put things together. Of course if you want to have the best experience possible, you should play them as well, because the choices you make carry over and people will react according to them.  The choices and actions you make are one of the reasons what makes this game so great. Help one person do a certain thing and you'll get a whole kind of different situations afterwards, even when it's gonna end bad and you didn't realise it could be that way. After each action people might act differently towards you, too.  The main story quests have some of the most memorable moments I've ever experienced in a video game and will have you glued to your PC. The same goes for the side quests. As they are practically everywhere, you'll spend most of the time doing them. They're not the typical boring side quests, all of them are diverse and have their own unique stories to tell and that's what makes them so wonderful and very enjoyable. Either doing the witcher contracts on monsters or helping out an old woman clearing out her kitchen. All quests can be found on notice boards in towns or when exploring.  The world you'll get to explore is huge. You'll encounter different kinds of stuff everywhere. In the forests, bogs, swamps, beautiful fields, meadows, hills, rocky mountains, rivers, the open sea and the surrounding isles, or outskirts. The cities and towns are lively, especially the majestic city of Novigrad, where you'll spend a really lot of time.   The graphics are breathtaking, the soundtrack is fascinating and suits the places where you are or the situations you'll find yourself in. The controls aren't hard to get used to and the same goes for combat. It can be tricky in the beginning because you can't fight all enemies the same way. You'll have to adapt depending on who or what you're fighting, which is a good thing though.  The game's expansion pack is another thing worth mentioning because it adds new locations but most importantly, more stories! The story telling is fantastic, maybe even better than in the original game :)  Another thing worth mentioning is Gwent, the game's addicting card game. Once you'll understand how to play, you'll spend hours gambling with other people to win their cards which you can add to your deck to make it stronger. And of course there are Gwent side quests, too.  The game offers a lot of fun for hundreds of hours, the characters are unforgettable, there are moments where you'll laugh, other will be thrilling. And in most you'll have just some casual fun, but it's damn worth it and you won't forget any of it.  Definitely recommended, because for me it's the best game I've ever played!

**Disclaimer: I've been a very big fan of The Witcher games since I played TW1 back in 2012. This review may have a bit of bias towards the game and it's creators**  Having put almost 40 hours into the game now, I feel I can make a review about the game. The Witcher 3 is the third and final chapter in The Witcher saga and it delivers. Picking up about 6 months after the events of The Witcher 2, the kingdoms of the North are in chaos as Nilfgaard's invasion shows no signs of stopping. You play as Geralt of Rivia. A human who had undergone severe magic rituals and mutations to become the perfect killer. As a Monster Hunter you're biggest enemies will be the monsters of this land. Giant insects, elementals, vampires, etc will be other enemies you'll face besides from humans of course.   The starting area of the game is basically one giant sandbox tutorial that allows the player to get a feel for the game and learn how to play through helpful hints and tutorials. Veterans of the series will blow through this area rather quickly but if you're new to the game I'd suggest you explore everything the game laid out of you in detail because most of what you will learn will be useful even in late game.   Combat in this game is brutal. On normal difficulty monsters will hurt hard and won't back down from a fight. Unlike other RPGs, enemies in this game do not scale. They each have their own set level and stats. So that wraith guarding a cemetery might be too high but after a few levels, you'll be ready to take it on. This adds an overhead challenge when exploring. The first zone outside of the starter area does not have a level requirement. You will run into monsters that far exceed and even triple what your level is. This is why it is best you save often while exploring. The village that offers quests for you level might look safe but after going out towards the thick swamp you might come across a few nekkers who will eat you for dessert. Your best friends throughout the game will be your Steel and Silver swords. Steel is reserved for wild life like wolves, bears along with humans and non humans (dwarves, elves, etc). Silver is reserved for the monsters of the world. The game itself has a monster encyclopedia called the beastariy. It contains information on all the monsters you know and what they're weak against. Oils and potions are also necessary for combat. Oils on your sword can give more damage against certain types of creatures while potions provide active effects in combat like healing, damage resistance, etc. However, you can not just spam drink potions. You have a toxicity bar that fills up each time you drink a potion. Filling it up fully will cause you to lose health rapidly until you die. Knowing when to drink a potion and when to save will be the key for battle.   Questing in this game is also incredibley fun. Unlike normal side quests that devolve into kill X and retrieve Y, they turn more into overhead stories that will flesh out into unique stories. An interesting side quest I came across was to retrieve a woman's frying pan. The entire quest took part in a single house on the shoreline and barely took me five minutes but it still felt like an actual quest. CD Projetk RED have excelled in this aspect in making not only a very interesting main story but side quests that feel like an actual story is being told.  The game map is huge. The zone of Velen is massive in space and feels like it's own little world contained inside itself. Villages sprawl across the countryside with a massive city that looms off in the distance that yearns to be explored. Guarded treasures, monster nests, villages that need cleaning of monsters, and more are littered across the countryside all offering loot that can be used or sold depending on your character's level.   Pros:    Beautifully crafted game with an expansive world yearning to be explored    Tactical and engaging combat that will not be afraid to punish you for mistakes    Engaging narrative that doesn't rely on black and white/bad and evil choices. Instead focusing more on choices you think as a player are the right ones.    Dark and gritty world that doesn't shy away from controversial topics like sexism, racism, torture, etc.   Cons:    Gwent card game needs a better tutorial     No dice poker

I honestly don't usually waste my time writing reviews. But this game's different. Before I got my gaming PC I played most of my games on the Xbox One. And thats what I did with this game at the time. However I got bored quickly and stopped playing the game. But once I had my PC I knew I wouldn't let this game pass me by because of the extremely high ratings on steam, higher framerates and better graphics. So I got the game and started playing. Once I had reached the part that I reached when I played on Xbox, I wasn't sure what to do (as the main reason I stopped playing on Xbox was the fact that I wasn't sure what to do during a certain part of the game (family matters)) But after some faffing aroud I found out how to continue. The more I played this game, the more attatched I felt to the characters in the game, and by the time I was nearing the end I wasn't even playing for fun but for the insanely good story of Geralt by CD Projekt Red. I honestly think this game has the best story in a video game (that i've ever played at least). I rate this game a solid 9.5/10. The only reason I won't rate this 10/10 is because I don't think ANY game can TRULY be 10/10 and every game has flaws. Get this game even if your not into RPG's (like me).

This could very well be, the best game I have played to date. I loved playing this game.  So much freedom, including choices that actually had impact on the storyline. Some games, you get choices but it doesn't feel like it changes much of the story. So your choice(s) have zero impact. This gave the game HUGE points to me, I hate when games offer you choices, but really whatever you decide is rendered irrelevant to the story and overall outcome.   The combat, well it's very good but like most RPG's it can get repetitive but combat in RPG's will never be perfect. This could be as good as RPG combat ever gets.  The soundtrack was great as well and the cinematics were really well done. When I first heard 'Priscilla's song,' I was blown away. Such a beautiful song, I forgot that I was playing a game and just sat back and listened. Wonderfully done.  Character development was overall really well done, I actually cared/disliked characters which generally I don't end up doing in most games. Most games are quite 'black and white' with their characters. I like that the developer was not scared at all to let your character go from ♥♥♥ kicker, monster hunter to having emotional connections with his romantic partners.  So overall, this game (in my opinion) definitely is a huge favourite to be considered Game Of The Year. It's possible by 2020 this could be the Game Of The Decade.  Absolutely fantastic. I will be replaying this game, to make different choices and see their effect on the story and possible outcomes.  10/10

The best open-world RPG game ever made.

Story:  Absolutely amazing story. I have never been carried away with the characters and the atmosphere of the game so much. I almost cried when I realized that the story is over. The story is so good I actually started reading books (already completed 'The Last Wish') which I would never usually do. I highly recommend completing the first 2 games as I think they are essential, they allow you to build up your own Gerald, and it gives you time to get attached to the characters. If you have completed the first 2 games I guarantee that you will go on an emotional trip after the completion of the 3rd game. Although at first I thought the story did not flow very well from the 2nd game to the 3rd after a few hours I was again fully immersed in the Witcher. 10/10 for the story  Combat:  The gameplay overall is a massive improvement on the first 2 games the fights flow very nicely and they feel very cinematic which is very hard to achieve. Furthermore, you have to use different tactics when fighting different monsters you can’t just press one button repeatedly (on easier difficulties maybe). I do however find that it does get repetitive after a while. There are also signs and potions that are infinitely important. I love what CD Project red done with signs, they are no longer repetitive feature of combat, in Witcher 3 they are dynamic and very fun to use, in combat you can decide what is the best way of applying the current sign. The potions however are a bit disappointing now, you can basically just spam them. 9/10 for combat  World:  Just WOW. It is absolutely massive and very very dynamic, the little side quests are always fun to do when you travel from one location to another, the people you meet and new quests you pick up are always interesting, it feels like every location has been worked on for month! The random encounters add adventure to every little bit of the map. 10/10 for world  9.9/10 MUST HAVE

One of the best RPGs in recent history. Many many hours of gameplay and that's just the side quests. Characters are well writen, story line is fantastic, graphics are top notch, and the world is just *massive*. Because of the size of the world and the large amount of side quests, there are a lot of quests that can have similar types (go to ___ kill ___ return for reward), but because of how well the characters are written, every quest feels like something completely different. You are driven to want to help these people (or not, your choice) and you actually care about the outcome. Your choices actually matter and have real consequences down the road. Nothing but good stuff. About 40 hours in and maybe halfway through level 9 now. I haven't really run into a sidequest that felt mundane yet, a couple may drag a bit, but the backtracking isn't really bad (and with the amazing countryside to gawk at, backtracking isn't really an issue! Go cross country and witness an amazing sunset from atop a mound of rotfiend corpses on the way!).  The main story is captivating, in true Witcher form. Oops, pulled another all-nighter.   My only complaints so far are minor stability issues resulting from a mild overclock, and the new alchemy system.   This game is VERY sensitive to GPU stability. My overclock is very mild, no stability issues found during stress testing or other games, but this one finds them.   As far as alchemy goes, I'm not a fan of the 'hotkey' potions that you can instantly slam down while wrist deep in a werewolf's chest cavity, I prefer the strategic preparation required from the first two games. Luckily, mods are already popping up on the nexus to smooth out these minor issues! Can't wait until official mod tools are released, this game is going to stick around.  In my opinion, while not required, play through the first two games and read up on the witcher wiki for backstory and character information. Really immerse yourself in the universe, remember who people are, remember what they did, remember that how you deal with them may have consequences 40 hours later!

I dread finishing this game.   Truly.   I have become so invested in this world, in these characters, that knowing it's the end... I'm not even sure how to describe how it makes me feel that it's about to be over. For me, that's the greatest endorsement that I can give; this game actually makes me care.
This is the best game I have ever play...EVER! I can not recommend higher! BUY THIS GAME, you won't regret it.

Just finished my first game in 88 hours, with only the handful of minor free DLC that probably added two hours to the game. I didn't even touch the Gwent stuff either, I hear that can take a long time too. I also didn't try and find all of the optional locations in Skellige but that might have ruined the game for me. You'll see.  It's a phenomonal game. The world is enormous, but also dense. The side quests are compelling in their own right, not just filler to get more XP and pad out the hours. The main story is well done. It meanders through the different regions, and each of the subplots within are pretty well fleshed out. Your actions do have consequences, yet unlike most games, those consequences are not immediately apparent and even after finishing the game, I am not really sure what I did that resulted in some aspects of the ending. And it doesn't even get into the Good/Bad Ending crap, some parts of my ending were very gratifying, others actually made me regret what had happened and want to do it over. So despite having just put ninety hours into the game, I'm feeling ready to start a NG+ and play again on a higher difficulty, with DLC enabled, making different choices, and trying a different build of character. It's definitely one of the best games I've ever played. Can't recommend it enough.

FIrst off Read the Books, they are really a cool experience and open up the world of Geralt the Witcher. Secondly, all three games build on each other, however, the third installment is congruent enough with lore and sidequests, to get you what you need to know to enjoy the game and the story, just like you can watch Star Wars: Return of the Jedi and get most of the story, even if you have not watched the previous 2. Even if that is a bad example, you will enjoy this rich, atmostpheric game which is both gritty, deadly and beautiful at the same time. The romances in the game are what you decide to make them and as with most relationships in the real world, can be complicated. If you play one game this year, this needs to be it, without a doubt. Check the rating on the game to see what you are buying, if you do not want to see certain things flash across your screen, in the living room, be aware that could be the case, depending on what choices you make with Yennefer or Triss. I must stress this is not a game for children. The combat system is finally much more enjoyable, albiet a bit more simplistic. This feels much more realistic and sensible as fantasy stories go and you will not be dissapointed. The graphics are top notch and yet will not run badly on most mid to high level rigs. Surprisingly, they have it working fairly well on consoles, particularly the PS4. If you are a fan of the Witcher, you need to set aside some time, stop playing Call of Duty or Destiny and play this game thoroughly. Take your time, enjoy it and it will stay with you, long after you complete the game. 10/10 stars.

EXPECTATION  The one thing i and many others out there expect to be in our rpg games, because we have been so used to it for years that we just accept it as normal, are those tedious boring side quests that we only do for the xp/gold/sword etc, we have no interest in the character that gave us the quest or why they want us to go there, fetch that/collect ten of these or twenty of that, you know the quests i mean, the utterly pointless and is instantly forgettable ones.  I'm now about 70 hour into this game, done lots of quests, side quests and witcher contracts and every single one has been enjoyable, even the ones i thought were destined to be boring just by their very nature, the horse racing and card quests, turned out to have very good missions attached in some way or another, i have not came across one single boring or tedious mission yet and i find it quite sad that those type of quests are considered normal in our games that i still fully expect to run into these type of quests at some point, because that's just what happens in rpgs.  I really hope other game developers take note of what CD Projekt RED have done here because this game is an absolute masterpiece, yes there is a few niggles, the controls can be a bit iffy at times (on foot and on horse) the combat takes a bit of getting used too but after a short while you begin taking out groups of monsters with ease and style, as long as you have the right equipment and signs.  The game looks great, plays great (minor niggles aside), sounds great, has some of the best characters and story i have seen which is delivered by the best voice acting i have ever heard in a game.  Lets all hope that this right here, these side quests that are not just there for you to grind away with or to pass some time just for the hell of it, that these side quests, ones that feel like they actually matter, they become the norm.  CD Projekt RED have set a new standard with this game, lets keep it this high and hopefully push it even further.  100/10

I wasn't even a fan of the other witcher games, but I bought this one because I've only heard good things about it. I got it during a sale and said why not? And HOLY ♥♥♥♥ this game!!!  First off, every side quest in the game feels like it eventually becomes a major quest as each one has a pretty big backstory. Some of the quests actually made me tear up a bit. All of the characters are interesting and something that was huge for me was that I actually wanted to read my character index and bestiary, which I never do. The voice acting is outstanding and every character you come across feels important.   Combat in the game is....well...arguably bare at times. However, preparing for a big fight is always fun like brewing the right potions and applying oils to your swords. General movement is pretty clunky and a controller is definitlely required, until I found out that if you go into the options and change movement to alternate, it's much snappier.  The game looks absolutely beautiful; sharp textures, pretty environment, insane amount of detail etc.  The game of course isn't perfect. One thing that I found frustrating was your income comes in at a very slow rate when starting out. If you're playing on the highest difficulty, alot of your hard earned money will go into food and other healing wares. This will slowly change over time when you aquire new armor, but the first few hours will be aggrovating.  Final Verdict? 10/10.  This doesn't mean that the game is perfect. IMO there is no such thing as a game that is. But a 10/10 to means that it is worth every single penny you pay for. This game isn't limited to just Witcher fans, this is a game that everyone needs to play and take notes on what a true piece of art this game is.

This game is amazing. You don't need me to tell you that. The dlc is even better. But you don't need me to tell you that either. In short, you can stop reading here, unless you enjoy rambling nonsense. Just buy it.    The one viewpoint I   can   bring to this game is one of someone who tried and failed to get into the last two games, despite enjoying the lore of the Witcher's world - IT IS SO MUCH BETTER. It takes all the ideas of the other games, the combat, the crafting, the magic, the potions, the loot, and it improves them tenfold, and sticks it all in a GORGEOUS open world with a great story and a great cast of characters, and a ton of stuff to do.  For a start, you have job. Yes. An actual job. It is your job to kill monsters. You take on contracts, you find specialist equipment, you wander from town to town picking up work and monster's heads as trophies. That in itself would be a fun game. But this game is so much more. Sidequests with interesting stories, places of interest with nice loot, fun boss fights, fun combat, good levelling and progression, and a great main storyline for when you get bored of all that... this game is the ultimate open world RPG, and I want there to be a hundred more games like it.  That said, it is not without it's flaws. It is an extremely demanding game, for a start, and even with a Nvidia 970 and 16gb of RAM it doesn't always behave, the fps drops for no reason (on any settings), not a lot, but enough and often enough to drive you mad. Also, it tricks you into thinking you can do Parkour. DO NOT, unless it is really obvious. You will get stuck. And, obviously, not every sidequest is great fun. Some of them fall flat. Also, the loot system is a little bit confusing, it feels complicated and there are a lot of items, but most of them are literally junk, and 90% of the stuff you find is crap compared to the specialist gear you can craft every few levels. It is far from a perfect game. It's more of a flawed masterpiece. But a masterpiece, and really, really fun, nonetheless.  And, of course, Gwent. The BEST minigame within a game that I have ever seen. I bought Playstation DLC special edition packs so that I could pick up some real Gwent cards and play it against real people. They're turning it into a proper game in itself, coming soon on Steam. Gwent is amazing. And if you get bored of it, you can always go off and kill some monsters before continuing to play cards. Did I say minigame? Isn't that thing about Ciri the minigame, actually, now that I think about it? I'm playing The Witcher III: Gwent Card Hunt.  (Witcher 3 for 'Best Game Within a Game' Award! Also, every other award that could apply to it. Even the farm one. It has farm animals in it, although they don't live long when I'm around and feeling hungry...)   P.S. Since I finished this game and both dlcs I have tried to play the Witcher 1 and 2 again, and, honestly, it doesn't matter how much I love the characters and story now, I still don't like playing them. That's proof to anyone who's in the same position as me that the Witcher 3 IS worth your time.

It seems futile to even write a review about this game, considering how successful and critically acclaimed it is. Still, I'd like to share my opinion, and hope it is helpful.  If someone was to ask me what my favorite game this year was (even though there are still six weeks left before 2016, and at least one more game that I am interested in will be released this year), it has to be this one.   This is actually my second review... I deleted the first one, as I just started my second playthrough. I got the game when it first came out, finished it and had a blast, enjoying it tremendously.  I wasn't sure how much replay value this would have, but starting another playthrough, I realize it's almost as much fun as the first time, even though you know the reveals etc. I will make different choices this time, seeing how much things will change when I do.  In a nutshell: - Graphics are beautiful and very atmospheric, and the game is well optimized. I have an i7 4790, 16 gigs of RAM, a GTX 960 with 4 GB RAM. The first time I played this, I still had a GT730, and even with that card, I was able to play the game and it looked nice. With the 960, it's even more beautiful.  - The soundtrack is totally awesome IMO  - Difficulty ofc depends on what you pick, but I thought it was fun, challenging without being unfair. You will need to do some research (in game) on the different kind of monsters, using oils and stuff, and figuring out what you'll be fighting (contracts) is very cool... I love that moment when I know what I am fighting, meditate, go to the haunted spot and hear the monster approach.   - This game has some AMAZING writing. The characters are sometimes quite mysterious, and IMO not as cliche as you see in so many other games. They might be evil, but often have a soft spot, or a reason for their behaviour, or do something unexpected. So many dramatic stories here, and the storyline in general is VERY well-written  - So much stuff to do. Some of it can be a tiny bit grindy, but on my first playthrough, I did pretty much every bit of side-content until I eventually moved ahead and focussed more on the story.  - No glitches, no crashes, only one bugged event (Geralt drew a sword, but it wasnt in his hand, so I didn't do any damage. Happened ONCE)  - The atmosphere... omg, it's hard to explain really. I have no idea why but the world of the Witcher, the setting, the landscapes and towns captivated me right away. There is a quite dark and foreboding vibe to the world... riding through the forests at dusk, with rain coming down and the wind blowing... it's SO well done, so very beautiful. MGS, AK, FO4...none of these games captivated me even half as much. I am not sure whether its the graphics, the design, the music, the writing, or a mix of all that, it just sucked me right in.   - Replayability. I started playing when the game came out, and now, about half a year later, I started another playthrough. And it's FUN. Yes, of course I now know all the big reveals of the main story, but still, it's fun to play it again. Will try a slightly different spec and playstyle this time (because you can eg. focus on swordplay or signs or the other weapons, mix them the way you like. My first build was relying very much on signs, using Igni and mind-controlling enemies).   - DLC... check out the list of FREE DLC that the devs have added. I was blown away when I reinstalled the game and saw quite a list of free DLC. Some of it minor, some adding quests etc. Plus, the first expansion adds SO much to the game, it's amazing, especially considering the price.   - Controls are... a bit wonky. Have a bit of that 'drunk' feeling, a bit too rough and inaccurate. You eventually get used to it, but compared to games like the Arkham Knight or some of the AC games (and these games have control issues as well, mind you!), it felt a bit too...loose.    Pros: - Graphics and optimization - Amount of content - Music and sound - Story and writing (!!!!) - Fights - Very mature topics, things you don't have in games too often  Cons: - Lore and stories might be a bit confusing to newcomers to the franchise - Same for crafting, inventory management, alchemy - Wonky controls, not quite precise enough

A great game that you never want to end. I got this game 3 days ago, and already have 15.2 hrs. The graphics are amazing, the plot is interesting, the combat is good, potions can be crafted and used durring battle to gain an advantage. There's nothing bad to say about this game 10/10

Single player games have always been one of the most challenging games for me to get sucked in to and really invest a lot of time in. Not since Castlevania: SOTN or Legend of the Dragoon have I felt that passion for a single player game reignited. The immersion in this game is phenominal. The world is huge, the story and lore behind everything is fantastic. I personally love the combat system in this game, it feels very fluid (99 percent of the time). When I bought this game I was actually going through a dry spell of sorts. There just wasn't really any games out there that particularly interested me, was even considering not gaming anymore (insanity), and bought this one on a whim. Needless to say, again, this game reignited my passion for gaming. Showed me that there are developers out there that do care about making a genuine enjoyable game, not just one thats pushed out to make hype sales, and that truly listen and care about their fanbase. **If you are looking for a game to reignite your passion for gaming, reestablish your faith in developers, or to enforce an already existing passion, this game is it.**

The Witcher 3 is one of the best games I have played in a long time. It has a long, epic story and a huge, beautiful world to explore with lots of sidequests and contracts. If you like RPG- and Adventure-type games you should absolutely play this. The only critiscm I have is that it sometimes got stuck during transitions between cutscenes and while fast traveling, but this is something you could expect from such a big game. Also, you could fix most of the problems by simply just restarting the game.  P.S. You should have a pretty decent computer, so you can enjoy this game at the higher graphic levels.

The Witcher 3 is without a doubt the best RPG I have ever played, that in no ways means that its perfect, in fact at times its downright janky. The world created in this game is bloody beautiful, it really is. The urban centers, particularily Novigrad capture the feel of a medieval city in a way that I havent seen elsewhere, and whilst graphically it leaves a little to be desired the commitment to an artistic vision that melds realism with fantasy creates a consistent aesthetic feel that is spot on. Yet it is in the characters that the Witcher shines, some of the minor players in side quests will most likley stay with me for years as they are that intersting and well rounded. The combat and movement systems in this game can however be rather frustrating and non-intuitive, yet for an open world RPG I only began to become annoyed with this toward the end of my 86 hour run.    BUT... I NOW FEEL HOLLOW! I did my bloody best, tried to make the best choices presented to me, and I still got the worst bloody ending possible, LIKE COME ON! HOW THE HELL IS DRINKING WITH MY DAUGHTER BAD? JESUS CHRIST I'M BLOODY LIVID RIGHT NOW! Shiv me sideways with a sasuage and call me Bertha I'm angry, CMON I MEAN REALLY?? LIKE REAAAALLLLY? All that bloody work for a bad ending! I almost threw my controller through the bloody wall, it was so out of place, trying as hard as I could to go out of my way to make the world and my relationships stable to be ♥♥♥♥ on by like what, Two 'Bad' choices? TELLING THE PERSON THAT THE WILD HUNT WANTS TO KIDNAP TO STAY BACK DURING THE BATTLE IS NOT ANYTHING BAR SENSIBLE! I refuse to accept such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ing ending can come from this ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥ i'm mad.         That sside if you want a great open world RPG, this is a must.

I put off playing this for so long - I play a few MMORPGs and didn't really think I had the time to put into it. Then the Steam sale came along and I picked it up anyway (STEAM SALE!! WOOOO!)  Anyway - I'm so glad I took the plunge, I've barely dipped my toe in it and already I'm captivated by it. It really encourages you to learn about the world (where to find certain plants to make into oils, what oils work best against which monsters etc). You rarely see a game that makes you learn the same stuff that the character actually learns.  It all adds up to a world that feels so incredibly alive - victory can be hard fought, but with every victory you really feel like you've done more than button mash/thrown yourself against a wall until you get lucky.   A smart Witcher lives a long time, a smarter Witcher when to run away ;)  An amazing game - pick it up if you like rpgs/engrosing narrative/swordplay/fantasy/sassy main characters   10/10

I figure I'd tell it like it is. You know the things people are afraid to hear. Like the truth for instance. I've seen many men flood through the gates of hell, I reckon every man or woman has the same story to tell, it wasn't me, I didn't do it, I'm innocent. You could hear the screams just intertwine with each other, a cacophony of nothing but desperation. The new souls are always the worse, they could go on moaning for hundreds of years, until one day they just stop, as to figure out this is their life now, nothing that anyone can do. They become hardened and they start to hunt their brethren. Than there are the lucky ones who accept that they were garbage in their past life, they come to terms with the monster inside of them. These souls ascend to where all souls wish to be, they are free of the pain and free of their past crimes, they have repented and acknowledged their wrong doings. These types of souls are rare, when they first appear you can always tell.  They lived with this guilt for so long, they hated who they were, what they thought of, who they hurt, They were tormented on Earth, vilified and to far-gone to fix. When they pass the gates like all men do, they are asked what they wish for most in the world, and they all mention the same thing. You can interpret it in any language, and it still comes to mean the samething. That's not my place to say, no, I am the watcher, I see all that is the sum of man. I see the hearts and minds of creatures that are capable of love, and also capable of things unspoken. So if you find yourself approaching the gates, ask yourself what type of human you were, and what did you contribute to humanity. May the lost souls seek guidance from the unborn, innocence cannot be bargained, bought or faked. The heart is a gateway to salvation or oblivion.
Team Triss here...!

Round of Gwent?  Gwent aside (not sure why you'd do that, but for the sake of the review...Oh the things I do for you), this game is a masterpiece. It shows the true complexity of your actions, that no matter how good your intent, things can go disasterously. The graphics are very good, and only got better in B&W. Oh, and the people in Toussaint aren't complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They're actually respectful. Only a few have insulted me so far. This feels weird.    The main storyline wasn't the best in the world, as far as a certain entity counted, but it was still better than anything else out, and still to this day is. Hearts of Stone improved on all of the main entity's mistakes, and left us with one of, if not the best antagonists in history.    While I am currently going through B&W, its already shaping up to be another AAA game that CDPR has called 'DLC' once again. Great to see actual expansion packs like this in a world of AAA publishers who don't care about you and charge for everything.    Okay, I have now finished Blood and Wine: Damn, is it fantastic. People actually don't treat you like a freak, for the most part. Its weird at first, but once I got used to it, it is wonderful.   'People, like to invent monsters and monstrosities. Then they seem less monstrous themselves. When they get blind-drunk, cheat, steal, beat their wives, starve an old woman, when they kill a trapped fox with an axe or riddle the last existing unicorn with arrows, they like to think that the Bane entering cottages at daybreak is more monstrous than they are. They feel better then. They find it easier to live.' - Geralt of Rivia (The Last Wish)    Some people fight for glory, justice or gold. I fight for those I hold dear. I'm Geralt of Rivia, the Witcher.

In my honest opinion the best, or at least the best RPG, perhaps even the best game of all time. The start can be slow and combat might feel infuriating and frustrating, but once you get a grip on it it feels really fun. The world is just massive and unlike some other RPGs I've played it doesn't feel dull, boring or bland at all. All the sidequests have their own little story behind them, they're not just kill and gather type of quests. The graphics (even after the 'downgrade') are just amazing with the weather system being just stunning. The world feels really alive, with soldiers and bandits patrolling the roads, deer and wolves roaming the forest, the cities are like an ecosystem of their own and the dangerous monsters lurking in the caves and dungeons. It's the first RPG where I just could immerse myself in to. I played 7 hours on almost at one session. It even has it's own collectible card game, and it's not even a small one.  My pros: - Good graphics, weather system must have a note of its own - Combat is fun and challenging (I play on the highest difficulty) - Huge open world - Story is good, there's been a good few surprises - The card game, Gwent - Very immersive, it really feels like you are an witcher - Top-notch quality voice acting - Best bang for your buck. Since 5/28 I've played 67 hours and feel like I've done just half of what the game has to offer   Neutral about:  - Gwent, it feels too luck based - Game performance. I feel like I should better performance with OC'd 970 and OC'd i7 4790k 4.5ghz + 16gb ram.  - For some, slightly including me, the combat even on the highest difficulty might feel just a little too easy. I might just be really good at the game, don't know. - The game has so much content it might feel overwhelming for some. This is a huge bonus for me though  My cons: - Somewhat clunky controls (using controller, prefer it over kb + m) - Occasional bugs, few crashes - Some very muddy textures  My tips for new players:  ( Might contain really light spoilers. Not story related )  - Play on highest difficulty. It is really challenging, and killing boss monsters feel really rewarding - Don't start playing gwent too late - Invest in alchemy - Try to keep all the ingredients, trust me, you'll want them later on - Learn about strong monsters before encountering them - Learn to dodge, try not to roll too much - Loot pretty much everything. You'll be rich as f**k in a short while.

This is one of, if not the best story/open world game ever made.And i played all the ''greats''.After playing this game you realise how %90 of the so called ''AAA'' games are just a quick cash-grabs made for the casual audience.From the story to the soundtrack, the general atmosphere, the open world and the attention to the detail, it is obvious that this game was made with passion.  With this game CDPR set the bar so high I believe it will be a very long time before we see a game like this again.   Simply put: the greatest open world RPG ever made.

To put it simply this game is a pure masterpiece. 10/10 one the the best RPGs evermade worth buy or at least worth playing any rpg fan will not be disappointed, i reccormend playing on max difficulty to get the full experience. its a chanlleging indept Action RPG  I have seen many games with a lot of contend but most of them dont make you want to do everything, but this game every little side quest is so well crafted that it feels like its own little main story, every town ,village and ruin that you pass has it own little backstory that is presented in such an amazing way that it makes you want to learn, it truly feels like a living breathing world to explore.  The choices that you make in the game change the game in such unexpected ways. little things passing a guard in distress and helping them will much later have that person coming to help you get into a city. there is no clear right and wrong , it makes you thing about what choice would be best and then it ends up have negative effects.  the combat system is a much more refined version of the second game and is complex and truly fun it makes you make use of the enviorment and tons of potions and different buffs to craft many unique builds and play styles.  the graphics while not as good as the 2013 E3 trailer still looks like the pics on the steam page and it looks absulotly amazing, i found my self many times stoping it the middle of nowhere to enjoy the view.
Beautiful world fit for hours of exploring, countless quests and a ton of fun. Must buy!

Boring combat system. Bad difficulty balancing: 80% of the enemies are trivial, while 20% are excrutiatingly hard, without any connection to their importance to the story. Awful craftin system with millions of different components and no sane way to manage them - you just end up hoping that you have the stuff you need in the inventory by accident. Buggy movement, with protagonist and his horse constantly stubliing over insivible barriers and getting stuck in textures.  But - AMAZING writing and world-building. Every last minor quest is an interesting story; and together, they create a full, complete picture of the world you will want to explore. All the tropes you've grown to hate in fantasy stories are thrown out of the window. Instead of a blank D&D hero with artificial waggle space from Chaotic Evil to Lawful Good, you have Geralt - an excellently written character that still gives you a lot of freedom to perform meaningful moral choices.

I am a little distracted at the downgrade the game got, but all in all it is a very well put together game. Played all the witcher games and this one by far is the best   great job CD project.  Please show Cyberpunk 2055 now <3

Really solid game.    Fluid and satisfying combat, interesting story and characters, loads of content, beautiful graphics, music and art style. On top of that there are a lot of really nice references for people who've read the books and played the prior games, without making it obnoxious for people who haven't read or played those pieces of media. In other words: it manages to be friendly to new players, while satisfying fans of the series at the same time, which is very commendable.   ___________________________   Pros:

I have to say, this is by far the greatest single player experience I have had in a game in a very long time.  To begin, let's roll with the story. I will apply no spoilers - But if you are a person who thrives on an ever-changing story, one where your decisions ACTUALLY alter future and current events, you needn't look further. There are an untold amount of side quests, witcher contracts (which you can haggle for higher prices, if you can complete them), treasure hunts for both money and witcher set gear, and of course - Places of Power to find!  Geralts beard grows as time passes... How is that not F**kin awsome?!  DLC Content is released weekly, and it is free. There is no EA garbage microtransactions. And to those that say, WELL THERES A SEASON PASS! - That is for Expansion pack DLC which will provide over 30+ hours of gameplay content... Remember the old days when you bought an expansion and actually got your money worth? Well, welcome to the return of those foreign times!  The voice acting, scripts, and interactions are very on point. I haven't noticed any missed beats. Geralt is as nice or as badass as you let him be. There are some good comedy points as well, but you'll have to find those for yourself.  Combat is probably the most fluid system I have played in a game. Each movement feels real, and you can swap targets, dart/dive, mix in signs - all without ever missing a beat.  Graphically this game is very well optimized. I am by no means running a garbage machine (see specs at end of review) but it is not a top notch beast in the gaming world. I have the game set to near max graphics, and I run a constant 60+ FPS even in large scale monster battles or deserter brawls. If you can see it in the world, you can get there in the game. If you can't, it's because you reached the 'edge' of the map... I won't tell you what happens if you stray too far into the night ;-)  Character progression is amazing. I have about 40 hours on record, only hit about level 12. It does take some time, but I spend a load of time exploring and seeking the hidden treasures of this wonderful world. And yes, you are definitely rewarded for it. Anyhow, the skill system is well designed, and allows you to bend Geralt to your will - Want to be more of a mage, or perhaps a pure fighter? Maybe you just love those alchemical brews that give you ungodly powers. Maybe you want it all! You can (to an extent) - the choice is completely yours.  Difficulty... I have to say, even on normal the game provides a very nice challenge. I find the monsters just difficult enough that I am not wiping the floor with them, yet not too difficult where I have to restart every 2 minutes because said wyvern ripped my head off. The nice thing; The game warns you if said monster/quest is a bit too difficult - but it doesn't stop you from engaging haha  Don't be afeared to spend your money here - 'less you afeared the night boy, then wander elsewhere. The woods be no place for a welp, there be monsters about  Short Specs: AMD FX6300 Black 8gb DDR3 1833 GeForce 770 GTX Standard SATA HD Windows 7

this game is ♥♥♥♥ing sweet, i've spent 39 hours upon this game since its release, (today's date is 5/27/15) and it was totally worth it. The entire game has a wonderful artistic appeal to it, from the sunsets to the day breaks. the game is one of the best that i've seen. The Witcher 3 is a game I could recommend a thousand times over. Played it for 83 hours already and still nowhere near done as far as I can tell. Still dozens of quests in my book and none of them a really boring. Very little is repeated and the side quests have stories that some games could only wish to have as their main storyline. Always history to each thing you do, and the consequences become quite clear as you go through the life of Geralt. It is impossible to put in this review exactly how much content is stuffed into this game but it is well worth its buying price and more. First time in a long time where a game was made to be long without dlc pieces hacked off and fed to you later. Many game developers should take note, this is a worthy game.  The combat is fun and fluid. Even more variety than there ever has been before in how you want to build your skills. You can mix and match things from all the trees far more effectively than witcher 2 where if you did that you were gimping yourself incredibly. Mix of sword and signs and you've got yourself a deadly battle caster burning enemies and cutting them to ribbons as they flail around on fire. Go down the alchemy route and stick a few points in signs and you can make some brutal combo's with your explosives.  The story is great. It grips you from the beginning begging you to look deeper and find more hidden gems. You feel your choices have weight and what you decide may not turn out as you had planned. Save a being from a trap thinking you are doing a good deed only to find that it destroys an entire town due to your lack of foresight. Hindsight is painful in this game. Only because many a time it seems the right choice, the good choice, and then people die because of it. You must always weigh each decision carefully. I'd suggest playing the game through without going back on your choices. Live with them and see what happens. Then try again on a different game, see where all the paths lead you but stay on the one you chose.  Graphics though not what they were shown before are still damn good. Hell most people would never see the graphics that were shown anyway without several grand to toss down for a computer. So I'm fine with it being a little less shiny to allow a greater audience to play the game. Its a game worth playing and even dumbed down a little the detail is amazing. Save for my beard disappearing if I am slightly too zoomed out but just a minor pet peeve at best.  All in all its the best of the series. The open world has given it a lot of life though I will admit its a bit jarring to go from place to place then get beaten to death cause you walked into some level 30 monsters lair and you were only level 10. Usually best to do all the sidequests before checking out the treasures. A game that will be remembered for a long time as being one of the most well done RPG for a long, long time.

The game is amazing. So far no problems. Landscapes, battles and quests are amazing. If I should put a score to this game now, I will give it a 9 over 10. I recommend it to all but note that you must have a state of the art video card ;)

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is arguably one of the best games I've played in a while, years actually, and I haven't, or at least I feel I haven't, gotten through a majority of the game yet. The world is massive and the graphics complement it greatly, save for the red filter. Honestly though, the graphics are not something to scoff at. I would say it's on the level of, if not greater than, a fully modded Skyrim. As Kosmozuikis, in his review, said some things could use some work, but it doesn't detract from the overall experience at all.  The combat system feels nice, never really experienced something similar to it before -- whether that's due to having gone into a DoTA coma or some other factor I'll never know. I personally find myself going towards a certain style over the others, mainly, 'Screw blocking, everything must die!' In another run I'll probably focus more on a more defensive or counter heavy style, because I feel like I'm missing out on a lot just relying on a single sign, essentially spells, for defense.   The story is phenomenal. I have not played the prior two installments, nor have I read the books, but so far I'm captivated by the way the story is progressing. I'm not even sure if I'm halfway through the game yet, but it keeps getting better and better. More than likely I'll end up reading the books due to my thirst for knowing more about the lore of the world. Sound-wise I've found myself getting scared, I'm a major wuss, when the music gets darker and I'm in the middle of a cavern or out doing a contract. The atmosphere in general is just amazing, especially when you go to any of the cities.  I have yet to play Gwent yet, mainly because of my want to explore everything. For example, 'Ohhh, treasure... OH LOOK A BASILISK...' And then subsequently realizing that it has question marks for a level and then bolting faster than Usain Bolt. I digress, for now Gwent is something that is secondary to me, but I will eventually get into it on another play through.   Overall... 9.99999/10 (Might as well be a 10/10) gg CDPR gg

Brilliant as The Witcher 2 was, it suffered from wrapping its story up in the politics of an imaginary world. Players who weren’t familiar were constantly exposed to new nations, and new figures from those nations, and even if you did educate yourself on who they were and why they mattered, it’s hard to care about imaginary politics. Wild Hunt learns from this mistake, and gives you a very clear, and a very compelling goal: find Ciri, your surrogate daughter. There are a few brief flashbacks that sell you on who she is and why Geralt cares for her, but more importantly there’s a clarity of purpose here that does a few things exceedingly well.

I picked this up when it first released, and put in about 20 hours into it initially before other things caught my attention. I decided to get through the game over Christmas weekend, and man do i feel bad for letting this one sit on my 'shelf'. I haven't been this engrossed in a RPG since Skyrim. I'm about 50 hours in, and i'm no where near done with my first play through of the game, and already planning my New Game + playthrough.  To be quite honest, i never got into the Witcher series, i picked up Witcher 2 on a sale, and maybe have a total of 3-4 hours in that game. So i was skeptical when a friend recommended the third installment. I'm glad that i got this when it first released because the developer deserves every penny of that initial purchase price.   The world feels alive, there's nothing better than galloping down a dirt road, and the wind picks up, and you see the trees start buckling under the strong gale. It feels lived in, and not just like a playground for the player, i feel like i dropped into a world that actually exists.   It feels real, not everyone is happy to see the hero, some people try to actively hurt you for disregarding their customs, or just because of their fear of Witchers.   I could go on and on, but i think i'll just play some more.

After many Hours with this game, and close to my first finished Playthrough, i decided to write this.   The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a very special game of sorts. Let me first Talk about the Cons!  Cons - Controls  Many times into the story you just wanna grab your mouse and smash it into a wall. 'No Roach start to Gallop now, no Geralt i want you the get OUT THE WATER' UGGGH!... Its the biggest con for me so far, and maybe its just because i don't like to play with a controller.   -Narration bugs I don't really know if this is a Bug, Or for some strange reason done that way (if this is what you wanted.... please fire the Game Designer... he deserves it). Whenever you fast travel from one 'country' to another (from Skellige to White Orchard for example) Dandelion will explain you the story, over and over again. and you cannot skip this, its a Loading Screen, and Dandelion going 'now that Geralt knew where to go...'. It would be okay, if he would be up to date. but until the last portion of the Game he always tells you, the story of this specific area of the world... even though you already finished everything in that area.   Another big sad Part is for me...     Even After the Bloody Baron killed himself (he did so in my Story line) he keeps being Mentioned as the Current owner of Uma, only in the Quest text itself is speaks of his Sergeant who took his place     -Fighting  This here is only counting for the combat with your fists. its dull, its stupid, and its absolutely no fun to be killed by 6 people packing up on you and you have to beat them with your fists. This also counts for Geralts buggy swords. Sometimes the game thinks combat is over, and he sheathes his sword, the next moment you try to slap a Water Hag with your fists, get repelled and take a great amount of damage, cause the game decided to sheathe your weapon.   -Many other tiny little Problems I just make a short list, and people who wanna know more should read up on it. Game was designed with controllers in mind. Sadly this also means, the Menu screens are bugged beyond repair sometimes. You hit ESC to get out of the menu, but it keep selecting a Item, his ESC again, it goes to a item again. UUUGH! get your Menu's right! You are far too many times in your Inventory. Your Carry Capacity is way too low, after a while by just collecting alchemy supplies, and Crafting goods, i had 80/90 packed, but nothing i wanted to craft. And there is no stache or something. Your Weapons are ♥♥♥♥. Fight 10 Drowners and its down to 70% durability. where it starts to rapidly lose damage. Weapons break far too easily. Applying Oil to your weapons should be in the 'TAB' Menu and not be managed over the Inventory screen (basically always going into your Inventory and breaking from the fight)  So this is my List of Con's other peoplementon Graphical Problems and all... i must say.... 'horse ♥♥♥♥♥' the game looks decent. And there are enough ways to tweak it nicely (sweetFX configs and so on).   PRO's  -Combat The Combat in the Witcher always was quite real, you have to be careful of a beasts swipes and have to dodge or parry attacks, cant just slap into enemy's until you win (unless you play the lowest difficulty) You have to know what enemy you are facing, its weaknesses and how to beat it. Have to use oils, sigils, bombs even, in order to get some of the more fierce monsters to bite the dust. But don't Worry the Beastiary is your best friend.   -Sigils You are no wizard. But you have Sigils, and Axii is probably your best friend of them all. don't underestimate the use of them. They help you. a lot!   -Alchemy You make a Potion once, and every time you meditate you refill them as long as you have Alcohest. Sound's broken? It's not. It is absolutely okay i think. You run around, gather ingredients to make Potions like Swallow or Cat, and when you need em you just use them, but don't overdue it, if you drink too much, you will die.  -The Story While flawed at some points, its a lot of fun to play through the Story and to see how HUGE this game is, and how deeply most things... weave into one another.   -The Talk You do not understand English? I am deeply sorry for you. This game is awesome when it comes to language, should totally play it English with Subtitles in your language.   -The Witcher I always loved how... 'hated' Witcher's are. It is to me one of the biggest hight's the Story has to offer. People will beg you to help them with killing a beast, you Agree, for Pay, and they call you a heartless greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The world damn well knows how to work in the fact, honest pay for honest work. Even when the peasants keep crying about you beeing greedy and ♥♥♥♥.   Thing that would have made the Game better for me: -Stealth Geralt is not exactly stealthy. sadly. And that's what i am looking for usually, a more stealthy approach to things. Maybe an option 'lets wait until the beast falls asleep' or something like that.    So do i recommend this game?  Yes and No. I only Recommend it to people who are willing to dive into a huge Game, that will force you to read a LOT, force you to do a lot of sightseeing, and force you to stop on your Story Quest to do some random ♥♥♥ thing, which helps in the end to improve your character and overall bond with the Game's world.   My Recommended Setting for Difficulty:  - Just here for the Story - If you wanna have a very easy game, no need to worry about anything. No Potions are needed, no Oils, no Brain. This setting really is just for people who wanna hop from one Story point to the Other.  - Story and Sword - Here you will need some Brain, you need Potions, you need some Knowledge on how things work. Its i think the Perfect setting for Witcher Newbies and for the first playthrough  - Blood and Bones You need everything i have mentioned before and then some, Enemys do significantly more damage, have more health and you NEED to know how to beat every Enemy. Perfect Setting for Veterans and for People who really seek a challenge  - Death March Almost everything will oneshot you. Geralt is almost 100 Years old. And here we notice how fragile it must be, be Witcher or not. You have to plan your every move, you have to chose the fights carefully, it feels very realistic, Only chose this on your second or third Playthrough, so you know what kind of things will await you.

TL;DR: One of the best RPG games I have ever played, though it may not be for everyone (and that's okay)  Pros: +Excellent graphics and perfomance +Well written and believable characters +Lengthy and interesting main quest +Some of the best side-quests in any RPG made to date +Interesting enemies +Fun side activities (Especially Gwent) +Gwent +Amazing world to explore +Fantastic soundtrack +Your choices have consequences +Lots of options in combat +16 pieces of free DLC  Cons: -If you do the side-quests you become overleveled for the main quest quickly -Leveling can happen rapidly of slowly depending on playstyle -Combat at lower difficulties is repetitive -Even at higher difficulties you become overpowered quickly -Many options presented for combat not necessary when overleveled -Some players may be dissapointed to only be able to RP as Geralt  Overall an excellent RPG, but you can quickly become overpowered by completing side-quests making combat a bit repetitive. That does not, however, detract from the game in the slightest, Worth picking up at the asking price, even more of an amazing deal on sale.
