I have been playing The Witcher 3 for 144 hours now, and finally I have finished the game! At first my plan was to just play the main storyline, but I got so immersed into the game that before I knew it I completed all the sidequests without any regrets. The Witcher 3 is definitely my game of the year 2015 and might just top my list of best games of all time!   So yeah... the story:  Since The Witcher 2, Gerald has regained his memory. This allowed him to search for Yennefer so they can both search for their lost adopted daughter Ciri. Ciri namely has The Elder Blood running through her veins. This Elder Blood can be used to summon one the most powerful magical spells which opens a gateway between dimensions which will lead to the destruction of worlds. So with Ciri on the run from these demons called The Wild Hunt, Gerald sets out to find Ciri and help her defeat these enemies. On the search Geralds meets many new and old friends, which together play a part in the amazing adventure that is The Witcher 3!    The best things of The Witcher 3:   -The writing is the strongest point of the game. The main storyline is amazing and has a some of the most epic gaming moments in gaming history. There is a lot of attention to detail in the cinematics which makes the story much more immersive. There is also a lot of great humor in the game which everybody should love. The best thing of The Witcher 3 is that every quest, even the smallest of sidequests have an interesting story. Ofcourse many of the sidequest end with you just killing a monster, but the writers wrote a storyline around it which makes it interesting almost every time. So you are constantly helping people for a reason instead of just helping people with gathering items.  -The game the beautiful graphics to date in an RPG, especially the lighting and amount of detail everywhere. This resulted in an enormous amount of screenshots for me every time I played the game.  -The game has one of the best sword battle systems from any game I've played. Especially because the higher you set the difficulty, the more immersed you will have to be in the game to stay alive. Instead of simply slaying monsters on easy, higher difficulties require you to prepare for battles, brew potions, pick the right bombs etc. At the start of the game this preparation might seem daunting, reading through a lot of lore to find out what to use to kill each monster. But after a while you know exactly which monsters require which strategies which makes killing them a lot more fun. This battle system adds a lot of variation to the gameplay which immersed me into the game even more because it forces you learn about the lore and the world as you go.  -GWENT!!!!!!! -> Doesn't need explanations.  -That Bloody Baron questline, mannn <3    The somewhat lesser great things of The Witcher 3:  - The main story line kinda goes into the background when you start doing sidequests, especially at the first 50 hours of the game when you are just exploring the world. This way the 'search for Ciri' could lead into Gerald just doing his thing for weeks and then deciding to go search his daughter again. On the other side, I don't really see how this could be improved other than reducing the amount of sidequests. - Some parts of the story feel rushed (The End), while other feel fleshed out (The Search for Ciri). The Search for Ciri is however filled with amazing main story questlines, so you won't feel bored. Its just that the overall story basically is on hold until you finally find Ciri after following leads for many many hours (of amazing other adventures).   Personally I think this is the best RPG currently on the marked and thus I really really recommend this game to anybody who likes open world games and has the will to dive into a deep, complex and epic story!  I also really recommend you buying the Hears of Stone DLC, which is an amazing addition to the main game!

Easily the best action RPG to date.  First of I’ll go by mentioning what I didn’t like: - The Witcher 3 suffers from the same issue most open RPGs do, it has a major plot that drags - is this a bad thing? not really, but it’s ironic that when the whole world is at stake Geralt can still prance around, I’d like to see some risk/reward system that makes the game harder if the protagonist takes their time to finish or continue certain aspects of the game. - I didn’t like how the game ended, after beating and getting one of the many ending the game boasts about you’re sent back to the world where everything has reverted back to what was before the final phase actually began, this just seemed lazy. - Maps are too condensed, walk 50m to the right and you get an event, I’d like a more dynamic system where bandit camps may move around certain locations  I have to admit that emotion gets the better of me after seeing the level of detail and care CDPR took, they built a truly amazing world from the books, Novigrad and Oxenfurt are some of the best and most believable medieval cities in any format ever.  The characters are amazing, CDPR had already proven with the Witcher 2 that they know how to bring book characters to the interactive format, they proved it again with The Wicther 3. Even though some of the best characters aren’t even from the books, but I’ll leave that to you to find on your own ;)

I'm going to touch on some things that some reviews don't bother to mention about the game. Mainly the environment, sounds, and performance.  The environment. It is probably one of the nicest environments I've played since Metro Last Light. Now while it may be more like Skyrim in its nature, it has the immersion of the Metro, which is the most immersive game I've experienced. Everything you do is compounded by the environment, fighting is largely influenced by it as well. Oh, you got backed into a corner and still got 3 enemies left and a sliver of health. Maybe you shouldn't have approached the pier and came from ect direction instead. Its small things like this that really get me going, it adds replayability and strategy on how to go about dispatching enemies. Much of the game is already akin to strategy, you cannot just spam attack, you have to be tactical about it. If a sword alone isn't doing it, then maybe set up Yrden as a trap or back off and use some bombs. I'm really waiting for a mod that makes a penalty out of dying.  Then comes the sound and ambient graphics. Its a pretty game, no doubt about it. It shows in the cutscenes and it shows as your riding your house around the block. At times it may feel lack luster, but thats only once you get used to the beauty of it. After all a sunny day can only be interesting so many times. The sound helps kick things back into immersion though. I would definitely recommend playing this game full volume with headphones in a dark room. The sound of the wolves growling or the wind rushing by as your speed on your house are really great and it is this small things that come together to make it a master piece.  Unfortunately there is a lot of bad news surrounding this game with Nvidia Gameworks and the like as well as poor performance. I myself using two 780s in SLI cannot achieve a solid 60 fps on full settings at 1080p. Dips as low as 30fps in some scenarios. This is just one of those games that you cannot play on full settings. As nice as Hairworks is I would recommend turning it off and setting the game to high or medium, even if you have an enthusiast level graphics card. Because this game is very vulnerable to choppy motion as a result of going from 30fps to 60fps three times in 6 seconds depending on the direction you are looking.

Youre going to want to pull your hair out in the beginning. The graphics are CRAZY, and that comes with pros and cons. If your computer isnt nearly to great, good luck running the game on great looking graphics. The controls will take a couple hours to get used to, and i fully suggest connecting a controller from a console because the amount of keybinds this game has will make you use every button on your keyboard. But after about 4 hours of me regretting buying this game on PC rather than on Console i finally began to enjoy it and I fully recommend this game to people who are looking for a game to spend hours on !

After reading the books and being a massive fan, I still had my doubts about the Witcher, simply due to it's playstyle and mechanics. Nevertheless, all of these fears were abolished when I had finally finished all side-quests as well as contracts 87 hours into the game. However, I still had not even finished all of the question marks (?) on the map, hinting that I had only completed maybe half the game?   The Witcher 3 story I felt competed with amazing storytellers such as Ken Levine with Bioshock and the incredible focus on the 'small things' as shown in the Elder Scrolls: Skyrim. The game is what can only be described as an emotional rollercoaster of fear, happiness, worry but excitement! Every side-quest has it's own unique storyline, giving the feeling that one person was designed through the entire production process to make that side-quest memorable and engaging.  With this being the end of the Geralt Triology, I wasn't saddened, as with the end of one story, another begins.  Bioshock was my favourite game of all time, but I am confident that this game passed the greatness of the Bioshock triology (Thus far) and if Fallout 4 is to be released this year as another one of my favourites, it will have to do it's damn hardest. :)

You that feeling you get when you watch a movie and leave though it touched you in some way?  Finally found a single player game worthy of 160 hours. People laughed at me when I told them how much time I dedicated to this game, completing all the secondary, contracts and treasure hunts before the primary quest line. I cried at the end, as if I was emotionally attached to the storyline and it was my child.   What I liked the most:  - Making real decisions quickly and accepting the concequences of those dicisions. - Facing off with massive beasts and trying to figure how the hell you beat them. - if you get bored of the quest side, just roam, plent to see and do.  The ability to explore was the one thing that lured me in. Though, in saying that there are certain things that did irratate me from time to time. These were:  - the clunky movement of Geralt, especially near small bridges, ledges and things that require precise movement. - about 5% of the missions were glitched and I was not able to finish them. (I expect this to be corrected in the future naturally)  - The explore tactics applied to the vast ocean areas was quite dull. (Placing smugglers drops everywhere doesnt make it interesting) - The go fetch this and give it to that person, or go kill this person and report back can get dull after a while. Hence, why they suggest go to explore a bit inbetween.   ...160 hours, around the same amount of time to finish a subject at most universitys. Though, I feel the money I spent on it was well worth the entertainment value.   Happpy I purchased this game. UB.

When this game first came out, i had no cinsideration even buying it. So when this game came out, i was not expecting what i have found out... I got this game for 29.99! on sale... and all I have to say, is this game is amazing! ive put over 40 hours into it in 3 days, and still not done with the main story... but close.  The fighting mechanics are a little weird at first, but once you get used to it, it is FUN. I love how they made the map in this game, it tells you where to actually go, and land marks etc. (some thing very close to skyrim/fallout)  the story line, its great and a lot of fun if you do side quests and explore, but when you get down to it, most of the story is pretty boring, mostly because youre just chasing some one, and it gets pretty old after 25 hours of asking people 'have you seen *****?' their response, 'i have, but you have to do some thing for me to tell you' as you can tell, that will get annoying pretty quick.  The graphics are stunning! but its 2015, why would they not be?  $30 well spent! and this game went far and beyond my expectations. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt This to me is the definition of what an open world RPG should be. The Witcher 3 hits every point necessary to create a large and well written world that the player can truly get lost in. The storytelling on its own is some of the best in the genre creating meaningful relationships with curious friends, lovely heroines, and bitter enemies. The Slavic lore from which the universe is themed has captivated me and kept me engrossed in the game. Turning up the difficulty forces the player to use the tools at the Witchers disposal further engrossing me in the fairly simple combat style. In the gameplay the items, spells, and systems reward the player for their proper utilization against specific monsters and situations. These details are coupled with the numerous small additions added over the course of the year by CD Projekt Red, completely free of charge. (Free DLC? In 2015? Absurd!) Not to mention the paid DLC, Heart of Stone, was one the best written stories in a fantasy title ive encountered in the medium. Overall the title sets a new pedigree when it comes to how Fantasy RPG's should be designed and I cannot commend CD Projekt Red enough for their hard work and success this year. (GOTY 2015)
Great game. Worth every penny. Lots of DLC too.

Masterpiece! One of the most beautiful and complex worlds ever created. A world so full of life and story that after a while you can't believe it's possible in a game. Some side quests are hours long, with rich story arcs and complex characters, masterful story telling. I was so caught up in the game I didn't notice right away, that you can go for hours without a load screen, the game constantly loads in the background as you move through the world! All games need to do this!   There are vistas so beautiful, I found myself just staring with awe over the landscape and ocean views. It's so refreshing to have an RPG with such vibrant colour, and so real.  There is so much value in this game, so many hours of gameplay, and CD Projekt Red has gone above and beyond with free DLC, when so many other developers would nickel and dime. For that reason alone, they have become my favorite developer.  No game is perfect, but the bugs and flaws are small. The movement felt a bit unatural when first released, but has been patched, this game has a high level of polish.  A new bar has been set in RPG gaming, all future games will be compared to this one.  Masterpiece!

(Full disclosure: I've not beaten the game, as I'm only 125 hrs into this RPG masterpiece, having just recently gotten into Act 3 a couple dozen hours ago or so. I will be lucky if I finish it before hour 200, and I'm already looking forward to my next playthrough...)  What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? I'd agree with most everything everyone has been stating. I thought it was all hyperbole, but thankfully, I was wrong. Rather than rehash what has been stated time and again, I will simply point out that I have tried to find fault with this game, and I've only found a single one that sorta sticks out--and that's not even really fair:  I can't play as a Pure Mage. I can't play as a Sneaky Thief. Often, when I play an RPG, I prefer to avoid direct Melee (e.g., via Stealth, Artillery Fire via Spells, &c.), and this is not really possible in the Witcher 3. It's not really fair to hold this against it, as in this RPG I play as a Badass Witcher named Geralt--not a character of my own Design. It kind of reminds me of playing as Commander Shepard (although there seemed to be more flexibility in how I could play my Shepard), which isn't a bad thing at all. And in many ways, this more focused narrative direction--whilst somewhat more restrictive in character direction/growth--leads to more meaningful plot and character arcs than games that are more open-ended lend themselves to. And the interwoven 'side' missions (that are anything BUT irrelevant fetch-quests and other RPG standards) are always making me want to talk to that next person, or pursue that next quest... I think the only things more beautiful in this game than the writing are the gorgeous sunsets. I have screenshot wallpapers for years...  I think it worth noting that this is really my only gripe, and that's a pretty huge compliment itself. Keeping in mind my preference for avoiding melee (whilst being forced into it regularly as Geralt), the fact that this has quickly become one of my favorite games in years (ever?) only reinforces how incredibly mind-blowingly amazing this game is.  I've read some criticisms re: the Witcher's combat. FWIW, this is one of my first 3 games as a 2K16 PC Master Race n00b (longtime Sony fanboy who is Hardcore about his Casual playstyle ;-), and I'm enjoying Normal difficulty (and that kb+m is still taking some time getting fully used to for me). I'm finding it no more or less clunky than any other game I'm playing on my new gaming PC.  So, in case I didn't make it clear, I absolutely LOVE this game. I don't know that it's 'The Best Game EVAR(TM)', but I wouldn't argue with those who do. It's certainly up there--no question. Most importantly, it's engaging, impossible to not get lost in for countless hours (game of Gwent, anyone?), and as beautiful as it is unique in its handling of the High Fantasy genre. I would recommend this to gamers who don't like RPG's or Fantasy. If you don't hate RPG's or Fantasy, why haven't you played this game yet?  Did I mention how breathtaking the sunsets are?

Wild Hunt is the new RPG by which all other RPGs should be judged. Not only has CD Projekt Red deliverered the largest and most convincing fantasy open-world we’ve ever seen, but a storyline, quests and systems that make it an incredibly compelling place to run, ride and sail around in. It’s the GTA 5 or Red Dead Redemption of sword and sorcery sagas and the biggest, most breathtaking time sink you’re likely to play.  PROS:  ✓ Huge, coherent and immersive game world ✓ Game systems and storyline both engage ✓ Beautifully rendered characters and scenery ✓ Crammed with interesting quests, side-quests and activities ✓ Geralt a more mature and sympathetic lead

Pros 31 hours so far and I'm on level 13, with dozens of side quests and monster contracts unfulfilled and there are also little random encounters throughout the world. Not only is there a lot of content, this content if actually INTERESTING - there are quirky characters, interesting consequences to your actions, changing combat tactics depending on who/what you are fighting (and there are a LOT of monsters!) nice music which changes dynamically to the situation, cutscenes even on smaller quests which add to the narrative. And I've probably spent several of my gameplay hours just messing around playing the mini game Gwent!  Theres been some controversy about the graphics, but playing this on an R9 280x (R9 290 was the recommended I believe) this game is still one of the best looking games I've played, especially when considering the scope of the game world (the city of Novigrad alone is huge and I haven't been to the Skellige islands yet which I'm told are another big area!)   Cons The story is interesting, long and full of many characters (31 hours and only level 13 remember!) so even having played the Witcher 2 I was a little bit lost at the beginning. If you are new to this game look up some info about the backstory and the lore before playing as you will ease into the game more!   There is still a little bit of a learning curve at the beginning with the various aspects of gameplay - combat, potions, signs, inventory, bestiary, crafting, alchemy .etc etc. BUT having played over 30 hours later in the game I can say this is appreciated as it adds interest and variety to the gameplay.  Overall I would say this game feels like a triple A game that the developers actually put the time and effort into, making one of the best games I've played in a very long time.

TLDR: - Stop thinking, and buy this atoundingly good game.  Long Version: Like many newcomers to this series, I played The Witcher 3 before I read any of the books, or played the first two games. I was intrigued by the colorful, varied, and lively Witcher Universe. I greatly desired to play the first two games, though I was unable to, as I just had an Xbox One (I know). On the Xbox, it was still a fantastic game, really only let down by the graphics (or lack thereof), and the horrendous load times that exceeded two minutes for not just the initial load, but all subsequent loads, including those during fast travel and after dying. I didn't know about the novels that inspired this incredible series yet, so when I built my very own PC, I immedeately bought the Witcher Trilogy on steam during the Summer Sale. I expected the first two games to be a drag, the first one more so than the second, and I only wanted to play them for the background for the third, but much to my surprise I was wrong. Due to my faulty expectations, I skipped the vast majority of side quests for the first two chapters, and upon learning of the novels, I decided that I would read the books, then start the trilogy over. Boy am I glad I did, the books were a phenomenal read, some of the best books I have had the pleasure of reading. This is coming from someone who thought the joy in reading died with his youth, someone who hasn't done a lick of reading outside of assigned works for years, since early middle school. The books gave me an immense understanding of the Witcher's world, I knew about monsters before I had seen them, I trembled at the thought of fighting a Griffin, or a Higher Vampire (though the fight was disappointing to say the least). I knew the characters before I saw them, had my own feelings for them, knew how Geralt felt about them, about his past trysts, affairs, and the like. I knew who had used him, abused him, and who had been used by him. I felt unequivocal hatred towards certain characters, a platonic love towards others. Needless to say, I am extremely happy I read the books. I knew things about characters that changed my actions, things that, had I not known them, the game would've ended very differently. The books supplement the games, and vice versa. Each one a masterpiece in its own regard, but together, unparalleled in scope and depth. I can't recommend reading the books enough, If you enjoy the games, you are sure to enjoy the books, even if you don't normally like reading (like me). Buy the games, buy the books, and enjoy what is quite simply, the best narrative I have ever heard.

Note: this review was originally written shortly after the game came out. I have just recently played through the two major expansions - 'Heart of Stone' and 'Blood and Wine' - and editited this review to reflect this.  The game is epic and the story and world keep you captivated throughout. This is by far the best open world and story telling rpg experience there is. Forget Skyrim or the Fallout games (including Fallout 4 and it's expansions). This is the new standard all future games in this genre will have to measure up against.  The huge world never feels empty, but rather alive and lived in, and just exploring this war torn world provides an imense satisfaction. The quests are interesting and diverse, and full of choices, and even small encounters provide you with snippets of lore or small side stories. There are few really good or bad people, and even the heroes have their edges and dark sides. If you have read the books and/or played the previous games you will feel right at home (and if you haven't and come to like the game: read them, too), with many favourite characters returning to make their appearances.  Plan for a lot of time to sink into this one. My first playthrough (just finished) took me 200+ hours (base game only) covering many but far from all sidequests (I left out many treasure hunts, ignoring them almost completely once I had my feline witcher gear in order, as well as missing a few quests that were simply not available after certain points in the story). Little of this was due to the difficulty, but rather because of the sheer amount of things to do, the long and well told story, the well laid out world design and the pure fun of exploration! With the two expansions I added easily another 100 hours on top of that (still on the first playthrough!). 'Hearts of Stone' expands the existing maps with more terrain and additional content all over, while 'Blood and Wine' adds a new huge map with even more content.  Also, almost no technical issues out of the box - and it has been improved all over during the last year. The game plays well on average hardware and looks stunning even on my notebook (with a GTX870M). Kudos for that, we've seen so many big dissapontments in this regard over the last few years, that this is actually worth mentioning. Not to forget the free DLC released for the game - and paid DLC that is actually woth the money and offers more content each than some full games.  Regarding the expansions: Without wanting to spoil their story let it be said that these are the best expansions I have yet seen for any game. The Fallout series had some nice DLCs over the years, but they pale in comparison to these - storywise as well as in the amount of content they add. As the main game they have their sad and hilarious moments, offer a great story each and are well worth the money and time.  If you like immersive open world rpgs with real time combat and the very best story telling in the genre, this is the game to go for. There were other great games in 2015 (e.g. Fallout 4 which I also loved and played), but even in 2016 nothing equals this game in scope, quality and pure fun!

Simple one of the best games in a long, long time. The level of detail in the world is exceptional and the free-form ability of the gameplay allows for genuine freedom with the game world.  I was amazed at the quantity and bredth of 'side quests' and missions that are external to the main narrative and found this added not just to replayability but also to the feel of being 'part' of the world.   The choices you have to make feel believeable and I found myself on more than one occasion wishing I had chosen differently - however this questioning of my choices simply made my journey as Geralt seem all the more compelling.   Notions of good and evil on the micro scale vanish in a world that feels believable, harsh, beautiful and violent in all whilst maintaining a level of variation and engagement not in many recent triple A games.   Buy it. Buy it now.

This would have to be my favourite game of all time.   An amazing story with loveable characters and a near-endless amount of side-quests to discover.  I still find myself coming back each week and playing a little bit more of this game.   I would strongly recommend getting the Season Pass for this game, the DLC packs alone are beyond-better than some of the AAA games that have come out this year.  All the voice overs are believeable and authentic, although an occasional background towns person may sound a bit cheesy. But that still adds to the charm of the world.  The combat has been majorly redefined since Witcher 2; I wouldn't say it is easier but it is certainly more intuitive. The animations are excellent and all the cutscenes are rendered in real time.  The game also runs brilliantly, with plenty of graphic options that I think will future proof it for a long time.

Let aside the fact that the game borders on perfection, I am just in love with the way the developers of the game do business. Most other gaming companies would have charged for the DLCs. I have so much faith in the developers that for the first time in my gaming life, I bought the season pass for the expansion packs. Love it, thank you CDPR for many many fun and memorable hours.
Those who made this game are not game developers but artists

This is one of the most beautiful, stunning, and detailed games I have ever played. It is set in an interesting world with deep lore that I am now completely hooked on. (Would totally recommend you read the books too btw). With The Witcher 3, CDPR simply makes other games look half finished and sub par.  The combat is great, and animations are bloody. The skill sytem is improved and allows you to build your character in a certain way rather than being a god at everything by late game. A sign/fast attack build, which I went with, was pretty fun. There is something satisfying in burning witch hunters alive with a stream of Igni. The mutations introduced in the Blood and Wine expansion were great options to enhance your character further.   My only gripes: - Cant pause the (sometimes long) cutscenes without alt tabbing or a mod.  -  The inventory system has been simplified since witcher 2, harder to find certain things. Eg, withcer 2 had a tab just for bombs, but bombs here are stored along with others in a more generic 'usable items'.   FIXED WITH PATCH!! - They shafted all the people who played an Iorveth/Saskia playthrough in witcher 2. :\  One of the best things however in that a lot of secondary quests have very interesting stories, and they are not simply fetch quests but often tell their own complex tale.  Pick carefully in your dialoge choices, as this can really alter how you expeience the game. (A great touch of story personalisation). I want to play this game again in order to experience the different endings and consequences - And thats the thing, choices arent black and white good/evil.  'There are no lesser evils.'  I played the expansions and omg they were cool - so much good content. I ABSOLUTELY URGE YOU TO PLAY THIS GAME!

Bad :    Points of interests (questions) are silly and i think the only use for them is to fill the map.   Story of the second dlc, is not so awesome, but this is a minor point.   Combat is easy in main game, even on death march.  Hints: PLay witcher 1 and 2 before this one, because you will be confuse, and will say on forums how shityy is this game. ( i saw many complains because of story, is poor, but they never tried to understand more) This game is the last one , so, make a good playthrough.  For fans who played witcher 1 and 2: this is a great improvement, combat is better, gwent is more fun than dice poker, and more romance options. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is exceeding my expectations and living up to the hype. The game looks downright gorgeous at times, and performs admirably on my modest 2 GB GTX-680/ i7-3770k rig. The game is a bit rough around the edges from a technical standpoint, but I'm sure CD Projekt Red will roll out the necessary patches. Simply put, this is a role-playing world I cannot leave. Everything from the dialogue to the score is handled masterfully. The combat is more tactical and engaging than any of the previous Witcher titles. Dynamic weather effects with THE BEST water I've ever seen in a game, make this truly feel 'Next-Gen'. Not to mention, the sheer scope of the game world the developers have crafted here. This game is something that must be experienced and played--for hours upon hours. No amount of graphical glitches or framerate stumbles can take away from the soul this game carries with it.

A gorgeous, heartfelt, deeply satisfying roleplaying game that has been carefully considered right down to the various fetch quests and unimportant monster hunts. CD Projeckt Red cares about its customers and even more about its game. The pride they took in crafting TW3 can been seen in every line of dialogue and every shining link in Geralts chainmail. The DLC amounts to the sort of oldschool expansions that many believed lost: expansions as games in their own right well worth the money you trade for memorable experiences. With EA and Sega you get worthless skins and new units that do little to change the games they populate. Most can't recall the specific content they have bought because it is bland and predictable. I'll be in a nursing home somewhere fifty years from now and still be able to relish the fun I had playing through the plot of Hearts of Stone my in the same way I remember the roller coaster ride of playing through Brood War.   Companies like Sega and EA rely on customer stupidty to leech as much money from gamer wallets as they can with as shallow of content as possible. Giving CD Projeckt Red my money was a pleasure. At the risk of broaching the absurd, I'd say it was a priviledge.

One of the best games I have ever played. A true masterpiece, etc. etc.  PROS: - Great graphics. - Great and strategic combat system. - A ton of content. - A fantastic and long story, with great characters. - Proper implimentation of RPG elements. - Great and in-deapth crafting and alchemy systems. - Gorgeous landscape, especially the cities. - A huge world filled with things to do. - Well optimized. - Great soundtrack. - Gwent. - More stuff that I can't think of atm.  CONS: - Some clunky animations and controls some times. - Kind of empty after the main story, as you can not see it affecting the world. - A few minor bugs here and there.  This game is worth three times the asking price. It is one of the best games of this decade in my opinion. If you have money, you should buy it, even if you have to starve for a week.

Just the story - 35 hrs to complete Story and sword - 150 hrs to complete Blood and broken bones - 750 hrs to complete Death march - 999999999999999999+ hrs to get past the first mission  Pros- *amazing story *amazing graphics *runs really well 55-60fps on a 960 with medium graphics *good characters *side quests that affect the story and are fun *mods *different ending based on the choices you make and the side quests you do *loads of different items *fun combat *amazing soundtrack (especially the skellege song) which you can also get free with the game, its in your installation folder  Cons- -absolutely ♥♥♥♥ all to do afterwards. when you complete the game it puts you into an end game world that is set before the final bit of the main story. All of the main characters are no where to be found on the whole map which sucks loads. So all there is to do is get on your horse and ride around. I'll buy the DLC soon as soon as I get paid so I have that to play but still, they could have at least put the characters on the map  I suppose you could install the companion mod to get them there with you but still.  Even still, I really recommend this game. Everything about it is perfect apart from the end game world. And i've heard the dlc is even better.

There are many games out there, most will provide some entertainment but inevitably over the space of a few weeks and months they will be forgotten or will simply be disgarded. Then there are the games that stay with you, the games that you remember, the ones you return too time and time again, the 'classics'. Make no mistake this is a classic.   In truth, I've never been a huge fan of third person RPG's, but I found myself looking for a new game to play. I wanted a new world to explore and a rich story to delve into, so I began searching the store for such a title, and quickly stumbled across Witcher 3. Intrigued, I checked out the screenshots, then read the reviews - they swayed me almost immediately.  So I bought the game. At first I was unsure if i'd made the right choice, the world was simply stunning, but I found the camera and movement a bit awkward. However after playing for an hour these initial fears were banished. I quickly began to realise the sheer quality and scope in this game, and the more I witnessed, the more certain I was that Witcher 3 was worth every single penny.   If ever you want to lose yourself in a world, this is it. The scenery is nothing short of majestic, you will frequently stop to admire your surroundings - You will savour each stunning sunset, and find yourself seeking shelter from ferocious storms. As i'm sure you'll be thinking, good graphics alone do not make a game, I agree. The true enjoyment of this game comes from its variety of characters and fluid combat.  I fell in love with the characters populating this world. Each one was unique and believable. I was amazed at how the smallest decisions, could have such dramatic ramifications. The characters brought the world of Witcher 3 to life.   The combat speaks for itself.  Its a rare enough thing, to complete a game and feel a mixture of elation and dispair. Joy at witnessing such a masterpiece. Sorrow knowing that it be a very long time, before another game can even get close to matching this.  I envy those yet to play and yet to experiance Witcher 3. If you do buy this game throw yourself into the world. Enjoy the journey - believe me, you'll enjoy every second of it.

Is it possible to make a short review of this game? Well, yes, definitely! If I have to choose one word 'bout this game it would, frankly, be: Fantastic!  But I am not able to simple sit back and say nothing more - before I knew anything 'bout this I sought for a game that was worthy for a title of a true time-killer, like The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Kingdom Hearts 2.5 HD ReMix (and the ReMix predecessor). Even though I've naught touch or heard anything 'bout the earlier titles presented and made by CD Red Projekt, I could naught help but to notice the trailer and the talk 'bout it. My curiosity was sprouted by what my simple eye caught in the content of the trailer; the astounding graphics, the vast-looking scenery, not to mention the taste of immersion in the farms, the life in the streets of cities, the adventurous feeling I felt by simple looking at the protagonist galloping through the well-a-lot-made wilderness.  Despite being hesitant by nature 'bout games I've naught tried yet, I was already convinced to at least give it a try caused by my longing for finding a game that was as good as the earlier mentioned different franchises. But... oh boy!  This game has an incredible vast content of story to tell that could easily be matched with or even surpass most of the story in the world of Kingdom Hearts, and believe me, it is enormous for a franchise. The earlier mentioned description of the visual content inside of the game easily surpasses TESOV: Skyrim compared how long PS3/Xbox 360 existed before the release of the latest single-player TESO-title. After a year and a half of the release of PS4/Xbox One CD Red Projekt was able to make a game that made several, if not dozen of standards of what you should expect of a game that stands true to the RPG-genre. The trailer did not in the slightest delivered unfaithful content, more likely otherwise, and even more: Immersive world which is full of sprawling life with people and collectible vegetation, challenging creatures and monsters with a battle-system which fitted the nature of the protagonist as agile, fast-paced and full of variety, exciting and compelling stories from both the main and side quests, an addictive original mini-game called Gwent, the beautiful and sometime simple breathtaking Original Soundtracks that would make you want to just stand by a high hill or a mountain side and watch the world go by with the ever-changing weather. Unfortunately, some of the soundtracks are only available ingame if you've pre-ordered the game but I assure you, you will not be disappointed if you buy the game after its release.  Some glitches, bugs and exploits have already been found and I must admit, even though some of the bugs and glitches might be eye-catching, the defect parts are as much worth of a pile of fiend dung compared to the upside of the game!  Last but not least CD Red Projekt releases frequently small but worthy DLC contents in form as new quests, new cards and alternative looks for some of the main characters which helps to keep the world from dying of the White Frost!  Alas, me review ends here and me final rate for tis game would be: 10/10!

As a big fan of the Witcher 2 (and the first game to a much lesser extent) I was really looking forward to this one. Turned out to be a super enjoyable game. This game features a huge open world and offers a ton of content, but I never found lost like I have been in some other open world titles. The map and quest system works great and there was always direction. I found was always driven to see the next part of the story.   The story was very engrossing and interesting. Very well developed and voiced characters and I loved where they went with the plot. I'm looking forward to the DLC. I don't think it's a game where you need to have played the one prior to it, but I would definitely recommend playing the Witcher 2 if you have the time. Overall I was lost in the Witcher world agan in this one. Great experience and a well polished game.  The gameplay is fantastic, constantly kept fresh with new mechanics, abilities and plot twists. Classic Witcher abilities and ingenuity. And the graphics are definitely 'next-gen.' Very beautiful game.  I recommend this game to anyone looking for an RPG and a great story. Took me ~35-40 hours to finish the main story, but I wasnt a completionist by any means. There's tons left to do, I just couldn't wait to see the next part of the story so other than some pretty relevant side-quests, I trucked along pretty quickly.   Game ran well with no problems. I run a i5-4460, 8 GB RAM, and a GTX 760 2GB and I was able to run the game very well at 1080p with medium to high settings and 45-50 fps.

Honestly, I did not think I would enjoy this type of game. Glad it went on sale, which led me to make the purchase. If you're looking for an adventure game (somewhat similiar to The Elder Scrolls or The Legend of Zelda), I definitely reccommend The Witcher 3.   The fights against the harder monsters take forever; people are not kidding when they say you need to actually PREPARE for these fights with potions, repair your weapons and armor beforehand, etcetera etcetera. I've died a couple times already against challenging bosses, and let me tell you, it is VERY rewarding when I actually thwart said opponent. And I'm only on the second easiest difficulty.  The only thing I dislike about it is the fact that in order to know what's going on in the story you need to at least have played a little bit into the first two (both of which I now own because of Steam sales). Oh and I can't forget, there are a few bugs here and there that annoy the hell out of me. When I first started playing, there were times the game froze while I was in an inventory screen, but that's dissappeared since I capped my framerate to 30. (I really hate capping my framerate, but oh well.)  I probably would have purchased this at full price had I known the game was this good. Although I did hear this is the last game in its set, unfortunately.  Overall amazing game.  8/10

I was waiting for a 75% discount, when all of a sudden my friend gifted me this game: 'Just play it. It's the best game ever.' Most of what can be said about this game has been said by other reviewers already, but to summarize: it looks great, there is  alot  of story, the characters are very well written, the gameplay (fighting) is pretty good... Not much negative to be said here.  One thing that I don't think has happened to me before is that I actually regretted some of the choices I made in this game. The choices you make actually have consequences, and sometimes things don't turn out the way you want them to.    For some reason I ended up with Triss when I was trying to end up with Yen...    I really loved the Ciri character, the main character Geralt's 'adoptive daughter', and after playing her side missions I wish they had made a DLC focusing on her as the main playable character.  I never got into The Witcher 1 as the game had a pretty slow start and the fighting felt really awkward, but now I might consider picking it up again (for the third time).  As for this game, I can't do anything else but recommend it, just like pretty much everyone else.

It's the greatest game ever created. Everything from the writing to the voice acting to the combat to the graphics is superb. I've just finished all DLCs on my second playthrough in the NG+, and after I uncover every single other thing there is to see and do, I'm going to do it all over again.  The devs have already said that for now this is the end of The Witcher, and that really is a shame. Personally, I don't think it has run its course even though I've got nearly 250 hours into the game; I really hope the devs decide to make more DLCs instead of making The Witcher 4. This game could go on for years and years just by releasing DLC like this, even one a year. There are at least three different endings for each version of the game and DLC, and every single action you take will affect those endings, no matter how small or insignificant it may be. Dialogue choices - even those seemingly harmless - can have a massive impact on the story. I recommend you manually save often because it can get really confusing. There are so many possibilities that I had to actually go to a spoiler site to keep track of them all and get the ending I wanted from the vanilla version in order to get the ending I wanted from the other DLCs. It's truly a domino effect and can get really unwieldy at times, but the good news is that it's so massive that it's pretty much got infinite replay value. There is just_so_much_story here that every time you play through it you love it even more. It's like the first Star Wars trilogy for Star Wars fans: it's something that just never gets old.  However, it's not without its faults, although they're mainly just tiny gripes. Maneuvering on Roach can be a pain sometimes because she gets stuck on trees and rocks occasionally, but it's not a big deal. Also, it's so incredibly non-linear that it can get unwieldy at times, almost making you feel like you've missed something in your quest for that next mission or next contract. I know that sounds like a first world problem - and to be fair, it is - but there is really nothing truly negative I can say about this game. In my opinion, it is literally the greatest game ever created, and with each DLC lasting at least 20 hours a piece, there's so much to do that it starts to feel like an MMO, only not crappy and repetitive. In fact, when the MMO genre came out, I'm sure this is the type of game they were going for yet never lived up to. CD Projekt Red has managed to create the perfect game, and although I'm very excited to hear about Cyberpunk 2077 being their latest project, I'm at the same time saddened to think that The Witcher will take a back seat to it.   A word of advice: go ahead and play through the first and second Witcher games. You can load your save from TW1 into TW2 and from TW2 into TW3, and all your big decisions from the previous games are brought forward into TW3. Of course, you don't have to play them at all to enjoy the game, but that continuity really adds to the lore and it makes you feel a part of the story. There's also a bit of nostalgia there.  Now excuse me while I embark on a third replay. I'd say it'll take another 150 hours or so.  Final Verdict: 100/10

Epic game all in all, had a great time playing it from start to finish; both the core story and the secondary missions.   PROS: ------ THE STORY is compelling for those that want a story in a videogame capable of matching and surpassing those on the big screen, and detailed/extensive enough for the type of person who likes to really get into every detail of the lore. Even the side missions have great writing and attention to detail.  GOOD BANG FOR YOUR BUCK. I ended up spending almost 100 hours by the time I finished the story. This was with me wandering around a lot for fun, doing many of the side missions, and using the brothels.   THE GRAPHICS are as far as I can see some of the best to date. From the smaller perceptible facial details you can notice to the epic, varied scenery there is an abundance of eye candy.   THE POLISH of the product by the Polish (at least the build that I played) was very good at least on my machine. For such a large scale open world game release that can't be easy. I encountered few bugs, or anything that disrupted my immersion. Only once was there an odd glitch where all my session's save games went into a balck hole.   CONS -------  THE ENDGAME was lacking in things to do. Once you finish the story, it puts you back at a timeline point in the game that for all intents and purposes is before all of the main missions have been completed. This combined with the fact there is no incentive to carry out the other unfinished missions breaks immersion somewhat. With such a large world I am sure I did less than half of what there is to do. This is partly because I leveled so fast so most of my secondary missions and undiscovered locations became obselete. It would have been nice to be placed in the correct point of the timeline afterwards, and given the ability to effectively continue to level up while finishing some harder challenges. In typical style, CD Projekt Red have outdone themselves.  I've been a fan of the series for years now, and have played each of the three installments, and there are some common themes amongst all of them:  - There is a fantastic element of choice in how your story progresses, with each choice having often far-reaching and unforeseeable consequences in the world. This mechanic is a staple of the series, and is done so well at least partly because there is never a right or wrong choice to make. There is no black or white, everything is a shade of grey.  - You're given the tools of swordplay, magic and potions and allowed to use them as you see fit. Additionally, each species of monster you hunt has its own strengths and weaknesses which you must learn to use against them.  - The character development forces you to become heavily invested in the game, and makes each of the previously mentioned choices matter all the more for it. You will find yourself genuinely caring about the consequences you caused, even if they were the lesser evil at the time.  - All of the games in the series have a wide variety of side quests to undertake throughout, adding hours of gameplay.  However, whilst The Witcher 3 shares this theme with its predecessors, it somehow manages to set itself apart by a wide margin. Combat mechanics are as crisp and responsive as they have ever been, allowing for you to truly become a master swordsman; the side quests are so much more detailed than they were before, requiring you to use investigation skills before tracking and killing the monster you're after; the visuals are the best this series has ever seen.  On these bases alone, I would absolutely recommend the game to anybody, and label it a must buy for any self-respecting PC gamer. However, I think it's only fair that a warning is also given to any prospective buyer... Many players (myself included) have experienced a high number of crashes. CDPR are working to fix this (at the date of writing two patches have been released already) but this may be a problem which blemishes the otherwise outstanding gameplay for you.

Everyone has their own preferences and things that make an RPG enjoyable for them.  I enjoy exploring interesting lands, and feeling like I am helping people or at least making my mark in the world. I think the questing is great, and I am really appreciating all the little things the game has.   Such as the realistic way the Witcher moves through different depths of water. I like the transition from dry land to water. I can see the bottom of the lake as it drops off into deeper areas. I can skim over shallow water in the boat and see weed beds gliding past just inches from the bottom of the boat. I like how the surface of the water is effected by the weather.  Last night I noticed how as I rode my horse slowly out of rolling plains and into a shadowy forest...the sounds changed with the location. It went from the sound of blowing wind in the high grass to song birds and crickets, etc.  Another time as I was making my way on horse back to a quest location, and a storm blew in. The sky turned dark and rain began to fall, thunder rolled and the sound of the rain hitting around me was very realistic. After a bit I saw a village coming into view. The warm glow of light spilling out of the windows of the homes. I was fortunate it had an inn. So, as I would do in real life in that situation I dismounted and went in.   That is what makes an RPG for me. This game is loaded with the kind of things that make an immersive experience. I just like being in the game.

Two things up front:  1. If someone complains about 'the downgrade', they're a moron. Anyone who sees a pre-rendered cutscene two years before a game is released, and expects that to accurately represent what the final game will look like is a total idiot. Period.  2. This is the best RGP I have ever played.   There's too many amazing details about this game to fully describe here, so here's an essential pro/con list.  Pros:  1. The most satisfying RPG game mechanics I've ever experienced. This is a true role playing game. You play a well known character with well established abilities, rather than an unknown blank slate. This may make it seem as though you have less choice in progression, and while that's true in a way, it makes all the abilities you do have so much more meaningful and satisfying.  2. Every single quest, from the biggest primary quest, to the smallest side quest, has multiple ways to find and complete, and your decisions make a difference. Bad choices may come back to bite you, while others could prove helpful in some other future quest you haven't even found yet. Your actions truly have an impact on the world around you.  3. Combat is of the simple to learn, hard to master variety. Think of Arkhams free flow combat, but with even more depth, and no hand holding such as indicators for when you're about to be hit. Different enemies will have different weaknesses to take advantage of, and it behooves you to learn them and use those signs and poisons which will aid most in your fight. It is extremely satisfying to take down an enemy several levels above you with patience and skill.  4. Many areas and enemies will chew you up and spit you out until you're high enough level. Makes things much more interesting, and much more rewarding when you can defeat a boss that is very tough, and get that sweet sweet loot.  5. The game is absolutely gorgeous. I never pass up staring at a sunset.  Cons:  1. Literally the only con I can come up with is that sometimes there will be some jarring pop in of objects. Doesn't always happen, so it may be something that will be addressed in a future update. Either way, it's far from game breaking.  In conclusion, this is the best RPG I've ever played. Period. Nothing out there compares. It is, in my humble opinion, the new king of open world RPG's.

I love this game. In my opinion, definitely worth a buy. So far I feel like a genuine witcher, travelling the world and having an impact on the lives of those who hire me. Every quest had a cutscene and dialogue perfectly voice acted. When I go and search a 'crime scene' often I get to inspect what happened and get to draw my own conclusions and make a decision based on not only what Geralt thinks but what I think.   An example: looking for a dead woman, talk to some kids who say they saw a woman leading her into forest. Search forest. Womans sister comes to tell me for the good of her husband to leave to end his pain. I remember what the kids said and am interested about the woman leading her into the forest so I refuse and continue searching, I don't want to spoil anything so all I can say is it was worth the extra search.   I feel as if my decisions in this game are important, every bit of dialogue and every decision. Also I find the dialogue extremely interesting. I rarely skip conversations and when I do it is because I already read the subtitles.  I keep seeing negative reviews due to controls and combat. I enjoy a challenge and play on hard because the combat is difficult but rewarding. I play on a controller and keyboard and mouse depending on how I'm feeling. I can tell that I am getting better at combat and now am rarely dying. If this game were an alcohol it would be a fine whisky. This isn't something you toss back to have a bit of fun. Instead it's something you savour and enjoy.   I would like to write more on the game, however I'm too lazy. All I have to say Is you will either love it or hate it. I has somethings it could improve so I give it a 9/10. So far I have had fun every minute of it.

WARNING: This game is very demanding; make sure to read the spec requirements before you attempt to buy.  I'm not going to give it a full review, but here are the pros and cons mentioned briefly: Visually, the game is absolutely phenomenon. Gameplay was a huge leap from Assassins of Kings; completely overhauled - giving you more liberties than ever in the series. The buttons and keys are adjusted more ergonomically than in previous games; no longer will you have to choose between movement and parrying for example. However, there is still some clunkiness to combat that renders the use of the brought-back alt+movement_key animation useless; forcing you to hit space and dodge instead - as awkward looking as the previous installment. I'm not sure if it's proper to complain about the healing system and alchemy, but it's made a lot simpler and a lot easier, so ♥♥♥ for tat if you hate and love drinking your potions in-battle. Oh yes, riding... and swimming... this literally revolutionizes the series in many ways. It immensely adds some immersion to the open-world atmosphere. I'm probably 5% into the game and I'm loving it. Gameplay cons aside, the only real downer (no pun intended; drowner... get it? nvm :P) is the fact that this game is pretty damn demanding! I'm having a hard-time running it on my GTX 765m (laptop; because I'm a moron). Nonetheless, that doesn't affect the score I'd be giving it.  This game deserves a 5/5, though if I was angry joe, I would reconsider giving it a badass seal of approval.

So far this is the best RPG game I’ve played. Recommended to everyone especially Skyrim fans.  -GAMEPLAY  I didn’t like the fights at first so much but as I advanced they became more interesting and challenging. I played a combo of signs and strength. I was too lazy to learn the alchemy or crafting so I just relied on what I bought for armor and signs for fight.  -STORY  I should admit that the game didn’t get to me when I first started. Played it for 3h, left it for 6 months and then decided to give it a second chance. When I went back to it again I became obsessed with it and didn’t play any other games till I finished the main story. Maybe it was because I hadn’t played the prequels and the story was confusing at the beginning but when I played it for more time, I loved it even not knowing the story of other Witcher games.  The effect of choices you make are on of a kind and even better than Skyrim. Because of this there is a lot of replayability. For example Ciri has 3 different fates and Geralt has 3 different relationship endings and so there are at least 9 different main endings resulted by the choices you make.  The side quests are quite fun but as the main characters are appealing and the story is great, I’d rather play the game for 2 or 3 times instead of just completing one. Well this could be different for another game.  -PERFORMANCE  I have an i5-4440 3.1GHz, a GTX 960 and 8 gigs of DDR3 RAM. My monitor though only supports 900p so at this resolution with everything at ultra I get about 45 FPS. I set the max FPS to 30 so I could get a constant FPS with rare drops to 28 (usually when it starts raining ore there are more than one people with fancy hair on the screen). Overall I can say it’s a decent port and a smooth game.  -GRAPHICS  The graphics are just awesome. The sceneries, Nvidia gameworks etc. make the game so beautiful and luring even at 900p.  -BUGS & ISSUES This game, like any other vast open world game, suffers from minor bugs. The most unpleasant one is the clothes changing to their original when you use “Alternative looks” DLCs during some cutscenes but the whole game is so playable and clean.  -CONCLUSION  Just one word… a Masterpiece   Truly the GOTY for me and looking forward to preordering the next game from CDPR.

SIDE QUEST. This is a side quest. It has branching options.   Also best game within a game about real characters in that game. Game-ception.  10/10

I was given this game as a gift about 6 months before it came out but never actually got around to playing it untill a few months ago. I must say I am very impressed with this game. I had not played the previous Witcher games but I felt like I was quickly able to become attached to the characters and figure out the combat system. This game has amazing characters, locations, combat, and plot but the real kicker for me are the side quests. Few modern RPGs do side quests justice and it really is the icing on the cake for this game. I would suggest everyone to try out this game even if they usually don't like RPGs.

I want to give the game a 10/10 because it is so much better than other games out there with 9/10 or 8/10 rating, but there are certain issues that just are there and shouldn't be ignored.  praise first: - Gerald really feels like a witcher, the contracts are just great - actually I can't say a single sidequest was too boring - you can explore, the world looks great and is alive - the game is challenging  My two complains: - the controls: ok its better than just doging around like in Witcher 2, but its clearly designed for consoles and that leads to clunky mouse & keyboard controls - certain story elements and characters: I don't want to spoile anything, but often Geralds choice of words and the reaction of others do not account for previous developments. Yeah it's 'open worldish' but if say someone important dies you would like to have other people talk about that. During the course of the game certain characters may side with you but they don't really do anything past their respective side quest.  In addition, I imported a save game from Witcher 2. I wasn't really too shure about my decisions there. The fact there was no single moment of Witcher 3 where someone responded to those devlopments sucks. Im pretty sure I sided with Iorvith. I never saw him in the game. Roche did not respond to my decision. The fact that I went for Triss in the final chapter? Apperently Gerald and Triss broke up after wards, don't now why. Maybe I should read the books.  The first one might be fixed a little bit, I have no hopes for the second one. So my personal verdict is 9/10

Every award well earned! This masterpiece of a game is hands-down the best I have ever played. Period.  Yes, the graphics are gorgeous (the volumetric light as it glimmers between brances, the sense of scale in the mountains, the most gorgeous sunsets/sunrises I have ever seen), the combat is tight and fairly challenging, and the loading is next to non-existant. Even so, this is not why this game is worth your time.  The story-telling is.  Never have I experienced a game universe that felt so ... real. I quickly grew to care for the characters - becoming deeply fond of some, intensely loathing others. This is first and foremost a story-driven game, and the story is its' strongest suit. The main game has an epic storyline, the scale of which you'd expect from a fantasy movie. It aims high and strikes true, the game delivers THE dramaturgically best build-up and tension I have seen in a game.  The DLCs are great, the ten (10) free (!) DLCs are - as to be expected - not the biggest in size, but more than makes up for that in quantity. And the paid DLC... Wow. Even tighter story-telling than the main game, with the most interesting and eerie antagonist I've seen in a while...  If you haven't already bought this game, now's the time. Or wait until the next sale. Either way, it's a no-brainer; play this!

if you are willing to spend 60$ on ♥♥♥♥ like call of duty, or dragon age, and then look at reviews before buying this game, you are doing it wrong. all nonsense aside, CDPR has done an amazing job delivereing such a beautiful game. i havent cried in years, and once you play this game, get back to me, and tell me why crying was perfectly reasonable in a few places.

I feel like I robbed a bank and got away with it because this game provides more amazing gameplay than many games I own combined. The value in this GOTY edition is great. I only have 15 hours in the game so far, but I feel pretty confident in going ahead and saying...this is the best game I've ever played, and I'd have to assume one of the best games EVER made...hands down. I can only assume I could get 1000 hours of play out of this game if I wanted to. I think one would be justified in buying a new PC just to play this one game. This is what Bethesda wishes it could achieve with their games. Despite them being separated by years for their respective releases, just for comparision's sake, this game makes Skyrim look like a joke.  Many reviews have already detailed the amazing things about this game long before I ever bought it, so I'll be brief:  PROS: -Story, story, story -Tons of mission, every one feels real and important -Choice in every mission and the choices feel real -Map design, without a doubt the best there has ever been, rolling hills, roads carving out ditches and embankments, trees placed in realistic clumps -Obviously graphics...worth upgrading your card for if you're near that point -Immersion -Voice acting, strikes a great balance between getting to the point and being immersive with conversation -Horse -Boat -Combat, I didn't like combat in the W1 and W2 but for some reason I like it with W3 -Forests, I mean, come on, the trees and the wind and the moon = eyegasm -Loot everywhere -Crafting is easy to get into -Alchemy  There are so many pro's to this game, I am sure I forgot several.  CONS: -If I were being really, really, really picky, I'd say the character movement sometimes gets annoying when trying to 'line up' to loot a container -Sometimes, rustic buildings get a little repetative to loot as they tend to be laid out in a similar fashion  FINAL: For $40 bucks, the GOTY edition should be an essential item in anyone's game library with a GPU that can run it at decent settings. The game is still well worth it if you can only run it on low settings.
I am a big fan of the Elder Scrolls series, but I gotta say that the love to detail in the Witcher III, the looks, the lore, the feel are unparalled.
I've never felt so invested in a game and characters in all my life until I played this game whenever I play every 2 hours almost feels like 15 minutes haha.  10/10

8/10  A huge game with tons of detail and amaizing content yet lacks in a few things and has A TON of problems.  Problems ive had: Signs scale up much slower than lvling either combat or potion.  Not having the option to jump in combat can get you stuck in certain places like falling from a small bridge protecting you from poison making you to kill the enemies from a distant in order to jump back up on the bridge.  Fps droping from long playthroughs (If you are having this problem a quick short solution would be to pouse the game and alt tab out and back in to it. Also if you are using nvidia, go to your global setings and manually add the game).  Movement outside of combat feels verry clunky combined with an awkward camarra position that makes it hard to loot and examine objects at times. Also disliked how there are places where you cant sprint... While it is understandable that someone would find it disrespectful if you run around there house, an abandoned almost destroyed house or a sewer i dont think should have this restriction.  Witcher gear is verry easy to find and it is way better than normal gear making you just sell everything else, most of the time its not even needed to dismantle since most dont give you any rare hard to find crafting matterials and they are all verry easy to make even the bear school. Now this is different when talking about the dlcs. If you wish to upgrade all the witcher gears to grandmaster it takes a rediculous amount of money even by crafting the resources. Combine this amount of money with the money you need for the glyph crafter and the house and its almost impossible. This gives more reasons as to why you should sell anything that isnt witcher gear.  Enemy difficulty. soo many monsters contracts are actually verry easy, some of em you can even stun lock em without having any stun or stagger on your equipment... And then there are some monster contract or bosses that just get rediculouse out of nowhere instead of implementing enemies that make you slowly think outside the boss and force you to slowly try new things to implement them against those bosses. and example of a really hard boss compared to soo many others are Djinn, and Von Everecs Nighmare.  Inventory needs more filters ESPECIALLY for diagrams. I would just love to not see any crap that isnt witcher gear. Also the way they are named... witcher swords have for example 'griffin steal sword - enhanced' which makes the diagrams much more organiced unlike armor which are named as : Enhanced witcher gear', This makes it so swords have the order for all the upgrades unlike armor which are piled up with all the enhanced ones.  No buying back option for the same money you accidentally sold the item for. since skipping a cutscene is the same button as selling an item i have accidentally sold a few things i didnt want to sell making me load back my previous save files a few times. Also idk if its just my game but a few times i have clicked an item to sell and even tho i click it multiple times to make sure im highliting the correct weapon i wanna sell, sometimes it ends up selling another item.  Game cutscenes not having the option to either pouse them or being able to load a save file, this makes it so that if you end up pressing a conversation by accident, you need to either press the sht out of your space button to skip everything to the end and close your eyes so you dont spoil anything or close the game entirely.  When sprinting with Roach he sometimes stops out of nowhere, this happends mostly when crossing bridges.  Volume problems especially when switching to cutscenes.  Djinns lvl scaling. For some reason if you are higher lvl than what djinn is supost to be and you have lvl scaling option on than he will 1 shot you with any of his attacks.  Npcs you need to follow sometimes not walking.  Witcher senses sometimes not showing footsteps unless im standing on top of them or if i pass em by and im looking behind me.  And finally when the game loads into a combat. For some reason when the game loads even tho its done loading it is still loading something while the game has started making so you dont have full control over geralt and sometimes not even being able to pouse the game and let it finish loading. This is a huge problem for the fist fights especially becouse the npc can still hit you while your character cant punch or roll for some reason.  Glitches: Invisible walls while in combat making it so you cant move to that location even tho there isnt anything on the floor. Roach getting stuck on a tree making it so that both he cant move and if you get on top of him than none of your buttons work other than loading a save file. Enemies that can jump sometimes jumping on to a invisible platform that for some reason makes em walk on air while not being able to hit me. The mission for lifting a cursed warewolf. If you kill the guys they still drop the neckless needed to lift the curse but for some reason it cannot be lifted unless you let em live... I guess the item isnt supost to drop in the first place.   Main annoying thing... Spiders. Almost impossible to dodge there webs sometimes even stun locking you.  Thing that I would love, An optiont to remove the hedious, horrendous, vomitting green smoke on the screen from taking too much potions. This both lowers my frame rate and makes the game look like garbage.  Roach appearing more closer than he is especially if he appears at my left instead than appearing far away behind me. The game not ♥♥♥♥ing auto equiping the torche in my inventory when I don’t even have it equiped on the tab inventory. When the torche is equiped it doesn’t let me use strong attacks, making it a real annoyance when you are using a strong attack build. Not having soo many secondary missions in which you just do the same thing over and over again. Remove the option for the potion clearance to not give you back the mutagens you used to unlock the abilities. It just makes the game tedious to go farm more mutagens just to test different builds, Im already paying 1k for the potion. An option for witcher senses to turn on by toggle instead of holding. Game needs a cap on dmg reduction that isnt either burn, bleed, poison. Geralt turns into a god when you reach 100% dmg reduction its crazy. An option to skp every cutscene by just holding the god damn button. I feel like ima break my space button playing NG+ skipping the things i already know.  Final thought. The delusion perk. a verry good perk for dialogues yet theres alot of dialogues where you are just left to question as to why it didnt have the option to use it? If Geralt can get out of a few combats by using it than why cant he use it for every situation where a group just wants to fight against you? why cant you use it to calm the jarl? seems verry weird. And the game being a bit shy to show beheadings and some gore at times. It kinda feels like the gore has been censored, in a game that one of the first conversations you might get is with a guy explaining gwent to you and you end up talking about how there should be a novel not afraid showing the horrors a war and yet the game itself is afraid to show it completely.  P.S Learn Gwent, it is the best card game ever.

Ive played games for about 24 years and played just about all kinds of games but never played a role-playing game.  The witcher 3 looks so good i thought id give it a go.  And im glad that i did as this as got to be the best game ive ever played.  If your after adventure story massive open world with lots to do i would buy

The beginning I was only interested in the graphics after getting a GTX 970, and oh boy were those graphics amazing (except a couple of minor textures here and there which look pretty console-skyrim-tier, but they're not a bother for me at all.)  But after getting a good 5 hours into the game, I became really invested in the story and gearing myself, soon as I learned crafting I started to have a lot of fun, the game has a lot of nice armor and weapons as well as a kick-♥♥♥ story and full voice acting, even for the main character.  The overall map is huge and has plenty of space to roam and explore with beautiful terrain and scenery. The characters are mostly well thought out and interesting, and the combat system even on the easiest difficulty can prove difficult if you don't learn to time attacks, use runes, and dodge/alternate the power of your attacks. Though this is fairly easy to learn and quite fun to play with after a couple hours of play. I will warn you though, anything above the lowest difficulty setting will be quite difficult to beginners unless you've already played Witcher 1 / Witcher 2 and/or are hugely familiar with battle strategies in 3D RPG games.  As the time of writing this review I have played the game for around 16 hours, and have only encountered maybe 2 very minor bugs and 1 fairly large bug, but this large bug was very entertaining and made me laugh for a good bit, I fixed it just by saving then restarting the game, so it was more fun to have happen than to have not.  TL;DR: ♥♥♥♥ Fallout 4, get this, way more worth it and $10 cheaper.

I'm fifty hours in, and I THINK I've started the game?  What I am saying, is that Witcher 3 is one of the longest ga- WAIT I know what your thinking. This isn't a single player mmo like dragon age (no hate, amazing game) but this is a completely full thought rich game, where surely every acre of land was looked over many times by the developers, and they thought 'what meaningful quest, secret, or chest that has a book that, if you read it you find out about a murder that begins a quest tha- ANYWAYS'.  There is a LOT to do in the Witcher, and 15 hours in not one thing has been repetitive. I was originally scared to buy Witcher since 'graphics downgrade'. They released a hogwash trailer that was and still is not the quality of the game. They recieved too much flak, as the game looks a m a z i n g. It runs 55-70fps on an (overclocked) GTX 970 All ultra, 1440p w/ no AA or motion blur. Consoles hurt the game, but in the end it was the developers who chose to limit the graphics. Great graphics (like, god tier. Crysis tier), but not CGI tier. There are no insane effect w/ fire, smoke, or really any of the magic spells Geralt has. Not a big deal to me, but... yea.  So that's over, if that alone is enough to make you not play Witcher 3 I get it, but consider it. This surely will be known as one of the best games to date, ever. Let's go to the REAL cons, since there are some.  Cons: The combat for KB/M is m i l e s ahead of W2s controls, and overall is a pleasant experience. It 'almost' had a Dark Souls 2 feel, the flow of combat. The signs are well done (besides Aard, below), but sometimes the controls feel sluggy and especially when you fall into a CC you can't break out of (that I know of).  It's not dark souls. Fair con, right? The combat is great, but feels... dullish ~ once you master it. Still great and skill based with lots of timing. <-- I played on Death March and died frequently, the game is hard on the hardest difficulty. Very hard.  At 55 hours, I can say Aard when upgraded (the push ability) is overpowered. Cool? No, not cool. I had to respec to make sure I don't want to use it :( It is basically a 1 hit kill. Sort of, if you know how to 'exploit' it, though it's not a bug but a design.  Pros for straight males:  15 hours in, saw 6 ♥♥♥♥♥♥s, 2 asses. I demand more ♥♥♥. Now.  50 hours in, saw 42 ♥♥♥♥♥♥s, 11 asses. I am satisfied. :boomer:  Nvidia hairworks is BS and should have never been added as it cripples performance from AMD cards. BAD! I have a 970, and my FPS goes from 52-34 with it on, amd ~ 20. And for what? Tomb Raider tier hair? Who cares. -Edit the fps is much better now on both AMD and NVIDIA but still for me, I reaaally don't care to lose 10fps for curly animated hair that feels fakeish w/ it's motion..  TL;DR The game is amazing overall, with some small forgiveable hiccups. This will be known as one of if not the best RPG ever made. Long game, without grinding or dull 'go here and fetch me this' quest.
