A Masterpiece in every sense of the word. Do not pass this one up, it will go down in history as one of the best RPGs ever created.

-- Played On --  Windows 8.1, i5-4460 @ 3.20 GHz, 8 GB RAM, Nvidia 680 graphics, Ssd drive, Xbox 360 controller.  -- Graphics --   There is a lot of settings for your graphics so you can find a good graphic with a stable frame rate for your PC. I don't have the most powerful PC but still got good graphic and stable FPS with tweaking the graphics to my liking. Went down from 1080p to 900p just to get a stable FPS on 60 and that is worth a lot more than 1080p and unstable FPS. With 60 FPS fighting feels fluid and more 'responsive'.  -- Sound --  The effect sounds and music are perfect. The voice acting are also top notch.  -- Controls --  They are also very good when you get into them. Of course there is a lot of buttons you have to learn. Different button layout on exploration, combat, swimming, horse riding and sailing. But the button layout always show on screen when you are in the different activity so that make the job a lot easier.  -- Combat --  You feel like a powerful Witcher but at the same time you feel like you have to work for it. Combining spells, swords, blocks and dodging are very fun. It can be very challenging with many enemies on a high difficulty setting. Whenever I lost in combat it felt like my mistake and not the game system letting me down. The only negative with the fighting was that the enemy had their specific fighting area and if you walked outside that area the enemy didn't followed you. So it was easy to manipulate the system when fighting powerful enemies.   -- Story --  For me I enjoyed the main story and it kept me interested through the entire game. But even with a good main story the side quest wasn't boring distractions. They almost felt like main story quest and while you were on a side quest you forgot all about the main quest until you finished your side quest.  -- Choices --  I love the choices in this game. There isn't a correct choice, just different choices with different outcomes. The consequences of your actions doesn't appear right away so can't save right before and test every outcome easily. That means when you are about to make a choice you consider every options a lot, but sometimes in action you don't get unlimited time to choose so then you have to take a hasty decision and live with your consequences.   -- Sex and Romance --  This game actually admits that sexual drive exist between humans and don't treat sex like you live in Duckburg as Mickey Mouse. It's not like Bethesda games where you chop off heads, blow out brains and comes home to your girl to have sex and the screen turns black. I love Bethesda games but that is breaking game immersion when sex is such a big part in peoples lives.  Even the romance and sex are very good created. You will feel strong connections to your girls and appreciate when Geralt get some sex. Geralt is one horny dog but the girls love to tease him.  In the romance part it's also big choices and consequences. It's created tastefully and realistic.

This game is absolutely brilliant! Best single-player RPG game I've ever played 10/10  Without the expansion packs I've easily put 100 hours of gameplay into this game. The story is amazing, and if you've played the previous Witcher titles you're in for a treat.  PROS + Main plot is breathtaking As I've said, if you played the previous titles you're in for a treat =] Even if you didn't play the previous games, you can definitely relate to the characters and enjoy the story  + Your choices matter The choices you make in the main or side quests deeply affect the plot and the world around you. I didn't play through the game multiple times, but I get the feeling the story is not linear at all.  + Side quests are interesting Each side-quest is unique and it's story is well-rounded and interesting. This is the first game that I can actually say 'I want to do the side-quests for the story', instead of just for grinding for better gear / XP / ...  + Open world exploration is optional yet rewarding I'm not a fan of open-world exploration, I usually like to stick to the story and not wander around too much... yet in this game on route to different quests I found myself taking detours to explore. The world they built is beautiful, filled with monsters and challenges, and the rewards for exploring the map are immense. Yet you can definitely choose not to explore and still manage just fine.  + Combat is challenging A lot of different challenging monsters, each with their own weaknesses/strenghts/patterns. Each battle I fought was challenging, and I has to consult the bestiary (encyclopedia of monsters) often.  + Skills & mutagens offer various and rewarding play-styles I personally chose the Alchemy tree and wasn't dissappointed. After a certain point the bonuses I got from that tree made me really powerful on the right conditions. Each monster required different oils and/or potions to fight, and when I used the right ones they had a really big impact on the battles I fought.  CONS - On higher levels you are overpowered At around lvl 22+ I found myself having no difficulty defeating monsters 2-3 lvls above me. Maybe my build worked really well for me... but still, at a certain point the games ceases to be challenging and begs you to finish it already.  - Final battle is easy if your lvl is too high I reached the final battle at lvl 31 and it was a piece of cake, despite me playing on the one before the hardest difficulty. This was a bit of a letdown, especially because the build-up for the finale really had me gritting my teeth and saying 'I want to nail that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'... and then I did, and he was just so weak...  - Monsters are a bit predictable There are a lot of different monsters, yet once you learn how to battle each one they become easy to defeat (assuming your lvls are not too far appart and you use the right potions/oils/signs).  - The brawling / racing / gwent(cards) mini-games are not that rewarding or interesting Gwent is a big improvement over the previous gambling game (dice) but it's not that rewarding. Brawling and racing are just boring and not worth it.

I remember playing the first two Witcher games. The first one had a really engaging atmosphere, but the gameplay was fairly complex and not easily approachable without a lot of time set aside. Regardless, I still enjoyed it, but I don't think I ever finished it. The second game was much more approachable to a wider audience, but still retained the same depth and atmosphere. In a nutshell, the third game retains the level of polish and detail of the previous titles, (allbeit with a few bugs that every open-world games have) but in an open world larger than Skyrim. That, in and of itself is an incredible feat, but this game is truly an experience, not just some game you can waste time in. Geralt is a relatively unemotional character due to his mutations, and is morally gray for the most part. This works in the game's favor as long as you don't mind Geralt's gravely, sexy voice. You can choose to be distant, and stay out of others affairs, leaving them to fend for themselves, or you can go out of your way to sabotage them to benefit yourself (usually by means of money), or you can go out of your way to be kind and helpful, and be rewarded with meaningful relationships with characters that you struggle to accept as being merely fictitious.  This of course, is without even mentioning the gameplay. The keyboard and mouse controls are usable, but this game is probably better used with a controller. The combat is intuitive, challenging (just be sure to turn the difficulty up), and satisfying. The simplest way to describe it is a mix between Assassin's Creed and Dark Souls. Dodging is essential, but you can still parry and use Geralt's unique set of spells (called signs in game) to enhance your battling.  The Witcher 3 is amazing, no doubt about it. I'm on my second playthrough now, and even after doing the same quests again the game feels fresh and exiting. Add CDProjekt Red's free DLC and upcoming expansion pack and they've earned my love. And yours. Please experience this for yourselves.

I'll keep it simple and short:  The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is one of the best games ever made. Compared to any game released in the last few years, it stands as a titan among them. Amazing graphics, world , story, and gameplay. If you call yourself a gamer, buy this game now and play it.  10/10 - A masterpiece

9.5/10.  DISCLAIMER: I have not played any other witcher game, nor have read any of the books before playing The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.  The witcher 3 is a story about Geralt of Rivia, a witcher. Witchers are mutated humans that hunt monsters for payment. they carry two swords. a steel sword for humans/non-humans. and a silver sword for monsters. they also wield magic at their disposal, are alchemists and can get sober at will! The game follows up through the story of the witcher 2 I believe, and might be confusing at first if you haven't played the prequels.  STORY: - Introduction - The intro/tutorial of this game starts off fairly alright, the tutorial feels rushed quickly which is not neccesarily bad, it has more 2 sides of the coin on it. on one side a quick tutorial is nice as it makes it so you can start the game as soon as possible. on the other hand it causes a bit of initial confusion on how to play the game properly. although admittedly, figuring stuff out by yourself can be fun to an extend.  - story as a whole - This story features an incredibly extensive amount of dialogue, and the best part is that the vast majority of it is split into tons of different dialogue options, allowing the player to more or less make the main character say what they want him to say. My favorite part of the story is that there are moments in the story where your choices have a lot of influences on what happens thereafter. not a single moment goes by that I regret doing certain actions after I found out what their implications are, and also wondering what would have been if I had chosen a different option. To me however, the most incredible thing of this game is how the main story actually takes a very long time to complete. Most story driven games nowadays seem to settle around 8 to 10 hours of gameplay and that's it. but this game takes a genuine long time to complete, and with that feels as if it's trying to spit in the faces of game designers that haven't tried to make their games this long.  - Side quests -  This game features an insane amount of side quests. I'm sure about half my playtime has gone to side quests.  Some of them are short, other moderate, and some are fairly long. some side quests feature small story instances with sometimes dilemmas or different endings depending on your choices. there are also monster contracts which make you track a monster and kill it in exchange for gold. and lastly there are treasure hunts which feature niche area's that are hiding loot. overal the side quests are a very big part of the game, as it manages to fill countless hours  GAMEPLAY: - Combat - The combat is not exceptional, but it is really fun nonetheless. you have a variety of ways to engaging fights to your liking, using spells as you wish and slashing around with your blades in a way that feels a bit loose, but satisfying. and it's not one of those babysit-gameplay games either. if you do not utilize dodging and blocking accordingly, you will find yourself in a world of hurt. it follows the terms of game-flow really well. neither too hard nor too easy, but with challenges from time to time.  - Horseriding -  Your horse is the means of travel in this game. I was really surprised to see a game that actually succeeds in horse-travel, which I personally haven't experienced since Red Dead Redemption. your horse has stamina, which depletes when you gallop, although it recovers fairly quick. your horse also has a fear level, which is a mechanic that allows it to kick you off its saddle if it gets too scared by monsters, wildlife, bandits, etc. It feels somewhat realistic to have it, and it doesn't happen too often that you get thrown off your saddle, so it's not annoying.  - Crafting - Crafting is fairly well executed in this game. In order to craft something, you require a diagram, aka blueprints, which contain the recipe of how to craft an object. there are 2 things when it comes to crafting: Alchemy and Smithing. Alchemy: this means creating potions that give you small edges in combat. It actually took me a while to realize one feature that is really loveable about alchemy, which is the fact that once you create a potion, you won't need to create it again. instead it refills by using strong alcohol. this removes the annoyance that is gathering resources again and again, and simply allows you to enjoy what you have achieved permanently. Smithing: similar to alchemy, you gather components to create a piece of armor or weapony. you then go to a smith to have them craft gear for you. it's pretty much like any other crafting in games, so nothing exceptional to say here.  - Gwent - Gwent is a card mini-game inside the game itself. it's a best of 3 in which you try to outmatch your opponent in numbers, but you have to manage with your limited resources which makes it so you have to play it smart. if you spent all your cards at the first round you might be bound to lose. it has a lot of depth, too bad you are against AI. there's an official Gwent card game coming out soon though, as of the time I wrote this you can apply for a closed beta.  - Customization -  Your options at customizing your character is a list of perks and abilities that you can unlock by leveling up. every time you level up you gain a skill point which you can spend to unlock or upgrade abilities. these abilities eventually define your playstyle so it's important that you read them all first before you spent your points. I for example went mostly for magic perks, which in turn didn't give me a lot to invest in alchemy perks.  GRAPHICS: -Visuals- absolutely stunning graphics and that while I was playing at medium settings, I can only imagine how incredible the max settings can be.   -Design- The world is incredibly beautiful and nothing looks as if it has just been thrown in there to fill space, it's almost as if every nook and cranny in the game was thought out precicely. not to mention this is the only game to me whose forests actually feel like forests, and not a bunch of trees thrown around next to each other. the enemies and monsters are beautiful and very immersive, although at one point you start noticing with npc's that models are reused a lot.  BUGS/COMPLAINTS: first of all the bugs, holy ♥♥♥♥ there are a lot of bugs/glitches/faulty code that I've encountered in the game. I already mentioned how the combat was loose, that's because the game seems to have extremely accurate collisions, and small stone or tree will fully halt your movement, not to mention your horse's movement. AI at many times seems to get stuck or clipping. I've had many ocassions in which dialogue scenes are ruined by some random AI walking in the middle of the conversation. the AI itself seems to be glitchy at times, I've fought many enemies that just wouldn't attack me or walked away slowly because they became bugged. the funniest of them all was near the end when 6+ soliders got stuck on a tiny bridge and walked in circles clipping inside eachother. I also had the misfortune of getting outside the map boundaries once, making me walk mid air while also not being able to get out, forcing me to load a previous state. Fortunately these are mostly minor bugs which just break immersion, and the autosave system in the game makes it so anything that goes wrong does not ruin hours of gametime.  To summarize, this game is a masterpiece that ♥♥♥♥♥ on all the other story driven games and makes them look like utter garbage with their ~10 hour playtimes, it features enjoyable combat and a ton of very polished Rpg elements. the story is incredibly beautiful and intruiging as well as replayable due to its multi-choice dialogue and consecuences, and the graphics are very nice. Truly deserving of it's 'game of the year' award, even though that award is given a way a bit too loosely imo.  My general rule of thumb is that for every dollar/euro you pay for a game, 1 hour is spent playing that game, and this game goes far beyond that.

Well well, what can i say that has not already been said!   The Good: - The game is simply gorgeous. Never seen water look so real and nice, not even in real life! - There is no lag for such a gorgeous game (Tried with Nvidia GTX560 which is below minimum and it was fine with low settings) - Sound is fantastic. Weather effects and night and day cycle is just awesome. - This is an rpg following the witcher style, so i you didn't like witcher 1 and 2, then this game won't be fun for you. - They now have a mini card game named gwent i think. It's pretty good a la magic the gathering style and hearthstone. - The fights and move are much better than before due to gorgeous graphic engine. It feels more like real combat compared to the old witchers games. - Magic is diversified and not always helpfull - The world is biiiiiiiig and full of guarded loot. Luckily you got your horse to move faster around but it's still big. - Crafting armor and weapons is a lot of fun and very well made - Leveling is veeeeeeeeery slow. 15 hours in the game and i'm lvl 4. Take that wow!   The Bad: - This game is hard. Pant sheeeeting and peeing hard. You can encounter a lvl 10 monster in the first region just by exploring around. Sure it guards an insanely good treasure, but watch out! I spent a lot of time running away! - The fights are hard even at normal difficulty (and there are 2 other tougher levels for those masochists among you). Each monster needs to be fought a certain way and you have to experiment to find out which is best. No hack and slash forever in this game. You can use fast magic spells, bombs, crossbow, 2 types of swords, potions, oils, trophy to better your odds of winning. Lots of dodging and parrying are needed too. And there is a biiiig talent tree to specialize yourself in a lot of things. - Crafting potions (not oils) is bad. Problem is that you find a sheeetload of herbs everywhere, but the alcool you need to craft a potion is so rare or expensive that most of the time it ain't worth it. And crafting those alcool is more expensive than buying them. So you make very little potions in this game. And the potions last for just a few minutes so in a long fight (which most are) they expire waaaay before the fight is done. - Going with the crafting of potions, there is so very little coins to be had in this game. Maybe it gets better later (I saw that they actually nerfed the coins in loot in the latest patch! Da  fuuuu...ck?) . So you have to be very carefull what you buy at the trader.  That's it! Have fun

The Witcher 3 comes with many upgrades in all regards of what is important in a game: It is witty, great to play, has a gripping story and looks absolutely stunning. However, after two preceeding games of running all across cities, swamps and medieval suburbs full of religious fanatics, the one change that I was looking forward to most has four legs and is named after something that has six: Roach! Imagine having to travel all over Novigrad, Skellige and all the other lost parts of the world that Geralt has to deal with on foot. Luckily, we get our mighty steed and with that (almost) countless hours of brilliant gameplay.

I have put way too many hours into this game, and i still love it. It has a story line that keeps me interested and is memorable. There are a ton of side quests, and often you get to pick the type of person Geralt will be. Sometimes your choices have significant impact on the NPCs or whole villages. The combat system is simple enough to learn, but complex enough that it takes time to master. The world is rather large, and you can spend hours exploring it. I tend to watch all the cut scenes because they are fun, and some of the graphics are amazing. If you like open world RPG games, give this a try. Oh boy, was I in for a ride...  TL;DR The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an amazing game, that has been said countless times over, and it deserves every bit of praise it gets. I'm enjoying every minute of this game, and anyone who has a pc even remotely capable of running this gorgeous pearl in the gaming industry should give this game a shot. Even if you might be unfamiliar with it.  Now to get in to the gist of this review. I was extremely hyped for this game before it's launch, even if I didn't really know anything of the Witcher in general. I tried to play The Witcher 2 on my old laptop, but being as incapable as it was with running graphically intensive games, I stopped after a while. It was just not enjoyable. But even so, not knowing anything in the slightest, this game drew me in right from the start. Sure, you get lost and confused at the start, and I do recommend searching for some short YouTube videos explaining what happened in the previous games (as I did), or even better, if you have the patience; Play the previous games yourself. They seem to be worth your while. I simply couldn't wait playing this masterpiece, and therefore I jumped right in.  After familiarizing myself with the setting and the characters, I felt more attached to the story elements and background/lore of this amazing world. The countless books and villages seem to make the game feel more alive than anything I've ever played before. You really feel like a witcher, searching for contracts in towns, simply travelling the road and suddenly seeing something red pop up in the corner of your eye as you were using your witcher senses, therefore starting a new questline as you discover the mysterious claw marks on the tree besides the broken merchant cart. It simply has a never-ending universe of quests, contracts and exploration, carefully binding these three elements together and truly hitting the mark with all of them.  The atmosphere and story aside, the gameplay itself is nothing to sneeze at either. Playing the game on Death March truly gives you a sense of danger as you discover all kinds of enemies who you never fought before. Trying to dodge, roll, parry and flank yourself to victory feels very rewarding. Admittely, the game does sometimes restrict your movement a bit too much in certain areas, and you may very well find yourself getting stuck against a tree branch or a small fence, simply because the combat does not allow you to traverse all the objects in your path. This however does not retract form the awesomeness the combat ensues, and I do thoroughly feel the 'Dance like a butterfly, and sting like a bee'- mood.   The progression and skills feel balanced overall, although I do find some signs and bombs to be rather useless. Then again, it might just be my playstyle, and that's what I love about the Witcher 3; It let's you approach a situation, and you decide when, and with what, to engage.  As far as customization goes, I do feel the Witcher 3 might be a bit lacking sometimes. Before an angry mob shows up at my house, let me explain: Yes, it's true, there are tons of swords and pieces of armor that can be equipped with many different looks and styles. However, once I aquired my first 'Witcher Gear' it felt kind off pointless to try and search for better loot, apart from selling it. Don't get me wrong, I love the Witcher Gear, and the way the appearance changes as you upgrade it througout the game, but they just make the other armor and weapons feel a bit obsolete at times. This might just be intentional, for Geralt is a witcher, and perhaps he's supposed to wear gear designed solely for witchers.  All in all, this game is insanely good, and I can with utmost confidence tell you that it is worth every penny. Do give this game a shot, but beware: You do need a lot of time to truly experience this game. This is not a game to play once every few weeks. But boy, is it worth your time...

Compressed into a single sentence: Single best game I have ever enjoyed. This from someone whose gaming 'career' took flight with Pac-Man on the Atari 2600 in the early 80s. An incredible story with lots of twist and turns and 2 great extensions that, for me, added about the same playtime as the original game. My ingame time of ~240hrs is for a single playthrough of the game and its two extensions. Needless to say I enjoyed every one of those.  A word of warning though. This game might leave you feeling a tad empty once you finished it as there is nothing comparable. Other than that absolute recommendation, even for people who do not count RPGs to their favourite type of games. I am neither - although I bought Ultima 6 back in the day (cloth map and all), installed it, diddled around for 30 mins, uninstalled it, put the box back on the shelf where it has been sitting since collecting dust. TW3, however, the story, the characters, the graphics.. they all will draw you in. In an instant. Give it an hour or two playing and there won't be any letting go. I got the game a long while after the initial release because I was wary. In the end I got it for less but having finished I would have gladly paid the full price or even more than that. It's worth every penny. And the extensions, as mentioned above, add more content than most actual base games have. So go for it and let yourself immerse into it. Chances are you will like it very much.

OK after a year and a half of the initial release and during the Black Friday sale, I decided to finally purchase the 3rd installment of the Witcher series, the GOTY edition. Before I started playing, I decided to finish parts 1 & 2 once again to be more immersed in the story.   So, as a fan of the Witcher universe, I cannot but recommend the game. The graphics are stunning and well optimized, gameplay took me some time to get used to as there are a lot of key binds for my taste but that was quickly surpassed. The story so far is intriguing and hooks you up immediately but as this is a semi-open world game, I leave the main story for later. The game is worth every penny.  The game is wrongly labeled as open world while it's not actually one. It has vast area maps but you can't go everywhere without loading screens. E.g. from White Orchard to Velen, or from the HQ at Vizima to Velen. That is actually the only drawback I can find for it. Oh and Gwent. Why did they decide to implement that silly card game is beyond me. Dice Poker was excellent...  Finally the game, although beautiful, has some really blow-your-mind mods available, which make it even more stunning. Totally worth going there.

Just recovered from a very long gaming hangover and this one, unlike the literal meaning of it, was delightful. I don't often sing the praises of a game but 'The Witcher' like any work of art deserves a round of applauses and bows. During these 46 days I was on a true to life, almost real, absolutely extraordinary adventure. The 'Wild Hunt' took me through its tremendous world, from the burned to ashes villages, caused by the Great War's aftermath, and dark gloomy caves of various monsters for all tastes to incredibly beautiful forests, valleys and misty mountains stunning with their majestic ice peaks. On my journey I met a lot of unique people: kings, beggars, soldiers, poor mothers whose sons were taken by the inevitable wars or happy couples which were about to get married inspite of all the atrocity happening beyond the boarders of their village. And I still remember them all because they all had their own custom-made stories and fates in which I played a very significant role and so did they. All of these little stories I took part in were either ridiculous but really fun or dramatic and touchy. They got me into laughing hysterically or weeping bitter tears because of the consequences and the choices I made. The main story of Geralt of Rivia is deservedly one of the best stories in the history of the computer games. Throughout the whole gaming experience it keeps you on the edge of your seat and sets you free only after the credits fading away to the incredible soundtrack which is now forever stuck in my iPod. 'The Witcher 3' has erased the distinction between the games as a source of entertainment and the games as a source of something spiritual, a source of enlightment. Like a powerful book or a movie, long ago recognized as a masterpiece, it moves you into the burst of different emotions and thoughts which won't leave you in the next week or even more. To me this is the end of an era, the end of the epic trilogy started back in 2007 and finished today on June 26th, 2015. There's the only question left - What's next? Is there a life after the Witcher? Will there ever be anything like this? I hope so... I really hope so...
Simply the best game that I've ever played. 50 euro well spent.

Great story, side quests, and exploration. Every quest is like its own little story, and many take advantage of Geralt's unique background and abilities -- trained as monster hunter, etc. -- to be more interesting.  Combat is alright for what it is. Even the highest difficulty isn't trying to be 'challenging' like Dark Souls, but it does try to at least be 'balanced'. Potions feel like a deliberate part of the game, not cheats. The crafted gear is worth making, but not too overpowered. The best part is that lighting people on fire and watching them flail around is one of the best ways to kill humans, so it's encouraged.

'Damn you're ugly.'   Jokes aside, actually this is most likely the best game I have ever played. Prior to this, I felt it was a tie between Fallout: New Vegas or Skyrim, but this RPG blows those two out of the water. While it's probably not my favorite game ever, it is definitely up there. The visuals are stunning, the narrative is incredible, the combat is balanced - I actually feel like CD Projekt Red created a game as close to perfect as they get. The reason it's not my favorite game as of yet is because I haven't played it enough.   I recommend that when you play this, take it slow, do all or close to all of the side quests and contracts (which I didn't do and I regret since coming back to them later is too easy,) and also start this game on the 2nd lowest difficulty, and when you reach level 10 turn it up to Blood and Broken Bones or even Death March.   10/10  Update: Played through the game and Hearts of Stone by this point, and started Blood and Wine. Incredible. DLC is definitely worth buying, and the atmosphere in Blood and Wine is so different and beautiful.   11/10

I believe a game is deemed worthy of a purchase, if you can get 1 hour for each dollar you spent on this game. I got this game and all its DLC on sale, yet so far I have put enough hours in this game to have paid full price twice over. Yet I'm still not done with it.   The game has replayability, you can go back, try new builds, try new paths in your choices. Yet I haven't done that yet. The time I have put into this game has been playing the main story line, the Hearts of Stone quest line, and a lot of side quests. With still a lot more to go.  I can see myself putting over 200 hours into the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, with its vast open world, its amazing creatures, and immersive story telling. Not only in the main questlines, the side quests and witcher contracts feel like a short story themselves.  Each time I play the Witcher 3, I find myself not wanting to put the controller down. Many late nights have been spent as Geralt of Rivia, the butcher of Blaviken, and the many other titles that precede the main character of this breath taking experience of a game.   Witcher 3 Wild Hunt has won many awards, and whats more than that, its DLC has won many awards. The DLC good enough to be a stand alone game themselves. On top of that you even get around 17 free DLC to add onto the game, for completely free. CDPR is an amazing developer, they are what other companies should be, and they produce games other companies only dream of creating.   If you don't own this game, I more than reccomend it. You will start it up and play for what you think was a couple of hours, and find out you spent 10 hours in the game, and haven't even scratched the surface of this amazing work of art.

Now if you want to enjoy a masterfully done, expertly crafted RPG of insane proportions, then this Polish Mythology epic right here is your game.   The controls are slow and methodical, with quick reactions and swift, decisive strikes being your friend. This lends itself easily into an enjoyable and deep combat system coming very close to how Geralt would actually go about things in the books. Thinking things through, avoiding strikes where he can and cautiously maneuvering around his environment and his enemies.  The dialogue is thoughtful and mostly natural, with grade 'A' voice acting making everything come together perfectly.  Questing anywhere and everywhere is unique and rewarding, with many memorable side quests littered everywhere in the world. The story itself is, while a bit convoluted in places, enjoyable. Now, the expansions, 'Hearts of Stone' and 'Blood and Wine', are immense and interesting in both their storyline, but also the sidequests that lie within them. Adding these two masterpieces in storytelling to the lacking main story in the vanilla game easily makes this one of the best RPG's of 2015/2016, and hopefully for the next few years to come.  Performance is what you would expect from this beautiful and sweeping game.  AMD 8350 @3.9ghz Nvidia 970 16gb Corsair Vengeance 1600mhz  Game running and MAX EVERYTHING OOOOO BB  FPS result: 30-55 frames depending on where you are in the world.  In conclusion, this game is gr8, I r8 8/8, no deb8. Come for the story, stay for the everything.

You can plough nearly everything in this game. 10/10 farming simulator.  On a serious note, this game has impressed. Very much so.  It had a semi-rough launch with a few crashes, but they've fixed most of these problems.  The game itself is very pretty. Very nice to see a game with such a dynamic weather system. Most textures are high-quality, but there are some less appealing textures in certain places, such as foliage and rocks.   There is an obscene amount of NPCs in the game, though many are 'fillers', which provide a sense of immersion. They are often rude, disgusting and / or annoying. While traveling, people sometimes spit, cough and wheeze if you interact with them. The characters you can talk to have reasonable reactions to dialogue, believable expressions and body language.   The quests you can complete are many, but they don't get very repetitive. Well, at least they do not SEEM repetitive. They certainly are, but the depth of the world, plus the details the devs have managed to bake in to the quests make them unique nonetheless.   The gameplay feels polished. You can feel that they have used quite a bit of time to make things work well. However, the dodge and roll mechanics are sometimes a bit dodgy in the hit detection department. (pun intended) An attack you'd expect to dodge would hit you anyway. It's not gamebreaking, but i would not cry if this was tweaked.  The targeting system feels OK, you can usually rely on the autotargeting the game does for you. Alternatively, you can lock on if you like being whacked from behind.  The character progression trees were dissappointing. You get four mutagen slots, and twelve skill slots. The mutagens are drops from monsters, and some are unique to certain enemies. If you place said mutagens in their slots, all they give is a scaling damage / health bonus (depending on colour).  Most of the 'skills' or 'talents' you can get are flat damage / crit / health boosts. There are a few abilities such as alternate sign modes and a sword whirlwind. You will however see many 'boring' talents which give you flat bonuses which do not provide any new mechanics.  The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a game i can reccommend. If i'm to give it a rating, i would give it 9/10. Not full score because the game is not perfect, which is what the 10/10 rating is reserved for.

The DLC put out is so jam packed with things to do you will never feel like you were overcharged and underwhelmed.   The leveling system in The Witcher 3 is probably the most unique aspect of this title. You will not be able to level up even half the skills available to you. Because of this you genuinely have to make level up choices that will dictate much of your experience moving forward. Best title of 2015 easilly.

A titan among RPGs.   The Good. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt brings a vivid and atmospheric world,  full of bounties to collect, treasures to find and monsters to hunt... did I mention atmosphere? The story and dialogue alone makes this game an instant classic, it blends drama and bloodshed with jokes and wonder. The world size could be.. more, for those that enjoy massive scale. The world is large allready but much of it is either open water or dreadfully boring swamps. Also the fact that the city of Vizima is actually only the interior of a palace gives another 'meh' to the count. The combat is enjoyable and your character has skills and full gear to be customized. *Micro spoiler: Ciri is almost more fun to play as than Geralt.* Free DLC, also a nice addition.  The Bad. Your horse is possibly the dumbest individual in the game. Character movement can be clunky and get you stuck behind boxes, more annoying than game-breaking tho. Combat against multiple enemies can be hard at times, but it's even worse when friendly AI does nothing but soak up punches, block YOU from attacking and get you killed by being dumb. On some occations the game will randomly pause for a moment while trying to load a sequence in a dialogue that takes place further away. Rarely but still happening none the less, the game will get stuck in a loadingscreen into infinity, typically after dying and reloading. (This issue seems to have been fixed.   After playing Hearts of Stone I have to say the DLC is absolutely worth it. Cannot wait for Blood and Wine.

I would definitely give this game a go.

After spending 260 hours in this game (still have not finished it for the second time) I have decided to make a review of this masterpiece.  First of all, I have to say there are a lot of references to history of slavic people: Glagoljica, names of the cities (Novigrad), names of people and monsters, even lyrics in some songs (widow-maker) etc... and I am in love with that!  Now about the game:  1. Soundrack - just youtube Priscilla's Song. 2. Story - mindblowing, exciting, sad, happy, CHOICES DO MATTER, immersive, soooo many side quests, ... 3. Gameplay - at start it is strange, but once you get hang of it and master it it becomes exciting! 4. So many FREE DLCs and 2 expansions with lot of new, fresh and fun content! 5. GWENT. 6. I WANT MORE - the thing why I still haven't finished this game for the second time is that i don't want it to end!  This game has couple of minor hickups like once you master melee combat it becomes repetitive (even on Death March it is easy), or now and then you stumble upon a bug or two.  All in all, if You like story driven games, RPGs, where choices matter, like playing side quests, just roaming around, listening to some medieval music... THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU. And even if you don't like those games... this is still the game for you!  Personally this is the best game of all time in my gaming book!

Simply a masterpiece as always from CD Projekt.Evrything is cured in minimum details,from the locations to characters: the story is very intresting and even the secondary quests keep the player involved  The combat system should not be understimated because at higher difficulty levels,fights can be hard and its required to be focused,mostly while fighting many enemies at the same time.With the new 1.20 patch,all tthe menus are optimized and regrouped so its more easy to find what you are looking for  At last but not less important is the gwent: an amazing sub-game inside the game itself that its very funny and awesome

At first I was a bit apprehensive about this game, I have no idea why I just was. But damn, I am so sad I didn't get it sooner!  The world is thriving with life, there is so much content you will find it hard to keep track of all your quests and witcher contracts. The ways of traveling in this world make you appreciate the effort put into this so much more, wether you are riding your way through the forests on horse-back, or sailing the beatuiful seas surrounding the land or trudging your way through the mountains following the tracks of a Chort.  This game also has so many choices which will effect what happens in a story, and for a game with as much content as the witcher does whilst being an open-world game, that's pretty amazing! Ontop of the content they already have in the game they also let you customize yourself, with hair and beards, armours, swords, axes, maces and if you can find them in the city, masks. The combat system is both hard and fulfilling (I am playing blood and broken bones so please don't call me bad at the game for calling it hard xD) there are counters, heavy attacks, light attacks, blocking, parrying arrows and execution moves.  Also if you weren't already immersed in the game enough it makes some characters you will swing between loving and hating due to how real they are to the point where you really care what happens to them in the end. And even ontop of that immersion they have the witcher contracts, these are missions that you can get from a local towns bounty board, notifying you that a citizen needs someone's help to deal with a monster, which really puts your witcher skills to the test, you have to prepare for battle by brewing oils to do more damage, bombs, potions to buff yourself against this specific type of creature. This game has so much content, the voice acting is great, the characters are realistic, the world is beautfiul and thriving with life and they have a load of free DLC and the one's you need to pay for add so much more to their already full game.  If you still don't believe me that the Witcher isn't worth a buy, I managed to talk about a load of features and things about the game without saying ANYTHING about the main story. Now come on I can talk that much about a few minor things about the game for this long without mentioning a single thing about the main game.

Well-Rounded, memorable characters litter every street conrer and hill-top in the Witcher 3's dynamic and ever-changing world. Join Geralt, in one of the greatest action adventure games ever concived by man. As he treks through the Northern Kingdoms leaving blood, entrails, and titillated women in is wake. All on a tireless journey to find his (almost) daughter, Ciri.

A fantastic example of a basically-perfect game. I thought Witcher 2 was rich with story, gameplay and humor, but this one managed to top it in any possible way.  The performance overall is grand. The graphics are beautiful, even with my mediocre GTX 760 GPU.  Dialogue has a perfect mix of emotion, story/character-depth and humor. The voice-acting - along with accents, dialects, etc is top-notch.   The gameplay is great, attacks work fluid most of the time and you have some fair variety, plus a decent list with skills. It took me 110 hours to finish this game - WITHOUT THE DLC - and I gotta say, that's quite impressive for a Singleplayer game. The quests vary from challenging boss fights to hilarious goat-chasing, but every quest felt 'unique' and made me both curious and motivated to pursue all of them.  I recommend buying this if you're both a fan of the Witcher series or RPGs overall, you certainly won't regret it. It's truly worthy of the title 'Game of the Year', and the developers being 'Developer of the Year'.  Overall this is a finished game that's actually worth 60€, if not more - with a great story, great characters, great combat and great dialogues/voice acting. Something that is left to be desired in nowadays' gaming industry.  I will also be looking forward to buying the DLC later, for I'm convinced that CDRP won't disappoint.  EDIT: Game is also full of lewd

“Evil is evil. Lesser, greater, middling, it's all the same. Proportions are negotiated, boundaries blurred. I'm not a pious hermit, I haven't done only good in my life. But if I'm to choose between one evil and another, then I prefer not to choose at all.”  -Geralt, Butcher of Blaviken

It is great game. You can really immerse yourself in this game. Unlike other open world RPGs which have a similar fantasy medieval setting the cities and village have a believable size. In general the world design is very beautiful. The improvement compared to it's predecessors is breathtaking from a niche game to a game being at least on par with genre giants.   However the claim of the Witcher being an RPG is a half truth. While you really have some choices in the dialogues and can get a lot of loot, all other RPG mechanics are really bad. I get it you play as Gerald who is some kind of mix of mage and duelist but still they could at least implement a better character or perk system for customization of your hero.   But this is only me being nitpicking and the overall product is still a great game worth to be played.

So, here's what I'm going to say about The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, summed up rather quickly into 3 broad categories, the GOOD, the BAD, and the Uhhh...?  PROS! +This game is freaking beautiful +The combat engine is surprisingly deep +A LOT of character customization (outfits, skills, weapons, heavy, medium, light armor, etc) +AMAZING voice acting with superb sound editing! Even on my ancient speakers, it sounds FANTASTIC! +A story that seems simple, but becomes more epic as you play through it +BIG. FREAKING. WORLD. I'm over 50 hours in, and I've only just now hit the second map! It's a BIG game! +Lore, everywhere, so much lore!  CONS! -Absurd difficulty at times, where you may have no trouble beating a wyvern, and then a wolf that's 10 levels higher than you shows up 5 minutes later, and one-shots you.  -That's it for cons, seriously. That is my only gripe with this game, and it's easily fixed by dropping the difficulty.   Uhhh...? ?Gwent. The card game that I feel incredibly indifferent towards; I played it for a while to get extra money early on, but got really tired of it really quickly. For me, it's not particularly interesting, but I know some friends who basically decided to quit adventuring in TW3 to become, for lack of a better comparison, Yugioh.    In conclusion, you could do FAR worse for an open-world RPG. But be warned, if you're ANYTHING like me and like to try to get every collectible, you're going to go insane after a while. A lot of areas have a soft level-gate, where you can go in them, but you'll get gangbanged by a horde of robbers really quickly. It's kind of terrifying when it happens. But yeah, I seriously have very few problems with it, personally, and I can recommend this game to just about everyone.   I recommend The Witcher 3 to: RPG fans, lore fans, Witchers, people who like simple but good combat systems, and finally, anyone who thinks Geralt is a badass. And Geralt himself, if he can be bothered to play after murdering thousands of monsters and then falling into a moat.   I may play very different from everyone else...

This game has slowly made it's way to the top games I've played and enjoyed in my life. With the amazing writing, great open world, and meaningful quests that go further than the 'fetch this sword from a cave' type seen in other games. The story, including expansions, can be quite dark on one moment, and really funny another.  And I think one of my main things is that, even though you are a monster slayer, a witcher, violence is not the answer to most of the quests. It's based a lot more on research, detective work and the hunt. Ofcourse there are whole bandit hideouts to take out, but there are also quests to get through the beaurocracy at a bank or grabbing a pan for an old lade in a hut. Where a lot of games make violence the only conflict resolving option, like Fallout 4, the roleplaying, survival and real gameplay makes this game worth all. The expansions are vast and very worth it as well  Can't recommend this game highly enough.

Alright, so, im not big when it comes to posting reviews... i don't like posting reviews that are lengthy and boring to read, so, ill try and break this up into sub-sections... Lets start?   Gameplay:  I haven't played much of the other 'The Witchers' but i think its safe to say the gameplay is phenominal, the fluidity of movements and combat just seems amazing... This game is the first game where i actually took my time playing it... instead of running through towns trying to rush everything, i walked and listened. You can hear chatter amongst the NPC's as they discuss their personal issues, or issues you might encounter later on in the game... It's honestly a game that it going to take you a while to 100% complete... That is by no means a bad thing by the way, that just means you're getting more bang for your buck!   Graphics:  The graphics are unreal... my PC isnt beefy, and i cant play maxed out, but i can clearly see how much detail they put into it... the optimization is a large reason why i stay... as i said before, my PC isnt beefy, sure it has a r9-280x in it, but its not beefy >_> There are small details which make me have an inner-climax... The fog the blows in the wind, the monster looks, the towns that differ in variation... this is truly the reason why i play on PC... you can control how the world around you looks... it's in your capable hands!   Atmosphere:  Breathable.... Just kidding!. Anyway, this games so atmospheric that it just, sucks you in, and you can't stop playing it... remember that time you bought some other favourite game (i.e.) Far Cry 4? How everything around you seemed so lifelike, the animals were running around, eating, doing their animal stuff... people were chatting, driving, walking around, doing human stuff... Games like this are rare to come by, and the Developers of The Witcher 3 {CD Projekt Red) did a great job making sure that you would keep playing... I love you can just, walk in a small town, and want to stay there for the rest of your life, you just dont even want to finish the game, you just want to listen to the conversations, and become part of the community.    Sound:  The sound in this game is... well, i don't even know how to say this without being mean... up to speed with current games? It's comparable to GTA5 in the sense where, instead of hearing car horns beep, you hear people talk, and work at the village. I am using surround sount headphones (steelseries syberia v2) and everything is clear, and you know where the talking is coming from... its like there's someone behind you in real life when NPC's talk behind you... once again, great job devs!   Controls:  Controlling Geralt feels spot on, apart from some aspect where you're sprinting, and you stop, and you run into the wall and it looks clumsy. Same with the horse, you run into the wall, and it looks clumsy... im not saying that its a bad port by any means, im just saying, don't expect yourself to run into the walls and not look clumsy... :P   Plot:  No spoilers, i promise... The plot was well thought out, and followed through perfectly... It kept me interested, as there were moments that would shock you. and other moment where you just wanna cry and hug your cat because its the closest thing you have to a best friend (dat lonely lyf) Even the side missions are amazing, it's comparable to Skyrim to be honest... if you enjoyed the skyrim plot/side missions, youll enjoy The Witcher 3's side missions and plot!  To give this game a rating out of 10... it would have to be an honest 9/10, the other 1 point is because i havent finished it, and im stuck in Velen with over 100 Question Marks to deal with -.-

What Can be said that the hype hasn't said already? For once, a triple A title worth the hype and the price. I could go on for days about terrible triple A releases and their pricetags, but for once CD Projekt Red shows the industry how its done. Not only is this game beautiful, but its incredibly well written and will keep you playing for hundreds of hours. I've played through the game twice now, and can say it will be one of those games to inspire constant returns for the years to come. Whats most impressive for me is how flawless the combat feels. In the games predecessors I felt the controls could be clonky and found myself screaming at my monitor because my dodged just missed the tip of the enemy's sword thus resulting in my immediate death and wipe of all my save files (CURSE YOU WITCHER 2'S HARDEST DIFFICULTY!). Combat rarely gets boring and offers many different ways to deal with situations, though there are definitely 'optimal' ways to dispose of enemies.   The books this series are based on are throroughly well-written, even when translated and The Witcher 3 really holds strong to this fundamental for this intellectual property. The game's voice acting is excellent, and the writing is on par as well, with countless hours of dialogue to keep you listening and hopefully interested in the world unfolding at your whim.   This game is amazing, and definitely warrants a purchase from enthusiasts and casuals the same. You'll easily get your money's worth, which is greatly refreshing for our modern landscape of gaming. CD Projekt Red deserves a lot of kudos for this title, and I can say they've earned my money, and given me a chance to truly engage in the vast world of The Witcher.
Yennefer of Vengerberg, Triss Merigold and Keira Metz Need I say more?

The visuals and storyline of this game set it apart from anything currently on the market. You need to be aware of how you interact with certain people as it can alter how the game ends, whether or not you can fully (100%) complete the game, and the time frame of when you reach higher tierd (level) fights.  Secondary missions are key to not only leveling you charachter up but also to fully fleshing out the Witcher universe. Completing these missions throughout the map allows for you to talk to more minor part charachters who may help to develop the main storying.  There are books that tell you about not only different spells/concoctions you can make but also the history of different charachters and how to better fight specific monsters.  The only issue I have with this game is the somewhat boring fight system. The game gives the ability to alter how difficult the ai is to fight (this is the difficulty in the settings menu not levels in game). At the lower levels this game turns into a button masher, where no boss fight/monster fight will ever take more than one try to finish. At the higher level difficulty you may need to think slightly more about how to attack a monster (what concoction to use on weapons/monster/yourself) but again the majority of the fights feel monotonous.   This fight system can also make witcher contracts feel monotonous, this lead me to skip a number of them mid game to focus on the main and secondary storyline. Witcher contracts (unlike some of the main/secondary missions) can be completed at any time during the game and will never disappear (or atleast to my memory none did), they didnt change or evolve over time and therefore contracts that were meant for me to be completed at level 10 stayed at that level.... returning to it when I was level 24 made for an easy 1 hit kill. Personally I think each contract should evolve slightly if you skip it, so that a contract can become harder to defeat if you leave it too long (with the monster evolving) rather than being easier to defeat.  I would definitely recommend this game, the fight system is only a small negative as it is much like other games, the story however is step above the majority.

CD Projekt Red have meticulously crafted a game in a such a stunning manner, that they have taken the crown as best game developers in my book. There's so much content and it's all great! You can explore medieval cities, vast forests, chilling swamps and some down right terrifying caves. The combat is fluid, challenging and fun, requiring precise timing. Enemies don't wait in line to attack you, but instead team up and slash/spit/chomp simultaneously. The graphics can be breathtaking if your PC can handle it, and the ambiance is incredible. The sound of howling winds, water dripping off cave hangings and the bustling city all come together to immerse you in a beautiful fashion. The amount of time I've put in and yet I've not grown a single bit tiresome, because every quest feels important, if not to the story, to the characters and world. The main story-line correlates with side quests, and vice versa. No longer do they feel entirely separate. Actions you do (or don't do) ripple throughout the world. I could ramble on about this game for hours, but in the end, this is one of the greatest games ever made. Please don't miss this experience.

NO SPOILERS!  A crying little boy in the streets asks for your help. You follow him... into an ambush.  An woman is threatened by a group of villans. You intervene ... and after saving her she insults you.  You enter an abandoned village with corpses lying around, Suddenly a strong wind starts blowing, trees and bushes are bending and the sky grows dark - just before a wraith attacks you.  In short... Witcher 3 is a true masterpiece.  PRO: The obvious: + Stunning graphics, animations and cinematics (best I'Ve ever seen in an RPG) + Superb music, voices and sounds (BTW fully voiced) + controlling your character inside and outside battles is fluent and intuitive + Game never crashed - not just once. + Excellent quest navigation (never had to look up where to go next). But most of all: + CDPR created a living world worth exploring every last corner + with an immersive atmosphere + an interesting story + meaningful (no 'pick 10 flowers' or 'kill 5 Bears') and adult sidequests. + different outcomes and endings based on your decisions (decisions you might even have made in the first couple of hours)  CONS: Well not much here - and some are not even real arguments. - You need to get used to playing a premade character: Gerald of Rivia - so no character creation or individual look. - Also development of your character skill wise only plays a minor role. - Most of the time you are on your own - so no party or companions.  MISC: * Playing on max details, I5-2400, GTX780, 8GB RAM, 1080p * Playtime: without sidequests approx. 30 to 40h. With doing all sidequests and exploring the land >130h.  VERDICT: I played so many RPG's over the last 30 years, I lost count. But today a fully voiced game is mandatory for me because I'm simply tired of reading quest texts. So for me Witcher 3 is the best RPG since Dragon Age: Origins - and it's even better. It is one of the very very few games I'd say 50 € are well spend and CD Project Red deserves every cent of it. 9/10  Tip: * Install the game on an SSD because loading times (when you died - so not ingame loading!) can be annoying. * Consider playing the game on a higher difficulty level right from the start.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt was an incredible journey. I played this with no prior knowledge of any of the Witcher lore what so ever, but that did not matter because CDProjektRed did a good job of welcoming newcomers to the game by making Geralt (the main character you play) recovering his memory, I suppose he lost his memory in previous games. So if you have not played the other Witcher games, do not let that stop you from picking up this incredible game. Graphics are impressive despite a graphics downgrade from previous showings. Character models for characters are very detailed in voice acting and animations, a little thing I noticed however were that some character models were re-used throughout the game at varied points, which is not a huge deal, but lessens the ammount of immersion and authenticity of the world around you. A problem I personally come across in other RPG's is that I do the main quest and pretty much ignore everything else, unless it presents itself to me. That is probably one of the best things that this game does very well. Side quests are shown and placed very strategically so that it feels natural to the player. You will be on your way to a quest/location, when suddenly you will see an exclamation point on your mini-map showing a side quest available. This makes the players feel as if they naturally stumbled across this side quest on their own, and deepens the immersion by making it feel like a living breathing world. Everywhere you go there are side quests like this available, which are all optional, but at the same time are so satisfying if you decide to follow through with them. Most if not all feel as if they are apart of the main quest. It feels like you are Geralt, and you are just doing your job and helping or not helping people in the world that surrounds you. I did every single side quest that was available to me, and I do not regret it at all. I do praise the developers for making that happen, and I wish to see other games try and incorporate this as well. Combat in the Witcher 3 is fairly simple, you have your fast attack, heavy attack, parry, dodge, and roll. These are the basic combat elements, which play very well. There are also other ways to play for advanced players, such as applying different oils and potions for specific enemy types which will cause more damage. You also have Witcher signs which are basically magic spells. The combat dips a little bit here, because in my playthrough, the only sign I used was Quen, which basically gives you a 1 hit shield from enemies. I played on the second hardest diffuculty which was challenging but satisfying. I never felt like I was being cheated whenever I died. The story in this game is simple as well, you are looking for a girl named Ciri, whom you raised and tough how to fight as a child and the antagonist named Eredin wants to use her powers to bring what is essentially the apocalypse. Yeah Ciri is OP as hell. She has elder blood in her which makes her ridiculously powerful. That is the main goal, but the Witcher 3 shines in the journey towards that. You meet a vast and interesting set of characters along the way. The characters in this game really make this game stand out from others in it's genre. When you talk to other characters in the game it consists of a list of dialogue options. Yellow dialogue means that you will progress and get on with the story while white dialogue options give you more insight and background information which really help flesh the game out and make you essentially care and deeply invest into the games characters. I constantly found myself picking all of the white dialogue to find out more before continuing on with the conversation. Choice is another essential part of this game, your choices have immediate impact and effects the final conclusion to the game as well. You can even play out the choices you make with the love interests in the game. I found myself struggling with which love interest to pick from before deciding on one. The Witcher 3 does many things right, but it is not a perfect game. There are quite a few of bugs that I encountered on my playthrough. It varied from hair dissapearing from characters to constant pop-ins every time the camera angle cut between dialogue. I once found a man doing the 'Reject' a dance move while carrying some boxes. Those bugs were kind of annoying and broke the illusion of the world. Some game breaking ones however were when I had to get on a boat for a quest but had previously parked another boat there before hand which cause the two boats to glitch out on each other, which forced me to have to re-load one of my previous saves. Luckily the auto save feature is pretty good and keeping checkpoints so I did not lose too much progress. At the conclusion of the game I clocked in at around 94 hours. All in all, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt was amazing. Simple as that. Like I said before the game is not perfect. However, everything that the game does right makes up for it and even more in my opinion. The game is beautiful to look at, the story is interesting, combat is generally fun and challenging at the same time. The enemy types have tons of variation. I found myself get choked up at least 3 times in the game. This game has an incredible amount of value, and it is quality as well. It does not compromise one for the other. It was a time investment, but one that I do not regret. I have even bought The Witcher 1 and 2 because I wanted more Witcher (You do not have to do this however). It was an incredible journey, one that I will remember and that will stay with me. I can honesly say that this is the best RPG I have ever played. I am now curious to see what developer CDProjektRed is planning next.

I understand how some might be disappointed because of the graphical downgrade, but the game is optimized very well, which in my opinion is the more important thing after all and the game runs solid 60 FPS at high settings @ 1440p with my GTX 970. And even with the downgraded graphics it still looks excellent and more importantly the story and game play feel awesome. I would suggest the game for anyone interested of a good RPG.  And for anyone experiencing frequent crashes with NVIDIA cards I would recommend you to change the power management mode in NVIDIA control panel from Adaptive to Maximum performance. The Witcher 3 is one of those rare jewels that you only find once or twice every decade. It is masterfully crafted with the audience in mind by CD Projekt Red, a once-a-time small team. Their only games up to now are the Witcher series, but that will change soon. And you can easily see the love they put into it, from the beginning until the end of production.  First off, this game is beautiful. Moments like the splatter of raindrops on puddlesin the giant city of Novigrad, to the wind sweeping through the forsts of Velen will create beautiful screenshots, and the optimization is perfect. One of the best looking game for the amount of land there is to explore.  Combat is straight-forward : strong attack and light attack. There are 5 signs you can use as magic and variants to all of these. Since this is quite simple, The Witcher 3 compensates with a smart AI that is different for every creature in the world. Each has resistances and weaknesses, both in the damage and their patterns.   Story-wise, the main story is only 5 to 10% of the entire story. The side quests create a living world, full of colors, wether they be dark and need mosters ridden or colorful in masquerade balls. Oddly, up to now, my favorite quest has been a treasure hunt because of the lore and background they gave to it from books found near the objectives.  On the note of sound, kudos to the designers. The soundtrack is perfect for the setting and the moment, with a fluidity between all of the songs. The bustling Novigrad streets sound like streets, and I once had to remove my headphones because I heard birds and thought i forgot to close my window. It was still closed.   TL ; DR : Amazing. Witcher 1 and 2 are sitting in my library, with about 2 hours each. They never caught me, partly because of some inaccuracies to the books, which I have read. Witcher 3 retells these stories and speaks of the impact that transpired from these events so wonderfully, it is making me wonder if the author did not write the stories of the game. It is fastly climbing the ranks of my most hours played on steam ; il a week, I added 40 hours to it besides my full-time job. That is something I have not exerienced for a while.   Now, the wait for Cyberpunk 2077 shall start, but in the meantime, I probably can add at least 300 hours to this.

44 hours in, and I've done what seems to be a quarter, perhaps less, of this game. If that doesn't tell you the sheer scale, I don't know what will.   Firstly,  Graphics . Probably the least important feature for me, but the way the Witcher uses them is amazing. This game uses it's second to none graphics to create moments of jaw-dropping awe at the wonderful and amazing world in front of you (Seriously, I sometimes had to put down the controls and just watch the scenery in silence).  Secondly,  Story . I haven't actually finished this, but so far it seems intuitive and well told, which I would expect from a game based off a book. The game has a great way of unfolding the story to you in discrete ways, such as through world design and general attitude of people toward your character, and other people. Right from the get go, you know Witchers are hated and shunned as freaks, monsters and discriminated against big time. But this isn't just told to you in dialogue, you witness it first hand. It really makes you form your own opinions on things, instead of just being given the truth on a silver platter. Also, I'll incorporate side quests in here, since each one has a detailed, engaging story, which can span many hours of gameplay. Twists, interesting characters and unique, fun objectives. There are no kill quests, AT ALL in this game. Each quest has it's own unique structure and objective set, which makes them more of an enjoyment than a chore. Masterfully done.  Thirdly, the  Sounds . What to say here? The ambient sounds are very good. Not the absolute best I've heard, but honestly I don't think very present ambience would suit this game. It suits your current environment, and thats fine by me. But then... Music. The soundtracks of the Witcher are AMAZING. From fast-paced chanting to soft, calming mumming, the music does an amazing job of getting your attention and keeping it. Combat music really gets you focussed and into the mood, which is just masterful.  Fourthly,  Dialogue/Voice Acting : Dialogue is superb. Dry-wit lines from Geralt mixed with creative lines creates a wonderful experience. The things you say in conversation are often neither good nor evil, but a mark in between. Characters speak like they would; you won't see a commoner going around using words such as 'Grandeur'. The English is very good in the lines, much better than previous games, which makes me happy. Often times in previous games, lines would get lost in translation slightly due to CDPR being a Polish studio, but somehow they fixed this. Voice acting is amazing. You will rarely hear the same voice in two characters (Very rarely), unless it's passing commoners, but in both cases, repeated voices are far enough apart to not break immersion. You won't talk to the tavernkeep, then go down the road and talk to his mate the Blacksmith and hear the same person.  Fifthly, the  UI/Controls : Nothing to complain about here. The UI is very flexible, allowing you to turn off certain elements. It's all structured in a way so information is easy to access, but not overcoming. You'll only ever see things you need to see. Controls are nothing too amazing, but nothing too shabby. I use a wired Xbox controller with games like this (3rd person sword fighting games which use X/Y/B/A in combat), so I can't attest for the PC controls, but I have heard they are fully customizable. I never experienced any input lag, and Geralt always did what I wanted him to do, except on rare occasion, but honestly it was often times my own fault  Finally, the  Combat . A masterpiece. It is perfectly paced. Slow enough to keep it suspenseful, fast enough to keep you on your toes. There is a real need to combine several different aspects of combat i.e you can't just spam attack creatures or enemies, you have to dodge, get behind them, block, prioritize enemies, use signs, etc. Every creature feels different, and must be fought in a different way. For example, when fighting a Bear, you must wait for their slow attacks to finish, and use Quen sign all the time as a safety net, then go in for quick pot shots, where as with wolves, which hunt in packs, you must constantly be moving and using signs such as Aard and Igni so they don't group up and slaughter you. This means you develop personal styles as you play the game, which is what a Witcher is about: adapting to the fight. Also, I'd recommend Death March, as it really enforces the need to prepare for fights, which is half the game, and makes it all that more rewarding.   Final Conlusion

I love the musics and the background sounds really fit into the game's world. Really love those thunders and winds noises when a storm is approaching. Make the game feels alive.  The graphics are, well. You know about this already. Beautiful. TOTALLY WORTH IT.

This game is beautiful in every possible way. I have never felt so attached to the characters in a story and you actually start to care about them. The Storytelling is great, there are lots of cinematics involved and it takes quite some time to get through the main story and all the extras it has to offer. While I did not yet complete the game I can already say that this is by far the best game I have played in a while (atleast for RPGs). The world is incredible, it is massive and very beautiful and the weather effects and physics make it really feel alive, it feels like you really are in a forest or city. And all the little villages you ride through during the game is just lovely. I was struggling a little in the beginning with the combat system on the other hand, it felt a little clunky but it is just something you have to get used to, it is in every way an improvement on previous Witcher games. And I noticed that I have barely seen any bugs aside from clipping clothes and annoying horse mechanics. Developers have really polished the game well and created a masterpiece. It's hard to not recommend this game because it really is GREAT as far as RPGs go...

Fantastic near-flawless experience. This game had some of the best writing and cutcenes I'd ever seen in a game. The only weakpoints i could say about the game is probably the combat and some earlier points of the game take a while before things all come together story-wise.  Now with the combat - it's not bad in any sense of the word, it's just not perfect and you cant say that about any game really. But it's honestly not the game's strongest aspect - though it never feels repetitive, it just is there to hold your attention so you can get to the next part of the story or side-mission.  And honestly those are my only two criticisms of the game other than the fact you can sometimes fail quests when you start others since they might conflict with the grand-scheme of the story-telling, though those moments happen rarely and only during crucial parts of the story. You could always reload just before starting the new quest and quickly complete the old ones before they fail. I did that almost every chance I got and they were always worth it.   All in all I'd give this game a perfect 10/10.  Though it's not completely perfect - it comes extremely close to achieving perfection. Best game I've played all year so far.

When I heard about this game, I knew that it would be a great experience, so I went out and played the first and second installments of the franchise, and cloncluded with the Witcher 3. All I can say is that the 200 hours of my life that I lost in this series of video games were COMPLETELY worth it, and that the Witcher 3 is perhaps the best game I've ever played.   This game is somehow able to combine all the great elements of a linear, story driven game: choices, different endings, compelling characters, and a complex plot, with the immersion and exploration of an open world game. Every side quest you come across is interesting and has its own well-written plot and characters where your actions often influence the quest's outcome. In one quest you will be investigating a murder, while in another you will be hunting a legendary monster found deep in the forest. As for the main quest, where do I even begin? Combining both the personal life and challenges of the main character, the war-torn political atmosphere, and a prophesized apocalypse, this is a story worthy of any good book. The atmosphere in this game is incredible. From the cozy mountain fortress of Kaer Morhen, to the swamps, castles, battlefields, and villages of Velen, and the rocky, monster-infested, norse-themed Skellige Islands, the environment in this game is brilliant. The city of Novigrad, especially, feels very real, with a high-class of priests, two kingdoms, and a criminal underwold each competing for control of the prosperous merchant city.  A game, however, isn't only about its story and atmosphere. The combat is complex, yet fun and challenging. You utlize both strong and fast attacks with your two swords: steel for humans and silver for monsters. In addition, you can oil your swords with poisons that affect certain enemies, brew potions to boost your own stats, craft bombs with various effects, and use magic spells to manipulate the battlefield. All of this in addition to a complex skill system involving trophies taken from slain monsters, and the vast variety of weapons and armor in this game, and the combat in this game is definately a major strenght.  Finally, the game's developers need to be complimented, having released 16 free minor dlcs (such as new armor, weapons, and quests), in addition to two expansion packs that will together have over 30 hours.   Ultimately, this game is a MUST OWN, and is a testament to how a developer with a relatively low budget (compared to other AAA games) was able to create possibly the best story and world of all time in a Western RPG.
