I've been sucked into the Witcher world since The Witcher 1 (also read the books). So I came into the Witcher 3 with a huge amount of hype and expectations. Having finally 'completed' one run through of it (DLCs included), I can say that Witcher 3 is definitely the best RPG game I've played in this decade. CDPR has set a high bar for all other RPGs to aspire to (and sadly, I fear that it might have ruined other RPGs for me in this lifetime).   Graphics: As everyone can see from the crazy amount of screenshots out there, Witcher 3 is a beautiful game. I could potentially just stand there for hours, soaking in the digital rays. More gripping is the fact that each country in the game is so different from one another, making you feel that you're truly in another place.  Combat: I play on the M+KB (I'm no good with controllers). It definitely feels less clunky than the Witcher 2. While they haven't revolutionized everything, it's comfortable and engaging and that's enough for me.  The story: The books have always had an amazing storyline, and for Witcher 3 to dip its toes into it more and write a true sequel to the books excited me but scared me beyond measures. They did not disappoint, they helped find explanations and closures and twists and excitement.   The writing: A lot of the fun tidbits in game is through the books and notes you pick up. DO read them, they are so fun to read and often hilarious or heart-jerking.  Voice acting: Doug Cockle once again delivers, bringing Geralt to life. All other voice actors did a great job as well (e.g. Denise Gough brought out the ♥♥♥♥♥iness in Yennefer quite well)  Soundtrack: I often turn off the music in the back ground for RPGs this long because I'd rather listen to my own music after a while, but not for this game. It ties everything together and helps immerse you into the game, its world, its lore.  I think it's time for me to play through the game once more.

I'm a tough game critic, I'm the first to point out flaws in a game that the general population may find 'amazing'.  That is not the case here. My first hour into the game, I had no negativity, none at all, I was immersed into the story, enjoying the gritty combat (severing of heads and limbs), and laughing uncontrollably at literally almost all of the dialogue. I actually felt the need to take some time away from the game just to write a review on it.  Let's start with the basics, the graphics and scenery are out of this world. Setting the time to sunset near a lake, you'll actually feel like you're 'there', it looks the closest to reality that I've seen to date. (the ambiance such as deer, grass and trees swaying in the rain/wind, and even blades of grass swaying in the wind, really come together to create an amazing environment).   Secondly, it takes the importance of decision-making to an ENTIRELY new level, the importance of your decisions in games such as Fable or Fallout PALE in comparison to how much they matter in The Witcher 3. When a game gives me the option to end a cute/romantic date with the choice of either bidding the woman a bittersweet farewell, or slashing and incinerating her on an island....I'm at a loss for words at how awesome that is.   Also, I can't stress enough how important and influential your dialogue decisions are, they make a huge difference. You can either charm your way out of what would've been an unfair fight, or you can just say '**** it' and taunt your adversaries into a relaxing bath of blood and fire.   The storyline is very well written, and was put together in a manner that shows the developers actually cared about the outcome of the game, and the satisfaction of their consumers. My particular favorite example is the quest 'Family Matters' (From beginning, to end), I hadn't been that immersed in a side-story that much since I used to watch Law&Order in 2001.   I'm also enjoying the realism of the development of romantic relationships, or how that possibility can be revoked as a result of one single mistake/error in dialogue/task refusal (As is such....in reality...).   In short, all I can say is, just buy the game, and the Season Pass, if you can spring for it. You won't regret it. If you're a fan of gore/dismemberment/gritty combat, you'll love it, you can spend hours just wandering around slaughtering wolves, people, monsters, harpies, etc. If you love gripping storylines, then you'll definitely enjoy this one. If you like romantic stories, definitely go for this one, plenty of that. If you like sex....do I really need to explain this one? It's the Witcher series...and they've outdone themselves x100 in this installment.   Just buy the game, you definitely won't regret it, no matter how picky of a gamer you are.  Ultra settings + Nvidia Hair= ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for the eyes.  Oh, and...HIS BEARD GROWS IN REAL TIME.....I'VE NEVER SEEN THAT BEFORE. THAT IS JUST PLAIN AWESOME.

Let me just say I was not expecting to love this game, or even really like it for that matter. I picked this up during the steam summer sale for $25 after hearing many great things about it, but I was not expecting it to be as incredible as it is. After playing as much as I have I would happily pay $100+ for it! This is the best RPG I have ever played by far, and perhaps even the best game of all time. I am 50 hours in and have not even finished the main quest, and I admit that the side quests and contracts are so intriguing that I find myself doing all of them. The game has just so much content it's hard to actually explain it, honestly I am astounded at how many quests there are, things to do, and how the game has a backstory to each character and town which make me actually care about its inhabitants. Leveling, combat, and all other game mechanics are great, although there are some glitches which are purely aesthetic and do not interrupt gameplay. I can't wait to beat the story and pick up the two DLCs for the game which provide another 20+ hours each! Do yourself a favor and buy this game, you won't regret it.

Well what can I say, it took me 65 hours to complete this game while enjoying side quests and monster hunts, which might as well have been mandatory. Really, the quests in this game have so much quality in them that they rival the main story line. Gwent have been one of my favourite time killers, I really enjoyed completing all the quests and collecting most of the possible cards. The sad part is that when you start a new game (on increased difficulty for funzies) the deck won't carry over.   Combat: At first, I found combat frustrating given the amount of possible actions you need to memorize for each type of enemy (and there is quite a few of them) but after some time and leveling some signs (Igni and Quen op. Quen is not so op as in Witcher 2 but it's still a great sign). I was quite pleased at the synergy some signs have with witcher bombs, for example Dragon's Dream which fills an area with explosive gas which can be detonated with Igni.  Alchemy: I really like the addition of oils in witcher 3, there are so many types that force you to discover areas and merchants with the right recipe, they also require you to have a certain degree of knowledge as to which monster falls under which category (and making the beastiary more than just a lore addition).  The famous witchers' Elixirs were given quite a change, for those who played Witcher 1, you can use them during combat again! YAY! But they are quite harder to make now. Many times you need to search for their recipes in various places (most of them are avaible in stores however some eluded me), and some ingridients require you to seek help of a craftsman who can dismantle your current ingridients into more basic ones.  Armors & Weapons: Lots, Lots & Lots more weapons & armors! However when it comes to finding the right craftsmen it takes a bit of time and exploration. Which is not actually a bad point, since the game tries its best to emulate a witchers journey, through which he has to search for his prey, resources, and craftsmen.   Overall 10/10 the game was really worth the money!
Should I even review this game? Just buy it now.

It's honestly kinda baffling how goddam good this game is. The first Witcher was bordering on unmitigated disaster IMO, and one of the most disappointing games I had played in ages; the second game was good, with some great decision points, but some serious scaling issues and a lackluster third act that held it back from greatness; and now we have the final installment with is just short of perfection.   Pros:    Massive world to explore    Outstanding voice work and dialogue    Almost every quest is interesting and doesn't fall into MMO tropes like fetch quests    Interesting cast of characters, including rich character depth    Visually stunning, especially if you can run Ultra + Hairworks (which is no easy task though), even with the slight downgrade after E3 2014    THE FEELS. OH GOD THE FEELS. If you don't tear up a bit at end of Isle of Mists, you have no soul.   Cons:    Enemy and horse AI can be sketchy sometimes    Still a few bugged locations that can get you stuck    Easy and normal difficulties are too easy    Handful of progression bugs (none gamebreaking though)    Will bend almost any computer over and make it it's ♥♥♥♥♥    A few minor annoyances that still need fixing (like losing Decoctions during vital battles)    Flat out awful keyboard + mouse controls. Very clearly designed with controller in mind.  And this is completely ignoring the giant minigame that is Gwent. A quite enjoyable card game once you get the grasp of it, though can be a little lacking in balance as there is rarely a reason to include weaker units unlike games such as Hearthstone.   Final Thoughts:  I'm amazed at what CD Projekt Red have accomplished here. They set the bar really goddam high for other western RPGs. Not only did they make almost all quests feel interesting in fresh, the sheer amount of content is kinda staggering. If you have any interest in WRPGs, what are you waiting for?

Ruined my life, now have a crush on a fictional redheaded female character.  10/10

Pros:    Story: Wow. This game has an immense, immersive…I need another “I” word…INCREDIBLE story to it. Almost all of the quests have a depth behind them. It can be little crap things that lead right into a huge line that you would have never even known existed if you hadn’t talked to that little village person (there’s no giant exclamation mark above the heads of people). I stumbled upon many of them just wandering around the world. It’s…crazy. I’ve been humbled and taken back by how awesome it is. I’m not even talking about the main story, which in itself is pretty legit. No, enthralling. It’s storytelling at it’s best and honestly, all games in this category need to step it up if they want to compete with future witcher games.  The sheer amount of armor, weapons and items is staggering. You can upgrade a ton of things including your horse! There are so many designs to find and craft (treasure hunting) that you’ll be drawn into that aspect just to find them all. Things to do: You will get caught up in so many things you won’t know what to do with your time in game. It’s encompassing. Side quests will pop up everywhere from you running around while you’re just exploring or while you’re already on a quest or checking out the local board in a town, ect. Witcher contracts, horse races and treasure hunts, oh my!  Gwent! – This is a side game, but really it should be a stand-alone game. It’s in-depth and I found myself wanting to challenge anyone and everyone that I could to a couple rounds of Gwent just to win a card that I didn’t have.  Funny lines batman! The devs included references from media culture in the game. For one, I dare you to find all the Pulp Fiction quotes.  The world is crazy big and there is so much to explore. If you’re like me, you’ll love to just venture around and check things out on your map that might look like something interesting even if they have nothing to do with a current quest. The environment is fantastic to look at! It really shows with whatever atmosphere you’re in too. It might be in a pitch black cave or on the top of sprawling snow capped mountains. It all looks beautiful! No matter what you heard about dumb downed graphics (because of the console versions), the pc version is awesome.     Cons:    No matter what graphic setting you put the game on I still can’t get out of the game unless I ctrl + alt + delete. Alt + tab does nothing. I have two monitors, so that might have something to do with it? I’ve tried all the settings (yes, even windowed mode) and I still can’t get it to leave the screen without pressing those said keys.  Combat is just…well, it could use some work. It’s sad to say since it’s a main part of the game. There’s only a handful of things that you can do. You have your fast and your strong attack with your swords. Those each have a combo. Then if you “spec” into a certain skill tree you can have a special attack with the fast attack and/or strong attack. That’s it as far as the swords.  Magic skills seem to lose the value of what being a witcher is supposed to mean. They don’t seem to do enough vs. what your swords can do.  Counter attacking needs some help. If you have multiple enemies attacking you, just roll out of the way, If you don’t, you just get hit. It has no assassin’s creed combat value where it actually knows that multiple people are attacking you.  There needs to be more skill slots. That or they need to change the amount of points you get. You’ll end up just putting points in a tree and just going with that. There’s no hybrid builds really.  The game is riddled with bugs. From quests to talking to people to just trying to look at a loot items, you might stumble upon a bug or you might not at all. Don’t get me wrong, these are not game breaking bugs, but they can be very annoying. I can go into detail if you need.  No bug fixing by the devs? There was an update 9 days ago from this posting, so it seems they are doing something… This could just be me since most of the bugs that I’ve experienced haven’t been fixed yet.    Conclussion:    I could probably talk more about various things, but this pretty much sums it up. The game is definitely worth it’s weight in gold. Even if you haven’t played any of the other Witcher games, you’re sure to love this one!

Absolutely brilliant game for the price you pay. Everything about this game is great. The characters, weaponry, scenery design, plot, attention to detail, everything. Geralt is a fantastic main character, with just the right amount of snarky sarcasm and honest love for his friends. Despite the whole 'You should probably read the books/play the previous games or else you'll be lost' stigma around the game, I jumped into Witcher 3 with no previous knowledge of the games or lore. And I loved it, and loved the characters I met. Reading up about how Geralt has interacted with them in the past games/books made me love them even more. The DLCs are also full-game scale alone. Hearts of Stone is roughly longer than the BF4 campaign in terms of time to complete, and Blood and Wine blows that out of the water, giving a storyline that's literally a full game by itself, with the inclusion of an entire new worldspace that has beautiful design, and more interesting characters. The only downsides to the game that I could say is that the fall-damage is messed up, but there's a mod to fix that, and that your horse has a propensity to get stuck on walls and obstacles (In a great sidequest in Blood and Wine this is even referenced in a tongue-in-cheek way). Aside from this, this game is deserving of all of the critical acclaim it's receiving, and more.  Do yourself a favour, buy this game if you haven't already.

The highest 9 I have ever given, and so close to being my first 10/10, one thing stopped me giving it a perfect score (more on that later).  The Witcher III is an RPG of gigantic proportions, with almost endless content spread throughout a massive and frankly stunning looking world. The starting area at the time felt huge, but it's a microscopic portion of the game, when all is said and done you can easily spend 150 hours in the game if you want to complete everything. Every part of the world is filled with life, be it people or wildlife, and the scenery is truly breathtaking, I often found myself just sitting back in awe of just how good the game looks. The world feels so alive, and this is helped by some truly fantastic voice acting and story telling, riding through a town you will here countless little conversations organically playing out around you, and decisions you make will change the course of the game, so pick wisely!  So the game has top notch visuals and audio, unmatched story telling and all the content you could ever want, so what's wrong with it? Well, not much really, in fact the only negative is the movement system, especially on horseback. It's so bad I feel knocking off a point is justified as you spend a lot of time on horseback especially which is by far the worst offender when it comes to movement, as well as AI (Roach will often spawn nowhere near you, on the other side of a wall or just refuse to move at all until you manually mount him). Geralt's movement has been improved since launch with an alternative movement option, and I suggest you use it.  I should also mention the game within a game, Gwent. It's a card game that you can play against NPCs throughout the game, think similar to Hearthstone. It's very easy to pick up but quite hard to master, you will need to use sound strategy to beat the harder opponents. You can get lost Gwent easily if you're not careful, it's very addictive.  To sum up, The Witcher III is up there with the best games of all time, and it's an absolute must buy for anyone who enjoys the RPG genre as it's as close to perfection as possible and you will love every minute of it.

Steam keeps eating my review, which is frustrating...so I'll cut to the basics.  This game is phenomenally good, barring some performance problems I've had. The story is incredible, along with the characters. It has by far some of the best writing in an RPG I've ever seen and despite having a massive wealth of content to explore (a lot of my hours were spent wandering the countryside or sailing in Skellige) none of it ever feels half-♥♥♥♥♥. It takes everything that was solid about the first two Witcher games and expands and improves on it. It also is not a bad place to jump into the series, since the plot is mostly self contained, with stuff from the previous games being mostly references and in-jokes. Another big positive is that many of many negatives that I was going to bring up have been fixed recently with the current patch, making the inventory and general movement (running/riding/swimming) far superior to how they were at launch. It's clear CD Projekt Red is dedicated to listening to feedback and making improvements.   The only negatives I can list now are the aforementioned performance problems. The game crashed probably 10-15 times in my entire run-through to desktop, sort of freezing in the background. Audio would continue, but if I tried to get back into the game, the process would end. There was a point a couple of weeks back, as well, where I would crash this way every single time I reached a certain point in the main storyline, barring my progress, though a patch fixed that issue. More recently, in the final stretch of the game, I had two HARD PC crashes which forced a reboot. I fixed this by fiddling with some Windows settings (based on a huge thread I read about ths issue) and managed to finish the game no problem. Regardless, when the game doesn't crash, it runs incredibly solidly framerate-wise on my 970 on maximum settings. I just need to note the crashing because I'm not the only one it affected.   All in all, this game is probably gonna be sitting on a list of my favorite games to come out this year. It was a hell of a ride.

You're on steam. You're on the Witcher 3 Store page about to click Add to Cart. DO IT!!! DO IT! DO IT!!   To put words to the beauty within this work of art is nigh impossible but I will give it a go anyway.  The Witcher 3 is the last leg in the story of our very near and dear White Wolf. The realm is in utter chaos. War is no more in the distance. It is the way of life for the common folk. Amidst this chaos our hero must risk all to fulfill his fate which is forever intertwined with that of his long lost love. You can guess who that is.  An open world which challenges the likes of Skyrim and Dragon Age Inquisition but having the flaws of neither. One of the most pleasant surprises was once you know a potion you don't have to keep brewing it again and again and again. It had become tedious and annoying in Dragon Age Inquisition but it is not so with Witcher 3.   The UI is quite superior to Witcher 3 and very interconnected and fluid. Shortcuts for EVERYTHING which is brilliant!  The gameplay is just fantastic! The running around and fighting has not changed much but the subtle platforming built into the game makes it so much more believable and fun! And Geralt can jump! Woohoo! No more 'Press E to climb'.  The animations are well done. Every subtle detail has been paid so much attention. CD Projekt Red ARE a bunch of perfectionists!  And the GRAPHICS...Oh My God! When it's dusk in-game...all i want to do is walk into the sunlight wafting through the tree leaves!! And thts just the tip of the iceberg!  The story is something filmmakers could learn from but having said that the game is based on the books so there's that.  Overall, the devs have outdone themselves! My only trepidation is that this is the end of the trilogy :( although i have yet to even get 1/4th thru the game after having played nearly 20 hours.   Oh also...be ready to sacrifice whatever little social life you had.   PS: The beard grows. The beard freakin grows!

About the story, it's sometimes intresting, sometimes funny, sometimes dramatic, everyone can find something for himself. Anyways let's talk about minuses of the game. First one and the most annoying for me, game itself is designed for consoles. You can play with keyboard and a mouse without bigger problems but while riding a horse, dodgeing or even attacking you'll feel that it's most comfortable to use a controler. There was only one bug that forced me to reload the save and It was an enemy stuck in the wall.  Now the final verdict is: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is close to be a master piece, it has wonderful graphics, intresting story, great humor implemented and very good combat system. I would surely reccommend you to buy the game, complete the story, start the new game + what is a great free DLC btw. and focus on exploring, side quests and leave the great main story for the end. Totally worth it. Ive seen people complaining about the combat, but I really think that is because they are used to overly simplified combat systems from Assasins Creed, Shadow of Mordor, and the Arkham series. I suggest playing the game on a harder difficulty, the combat once you understand it can be smooth and precise. In group fights you can plan out your swings and rolls properly, along with sign spells to give some strategic results. It’s a good game. You should play it.  All right, I can talk a bit more about it than that.   I’ve played 160 hours of it as the time of this writing and completed the main quest, all sidequests, and Hearts of Stone. I’m a late comer when comes to the Witcher series, only really pushing myself to explore the games this year (2016) starting with the first one, then second and finally Witcher 3.  I see why so many give this game such high praise. It looks beautiful, plays amazingly well, a moving soundtrack, and a story that builds in epicness as you continue on. It’s a special high note coming right off the previous games where I was familiar with the already present characters and the world and how it all comes together here.  In case you can’t tell, you play as Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher. You serve the role as a monster slayer for hire utilizing your various skills of combat, alchemy, and investigation. Thankfully there is more to it than just running around hacking at opponents as in some games. Being careless in this game will just make things harder and result in death. The game rewards you for acting smart and investing the time to being prepared and knowing your opponent, whether beast or man. This keeps the gameplay engaging and prevents the staleness of repetitive boring quests. Find the right info and you can effect the outcome of many a contract in the game, for better or worse.  Combat wise, the Witcher 3 feels like a tweaked version of what was implemented in the Witcher 2. It’s still action RPG, but the combat has been smoothed out a bit to reflect the open world nature. Combat will be a mixture of fast/strong attacks with parry/counters and dodging/rolls. Gone are the unnecessary prep times for potions and oils as you can just use/apply them when needed and just focus on the combat at hand. Throwing knives have been removed, but now replaced with a crossbow weapon. You still have a plethora of bombs and I find them much useful now than in the previous game.  Speaking of open world, it is, but not quite like Skyrim or Fallout. Instead you have open world “regions” spanning the world of the Witcher. You’ll spend most of the game in the Velen/Novigrad area which is the largest, but other areas such as Skellige, Kaer Morhen, White Orchid, and Toussaint (Blood and Wine DLC) will still provide a huge amount of time exploring. All in all, it’s a lot of land area (and sea) to explore and it’s all filled with things to discover (ala like the map in GTA V). Thankfully you have a horse for quicker land travel and can use boats for water travel. Oh, and you can fast travel, but only between set, discovered markers.  Like many open world games, there are… distractions. From horse racing, fist fighting, crafting, romance quests to ever popular Gwent. Gwent is vastly superior to the (IMO) broken dice poker from the previous games and I’m so happy CDPR replaced it with this. Fist fighting is back as usual, but it’s changed up to be more combat like. I guess it was too easy before, but now it feels too hard and gets ridiculously difficult towards the end of the fighting quests.   Besides that, the graphics of this game look phenomenal. This is a game worth investing in a good GPU for. Just look at any screen grabs to get an idea of this game. Yes, it’s that good, and for those who run this game at 4K on a large monitor, consider me envious. The game is filled to the brim with cutscenes, hope you like that, but only a few are pre-rendered (You can usually tell which ones).   Sound quality is again excellent. I praised the Witcher 2 for its excellent use of surround effects and the same holds true for the Witcher 3. SFX and voices are varied and distinct and have direction. Voice acting is pretty good for the most part, but admittedly at times I do get a bit bored of hearing British accents constantly. The music for the game is very well done and fitting. It just works. I especially liked the BGM of Skellige while exploring.   Game sounds perfect doesn’t it? Well… No game is perfect.  As with any huge open world game, there are some bugs and glitches here and there and I came across my share while playing. Ranging from minor graphical/animation bugs which were quite amusing to a couple game-breaking ones (One of which I lost about 2 hours of progress to). Sudden game crashes started to become more common once I got beyond the 100-hour mark, often times in the middle of cutscenes. The horse, Roach has a tendency to stall out on bridges, much to my annoyance during races. The in-game option of enemy up-scaling (while an excellent idea) will glitch out certain quests making them impossible to complete (of course you can just turn it off, but I feel like these issues should have been caught by CDPR in play testing).  On a negative, I would say I’m not a fan of the randomized leveled loot system in the Witcher 3. 90% of the time you will find equipment that is either inferior (because you can often craft things much better) or find a random crafting diagram for something you can make but can’t use (since you can only equip items equal to or less than your level). It’s system that doesn’t make much sense to me as most of things you will find are not useful or appropriate to your level. If only that “up-scaling” system was applied to equipment finds, hmm. As result, much of the early game feels RNG dependent on whether you will find good, usable gear and crafting recipes. The latter portions of the game don’t suffer from this so much. Some better consistency on this would have been nice.  So what do I give this at the end of it all?  9/10   This is pretty close to perfection here. Ignoring and forgiving some glitches, there were some gameplay elements I didn’t care for, but the story, graphics, sense of epicness and gameplay make this one the best RPG games ever made. CDPR has come a long way since the Witcher 1 and it’s been fascinating to see and experience the progression of this series. I look forward to what they have in the future.

Solid game. 18 hours in, playing one level above normal for difficulty, has the perfect amount of challenge/reward payout for my taste. I'll start off by listing my PC specs  I5 3570k CPU GTX 660 TI 3GB 16GB Ram  So as you can see, my video card is the min requirement, though being the 3GB TI it has more juice then the recommended card for the game. That being said I run everything on Medium or better, and it holds 50 FPS throughout the game. Theres a minor degree of texture 'pop in' when in the largest of cities, but nothing unacceptable. Helps to have the proper graphics driver and installing the game on your SSD is recommended.   Combat: Feel its improved alot since Witcher 2, many of the annoying aspects of the 2nd game are gone in this case, virtually no complaints in this category. I feel i use potions/signs/bombs a lot more this time around instead of relying on the swords.  World: Lush and full, has great atmosphere and you buy the situation your in. Through out the land are various areas to explore and clear, these are kind of like little 'instances', but every few you run into something that stands out from the rest, giving it a memorable feel (where as in games like the Elderscrolls, alot of the areas you explore are cool but never really leave that lasting impression)  Horse: Your mount in this game controls better then virtually anything else I've played. Vastly superior to Dragons Age or Skyrim, it actually feels like your riding an animal for once. 10/10, would ride Roach again. Oh and theres mounted combat, which takes a bit of practice but is pretty enjoyable. *protip, use igni to dismount other riders and quick attack them while they are prone, Geralt will put his sword through them for a 1 hit kill :D  Story/Character: Story so far is interesting enough to keep you involved. Everything is voice acted, and done well. I like Geralts personality more this time around, some good changes.  All in all, postitive expirence so far, I've crashed 3 times in 18 hours, all 3 times were when accessing the inventory after playing for 3-4 hours straight, never lost any real progress due to the autosave.   Was a worthy preorder....and interestingly enough I was one of those folks that picked up Witcher 2 the un-legit way, and while i beat 75% of it and liked it, I never would of paid cash for it, but because of that expirence, I looked into Witcher 3, paid full price and have been enjoying it. And they say nothing good comes from Piracy.

Finally a game that truly deserves the title 'Game of The Year'. One of the absolute best stories of all time. The Witcher 3 truely shines when you compare it to it's predecessors, a large open world, packed with content... The game is not without it's flaws though. For me, once I got to Skellige (Which is about fifty hours in) I was burnt out on all the quests and stopped playing for a month or two, and just wanted to finish the game,. I'll give the game credit though, the main missions and side quests are interesting but after doing so many it gets just a wee bit tedious, especially when your in Skellige, the parts when your sailing in your boat for five minutes to do one quest on the other side of the isles is boring as heck.   But I'm listing mostly cons. Here are some pros about the game.   + Runs amazing on my system on almost all Ultra, system specs 8320 and a 270X +Lots of Content +Interesting characters +The world itself is beautiful +The music, oh the music! It's fantastic, the gwent music is my favorite, just whistling along is a blast. +Gwent! I'd bet at least four hours of my game time are just playing that card game! Want to get a couple decks in real life and play. It's that fun. +The game has lots of choices to make. +Story is complex, deep and interesting, I recommend once you beat the game read up the entire thing on the Witcher Wikia.   Guess I'll list some cons.  -Combat. This was one I debated whether it was a pro, or a con. It's alright but once you get to higher levels it really amounts to just smashing your way through ♥♥♥♥. -  Armor designs; I still haven't found an armor other than the one you start with that I actually like (Got a mod so the other witcher sets will use it's model.). Wolf armor came close. Witcher 2 had the best armor designs of the series, in my opinion.   A friend showed me what some of the armors look like after upgrading, some look pretty dope so this is taken off. -Roach. Oh my God, Roach. He is such a pain in the ♥♥♥ to control. He will randomly stop while your sprinting as though there is a fence or something in the way, turning is weird, hard to explain until you actually control him around. -Actually movement in general is kind of finicky.    Now, the story. I can't list it under pro or con. It's a good story, but feels somewhat cobbled together, Ciri drops in from nowhere no mention of her prior, same with Yen, but I think she was mentioned one time in Witcher 2 in one of those flashback scences with Geralt. Maybe it was done on purpose, but it confused me. I got lost lots of times in the story due to the game always throwing around new names, but Geralt knew who these people were. It feels as though I missed some piece of story.   Story is complex, and after reading up some, it is hella well done.  Now, before this game came out there was this huge controversy about the graphics. The game is still awesome-looking even if it doesn't have 4k Ultra HD textures, people! Very mis-placed arugument, and I've even heard of some people passing this game up purely for that! Crazy! Game still looks amazing.  To sum it up, The Witcher 3 is an amazing game, one of the best RPGs I've played even with all the gripes I have with it. The Witcher series has definitely earned its place on my mantle of favorite series. Good work, CD Projekt Red.

Finally, after several months, and nearly a hundred hours of gameplay, I’ve completed the main quest of the Witcher 3. This is an incredible Open World Role Playing Game that everyone should experience. People who see my steam library can see how hard it is for me to focus on a game and finish it since most games I’ve played only have 1-3 hours of playtime before I get bored/distracted, but Witcher 3 was a beautiful delight to play through.  And what a journey it’s been. This is one of the most memorable RPGs I’ve ever played. I enjoyed the Witcher 2’s intrigue heavy plot, and found Witcher 1’s gameplay much too obtuse for me to get into, but from what I’ve read, Witcher 3 marries both the gameplay refinements of the second game with the open world, epic nature of the first and polishes everything to a near perfect mirror sheen. CD Project Red has absolutely gone all out for this game. The effort that went into creating such a stunning world is prevalent throughout. It took 2.5 years and over 950 characters were voiced in the game total. The game’s presentation show off the most convincing European fantasy world I’ve ever seen virtually created, with lush hillsides, dark forests, snowy mountain tops all rendered in crisp fidelity. The impeccable audio design covers everything from subtle birds chirping, wind howling, and silent sobbing from villagers whose lives were utterly destroyed from the conflict the world takes place in. Great soundtrack too.   The game’s plot follows pretty directly from the first two games, but still does a decent job of easing new players into the experience. I still feel like you get a lot more out of the game if you at least play the previous ones, something I didn’t do only because Witcher 1 was so rough to try to enjoy. The setting and characters are based off of the works of Andrzej Sapkowski, whose writing creates a backdrop to the game but doesn’t have much to do with the events that take place. Hardcore fans say it is nearly essential to read the books, and I plan to eventually because of how much I love the setting. However, despite this, the game starts off with Geralt on a relatively simple quest. Find Yennefer, and through her, find Ciri. Throughout these main quests you’ll meet an assortment of deep, complex characters both old and new, so having played previous games/ reading the books will help you understand just what the hell is going on. Geralt is a well known character in the world as the Butcher of Blaviken, so most characters already know quite a bit about you. This is helpful to new players who want to learn more about the history of the world, but the amount of exposition and info dump is still overwhelming. Geralt is a character, so unlike Skyrim/ Fallout where you get more of a blank slate to work with, he is already actively partaking in the world, and will only react/ respond to situations in a way that stays in character. You’re not roleplaying as yourself, you’re roleplaying as Geralt. I see some negative reviews are upset that they are stuck with what they find a gruff, boring grey haired old man, but I really think that sticking to a pre-created character allows the writers to give him real depth and make his relationships with other characters feel real and meaningful. In Fallout you could help a village fend off a mutant attack, but instantly turn around, shoot every villager in the face and take all of their stuff. As enjoyable as this level of freedom is, it ends of feeling quite disjointed, creating a dissonance between gameplay and plot. This is avoided by letting you roleplay as Geralt instead of creating your own character.  Just because you’re playing as Geralt doesn’t mean you don’t have choices. The choices in the Witcher 3 are far reaching and impactful, more so than in any other Witcher game. Important characters can and will die, and decisions you make will impact entire cultures/ communities. It’s as if CD Project Red, seeing this is the last game, decided, “♥♥♥♥ it” and let decisions play out with terminal, and final consequences. There are many plot lines and stories buried in this game, but one of the few criticisms I have is that not everything is neatly resolved in the end. I understand that a hulking behemoth of storytelling of this size would find it impossible to tie up every loose end, and the game ends open-ended enough (depending on your ending) to make it feel things could still continue, but it would’ve been nice to have a few more definite resolutions. Regardless, I still found the Witcher 3’s storyline to be the most memorable aspect of its design. I don’t know how the developers manage to weave cinematic storytelling, deep conversations with NPCs, and quest design into a game that makes it feel as if everything truly mattered. I found myself doing quests on the side not for money/ experience, or anything other than to get the chance to meet a few more characters and make a few more decisions. It’s really incredible how well the side quests are designed.  The best quest design in the world wouldn’t mean anything if the game wasn’t enjoyable to play. The basic gameplay from the Witcher 2 of “dodge, dodge, attack, dodge” is still here, but refined to feel smoother and less frustrating. Geralt slowly strafes delicately around opponents now instead of running awkwardly, and has multiple forms of evasion that help you control his movements. The potion/ bomb making systems are streamlined, and as a result I found myself using them much, much more. In the Witcher 2 I almost never used any potions/ bombs, but since I always had them on hand in a battle I used every weapon at my disposal constantly. You’ll have to use everything you can to survive, especially near the beginning when everything can kill you very quickly. Dodging, striking, and throwing bombs/ using potions and oils are a staple of being a Witcher, and I finally feel as if I am playing as a professional monster slayer, truly a “Whirlwind of Rage and Steel.” The animations are also perfect as well, showing a graceful, swirling fighting style that perfect encapsulates what the books describe as a Witcher’s fighting style. Later on in the game, everything becomes a lot easier as both your abilities evolve and you, yourself get better at playing the game, but leveling throughout is an enjoyable experience. By the end, you’ll truly feel like the seasoned veteran Geralt is.  The characterization of Geralt is something to praise. For much of the game I found myself pitifully poor, a far cry from the multi millionaire I found myself to be in other RPGs. I could barely afford to buy ingredients for crafting/ potion creation or even repair my weapons. I grumbled as I lost all of fifty gold in a Gwent game. I found myself taking on monster contract after monster contract just to get some money in the bank. I realized later that this design was intentional, as Geralt is essentially some kind of a supernatural hobo monster slayer. I’m supposed to feel dirty and raggedy and poor, something that other characters remark on as well. This brings a real connection in the gameplay to the storyline, as I’m constantly in need of money, making my side excursions make sense. It always bugged me that in certain game storylines there is some horrible world ending event about to occur, the main character finds the time to do side quests when Armageddon is imminent. Geralt does the same thing here, but at least there’s context.   The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a beautiful, expansive RPG with a deep storyline and satisfying gameplay. I’m sad to see this series come to an end, but I have yet to play through the Expansion content, which I am still itching to do. I’m beyond excited for CD Project Red’s Cyberpunk 2077, but for now, I’m so happy that this glorious series has such a great send off. The Witcher 3 is, for all intents and purposes, a must-play.

One of the best singleplayer games ever, imo.  Comparing the Witcher series, this is vastly superior to it's predecessors by basically everything. After playing this, I don't even imagine what would it take to make a better RPG than this one. I wish I could delete my memory just to play it again.    PROS:   - VAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAST open world to explore. It's massive. It's not filled with dull stuff. There are caves, cliffs, forests, mountains, castles, lighthouses, etc... And everything I mentioned is filled with loot, which is not easily accessible because of the enemies (there are tons of them too, all different and unique) and that makes the game fun. All in all, the sandbox in this game is insane.  - The story really immerses you into the game. You can choose what to say in most of the dialogues. You can ask non-quest related questions to most unique NPCs.  - Fighting is a bit hard to get used to, if you never played Witcher games - it involves lots of dodging, parrying, blocking - but you can easily learn to get used to it.  - Each NPC is unique. Everyone has their own personality, they scale from mean, old men and women who don't want to even hear the smallest word from you to lying two-faced ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to good, honest and friendly characters.  - You can decide Geralt's (main character's) fate. And not only his. His friends', the factions', which are at war with each other and even choose between romances. I've never seen that much choices from any other games.  - Graphics are fantastic, IF you can allow yourself a good computer. Every small detail is textured, the grass, bushes, trees move in the flow of the wind.  - The weather changing system really impressed me. You have storms, blizzards, rain which look absolutely wonderful and then sunsets and sunrises which look really colorful and are calm, relaxing.  - The soundtrack. Holy crap. It fits soooo well. There are different soundtracks for everything and they fit so god damn well. Although, sometimes they are a bit buggy (for instance 2 tracks at once), but it doesn't matter, it doesn't happen often.  - Tons of perks. Sword-fighting, alchemy, signs (magic), and you can respec all of them if you made a wrong choice somewhere.    CONS:    There isn't much bad things in this game, actually. But here's a few.  - Moving feels strange if you're playing for the first time. It's not as free as Skyrim, where you can basically climb 90 degree mountains. You can get blocked by a really small obstacle, but it's not as annoying as in other games.  - Horses. These sons of b*tches ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off really much. Sometimes you can run in a small obstacle which any other in-game horse would basically walk or if it's a bit bigger, just jump over, but oh booooooooooy, not in this game. Quite often I had a problem where you start running with the horse and then, in quite small areas, they would go off the road. And no, those roads were not made just to walk on foot, they are big enough for horses to go through, but they just don't. Or maybe I'm just really used to Skyrim's horses, I don't know.  - As much as deciding Geralt's fate is a really good thing, but I really got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off when I got the worst possible ending just because I was playing it logically and safe. Like for instance, *SPOLER*    where Ciri seems like just begging for you to go with her to the sorceress meeting in Dandelion's place and you go with her. And then, at the end of the game, you learn that it was a bad choice. WTF?    Well then, I'm off for another playthrough for the best ending.  Overall, I would rate 10/10 for sure. Soooo much content for a price like that. It's 100% worth it.

Top 3 games of all time. It has its flaws - a lack of real story presence, clanky controls... but the masterwork done in this game makes up for all of that. Each little sidequest is like its own campaign. There's just so much to do and see. I blazed through the story only doing a few side quests and the card game and look at my playtime.   The Witcher 3 defines a new era of RPGs: One where the world truly is complete, nothing is missing, and each character, no matter how small, feels real. Very rarely (only near the end) did I feel like I was doing a quest that was pointless or boring. The game stayed fresh no matter how long I played nonstop.   There's so much depth to the game that even after 40+ hours I barely scratched the surface. I played on some easier difficulties because I had more fun just experiencing the game, so the more intricate parts of the character customization and combat flew over my head. (Yes, the game is that versatile. Any playstyle can have fun with it.) But there's also a HUGE database in the game of every character and monster you ever come across in the game. When the lore gets confusing (and it does), a quick peek at that to remind yourself fixes yourself back up.  Nobody can truly call themself a gamer if they haven't played this game. As an extremely critical and pessimistic video game player, I give this a 10/10.

To begin I have played about 2 hours while I am rrighting this review, I will have more in the future. Now to the actual review. Its a very fun and beautiful game. For being out a whole year now and it still stands up with some of the most visually stunning games like Far Cry 4 and And the new Hitman game. The fighting mechanics are really easy to pick up and the spells are suprisingly easy to use on PC even. I would not say that this is a game made for PC like Half Life for example but it is a very good port as far as some games go. I really enjoy the slow down effect when you go into the quick access menu to change spells and even then you have the spells bound to the keys at the top. The combat is very fluent and it doesn't break the flow when you use spells or the crossbow in the game. The voice acting is very professionally done and sounds amazing. Speaking of amazing, the soundtrack is very good and not as forgettable as some of todays video game soundtracks. Some of the gripes I have with this game might just be with my game but I might as well say them. I personally have has some troubles with the game starting up occasionally, there have been some random crashes here and there but nothing to be alarmed about if you are thinking about buying this game, and personally I have had troubles with mods among other things but if you are planning on not playing with mods that it shouldn't be much of a problem. Aside from that and from what I have played, I believe that this game gives RPG's a good name. I would whole heartedly suggest this game to anyone with or without a PC and enjoys RPG games. Solid 9-9.5/10.

Without a shadow of a doubt... one of my favorite games ive EVER played in my 32 years on this earth... my tastes range from Stealth games like Metal Gear Solid, Assassins Creed, Hitman, too MMORPGs such as Warcraft, Star Wars Old Republic and of course the granddaddy of em all Everquest, too Moba's such as League of Legends/Dota2, too FPS like Borderlands and even Simulators... but RPGs have always been my favorite... i enjoyed the first witcher, loved the second witcher... but this one is hands down my favorite... this game will be in the top of my favorites list until the day i die.. i consider it an HONOR that i bought it at full price. i can only hope the Developers make a Witcher 4, even though they said they wouldn't... but i can dream.

I honestly don't know where to start, other than by saying this might just be the best RPG for years to come. I guess I can start with some basic points     Story easily picked up by new players and continues for returning fans, one so enveloping I - a serious cutscene skipper - was drawn in to watch   everything       One of the best soundtracks I have EVER heard in my entire life, music is a huge thing for me and this nails every single moment.     The world is massive and absolutely gorgeous, through several playthroughs I hardly ever used the fast-travel system     There is SO much content in this game it is mindblowing. Along side the main story, there are hundreds (no exaggeration) of sidequests including storylines with branching paths and multiple endings to nearly all of them, witcher contracts pitting Geralt against a huge variety of unrelenting beasts, and treasure hunts to delve into caves to find some extremely worth-while loot. Its all there, available to do as much or as little as you please.     Every character you come across in the main story is actually memorable - including Geralt himself (Zoltan is the best character you'll ever meet, so make sure to do every quest he offers and you won't regret it)     Mother♥♥♥♥ing Gwent, 196 cards in the game for you to purchase, win and find, THEN play with. It literally is a whole game inside a game.     The difficulty settings range from beginner at RPGs as a whole to absolutely ruthless sadism. On the lowest difficulty you can get through without much thought, but as it increases you need to seriously think about every stat, attribute allocation, potion making, armour and weapons being in top condition. Think you're good at RPGs? Try Deathmarch and watch your ♥♥♥♥ get handed to you.   Overall, this game really couldn't be better in my opinion. The base game is incredible and the DLC packs (Hearts of Stone, Blood and Wine) are both shockingly good additions, they are prime examples of how DLC SHOULD be done. This is my personal choice for GOTY in 2015, and DLC of the year in 2016 (B&W)    10/10 - a serious must-buy, even at full price.    I'll also take this opportunity to personally congratulate CD Projekt Red on leaving a mark in gaming history, because they truly have created something here that is worth everyone's attention, new players and veterans alike.  Oh, and remember;       Steel for humans, silver for monsters.

The game made me laugh, cry and feel for the caracters close to Gerald like no many others did in 15 years of gaming for me.

So far so good! Even my PC has some specs lower than the minimum recommended, still it runs smoothly on average good settings. It lives up to the hype! I will elaborate as I go deeper in the game.  --EDIT: Well well, now I am 100+ hour into this magnificent piece of software art. I would not waste my time trying to compare it to other franchises like Elder Scrolls, instead treat it as what it is... an excellent game with a lot of innovation and improvement over their past versions.  I am not used to write much about reviews and I will not extend on this one either.  Summarizing my experience so far:  Side quests are compelling and interesting, hardly you have the usual kill X and fetch Y formula of old. Contracts which one could think are repetitive, are crafted to be creative and have their own charm. If real life is itself repetive, that aspect of a monster hunter would be pretty similar. Yet TW3 makes it in a way you can enjoy it. Treasure Hunts are truly rewarding, although their missions would be the most repetive of all, the rewards are very very rewarding and it is worth all the hassle. Nothing like enjoying the cutscenes with Geralt in full Mastercrafted Griffin Gear.  Main story is brilliant, its not about saving the world, it about protecting the loved ones. Of course in that path you will change the world in many many ways, and your decisions will influece the many outcomes.  I cant really talk much about the graphics and I will not even step in the dowgrade, as per my machine specs I could not run the game past medium and high settings so I do not fret about it, yet I loved the art and detail and I really enjoyed the multi region open world of the game and the hard work on cutscenes.  Speaking of Gear, the crafting systems are very nice, gone is the grinding of leveling your craft formula of other games, its all about finding and collecting diagrams and formulae to craf the stuff you need, which usually will be given as you need it and progress deep in the game.  Combat although somewhat clunky, it is enjoyable, still has space for improvement, it was not a blocker to enjoy it. Although a wider variety of weapons and fight styles would not hurt in the future.  Horses: Races are fun and it might require some strategy to win, its not only about sprinting from start to end to win a race. About Horses, horse riding is very well done, very realistic. Combat is the best mount combat of a game of this kind.  To conclude: An excellent, must have game. By far the best RPG I have played in the past 4 years :D Totally recommed it. Far from perfect, still is a incredible crowning achievement! ;)

After awaiting this game for so long I am really stunned from its greatness. The open world that CD Projekt has offered us is amaizing. From the nature to the living of villages or cities, they have succeeded. They have improved their fighting system and the use of signs is much more fluid.  There is much more RPG feeling in this game than the two previous ones. Its crafting system is really good and full of possibilities. You have to get used to it though...   It's the kind of game where you like to hang out in the nature and discover everything that surrounds you. Every corner of the map has its magic and surprises. So you don't get bored!  This game is for you if: - you like discovering, riding at full speed through forests, huge fields with your horse  - you like fighting like a badass and cut some heads  - you like crafting things with the stuff you gathered while on the move and personnalize your character with amour and weapons. - you like to immerse yourself in a great stories with great characters - you liked skyrim - ...  Pros: - Huge map to discover. - Epic fighting system, - Great RPG aspects - Great graphics (You need a good Graphics card to run it fluidly in ultra) - Great story (until now / 6 hours) - All characters are charismatic and everyone has a role in the world. - Every decision you take has an impact in your progression... be aware ;)  Cons: - Movement and fighting quite difficult at the beginning - Some graphical and collision issues (will be fixed in the futur) - euh...=)

Easily one of the best Action RPGs available, possibly one of the best action RPGs ever made. To say anything about the story would be to spoil, so I'll suffice with some advice to new users to help them get through the, admittedly rough, opening levels:  1) If you're dieing a lot, spec into the second teir battle trance ability. It gives you a, for all intents and purposes, full heal if you're hit with 1 adrenaline point. This makes drowner manageable until your gear and skills get good enough to compensate.   2) Potions, oils, and bombs automatically refill after every meditation, and only cost a single Alcohlest. Build potions and oils ASAP.  3) 90% of the fights in the game will be won depending on how well you use the combat DODGE rather than the combat ROLL. Bind the Combat Dodge (The 'Hop') to an easy key and learn how to use it fast.   4) Live your laifu for your waifu. You know which one.

The Witcher 3 is the Greatest RPG (action?) ever made.   I'm 38 and have been playing games since Baldur's Gate. Baldur's 1 and 2 are still milestones don't get me wrong and Pillars of Eternity. My main computer died I think MB so I turned to the GF's comp to get my fix. Needless to say I am amazed at the coding and graphics structure of this game. The optimization is 2nd to none. It will take a LONG time to finish. DL it and make it your mainstay/bootiecall.

This isn't a 10/10 perfect game (IMO) like everyone seems to be making it out to be. It does have a lot of issues. While still a fun game that I would recommend, I felt like it had glaring issues that held back what would've otherwise definitely been one of my top 5 games of all time. They made a game that would be worth going back to each year for memorable battles and quests into something that doesn't quite satiate my fantasy open world rpg taste buds.  The combat, graphics, and characters are all awesome. Everyone knows this. I want soley talk about the parts people leave out or don’t talk about, at least not in these steam reviews.  The issues I have with the rest of the game undermine these. One of the biggest downfalls I found came with the pacing and quest load. I constantly felt overwhelmed. For every main quest I received, 25 side quests came along with it. I know that you are able to ignore these and do them as you please, but completing main quests mean that you are severely over-leveled when you come back to sidequests, even with enemy upscaling on and difficulty turned up. Characters you met are forgotten about, and I have no clue where they came into the story at or why they are there. Of course, a massive log of characters and beasts helps keep records of these persons in tact, but does detract from the immersion of the missions. If you focus on side missions, I feel like story becomes more irrelevant and less frantic than the game suggests it should be. Again, if you aren't a Witcher fanatic, or you don't have time to play for more than an hour a day, characters and stories are lost and confused. Some people may have no issue with this, I just felt bombarded and overwhelmed all at once. Before I had even completed a single story mission in a new land, I felt like I had inadvertently picked up every side quest and met every towns person that needed help.  Monster contracts, the aspect I was most excited for coming into this game, are underwhelming and forgettable. Again, before you know it, 10 different people want 10 different monsters slain. In my 65 hours played, almost every contract felt exactly the same, leaving few fights to feel unique and memorable. They all begin with you being approached by a peasant, or picking up a contract on a notice board, that then lead you to be told about a monster that is terrorizing a location. You then gather clues by asking around town or using your witcher senses to find tracks or scents at a scene. Following these tracks leads to you discover a monster that you then fight, after optionally choosing to gear up with different potions and oils (that I never onced use because of how powerful you already are) that are specifically more effective against certain types of monsters. This formula works, and while it does get a little stale, it was really the most logical option to have players begin a contract. A couple of them were alright, specifically the wyverns/forktails and the chorts (basically the big monsters). A lot of them, however, are common small enemies that you see and fight in the wild. A single water hag? Really? Maybe it was just me, but I was under the impression that side quests and monster contracts were separate to allow us to isolate ourselves from everyday scum of The Northern Realms and surround ourselves with unique epic battles against deadly beasts. A good chuck of these contracts would have been better served as regular side quests. At the end of each contract (remember, your main job as a witcher is to accept contracts and kill monsters), you receive a trophy of the monster you kill, and usually a weapon. The weapon is complete trash 90 percent of the time. The trophy (the monsters head) that grants you a small percent increase to either experience gained, gold find, sign damage, etc…) are all the same and barely vary. Larger more difficult “rare” beasts don't differ enough from a trophy you will get from a regular enemy to even justify the time. And because I was already overleveled, the experience doesn't feel worth it, the gold isn't important (as there is nothing to buy because crafting is the only way to get best items), and I come away feeling underwhelmed. The only solace you have is the memory of discovering and fighting an epic beast that the townspeople hyped up, and for me, it didn't quite happen.  Crafting is simple, clean, and enjoyable. However, it's for the most part unnecessary. You find or are rewarded diagrams that you can then take to a craftsman to have crafted. Most of the diagrams you find are for low level trash gear that you will never ever assemble or even think of wearing. At 65 hours in, one chest piece I crafted carried me at least 30 hours. I didn't get an upgrade until I crafted a piece that was only unavailable because I didn't meet the level requirement, not because I didn't have necessary funds or materials.  To sum it up, these are handful of my biggest issues with the game. They by no means make the game unplayable, unbearable, or un-enjoyable. I just think things could be tweaked to simply make the game as good as people give it credit for. They have, in my opinion, the perfect template to make what could be my favorite game ever. A great fantasy setting with the size and stature to create a memorable epic that would go down in history with games like Red Dead Redemption and Bioshock. It just doesn't quite hit the mark with me.

This game needs no more praises.  CD Projekt Red improved with every game to release this Witcher Gameplay. For waht this game gives you any other company would have wanted atleast 30% more on its price.  To new players, the story is part of a trilogy, so it is tides up to the other 2 games. You do not have to play it to enjoy it but to get the full experiance and satisfaction of the rich story you need to. (They are also very good).  Every little quest is fully voiced and unique. Yes, it may still be to kill the same looking monster, or even the same type of monster, but the dialog is not repeated (or even if it is because it is extreamly big game you won't notice).  The character progression is very well done. While creators don't like to see thier characters age and close to their end (not death, just potential), Gerald knows his place. He aged, he changed, he leads his persona to a conclution down the road. This is a great example of a strong protagonist and gread build of an adventure story.  If your open world and very lively acting NPCs, great story, fantastic romantic dilemas, stunning graphics and music is not enough, well we have a mini-game in as well. Gwent, the cute card collecting game, does is job well. While it does not have one of the strongest concepts and it baffles me how it can go solo, it strives to be original. You are not forced to play it, to win it, or even to punish you for missing that one card in the storyline that you will never ever get back, just because you did not loot eveyr single crate.

I was very skeptical of purchasing this game as I really didn't enjoy the combat system of the first two games.  The system is similar but it has seen a lot of improvement. It doesn't feel so unresponsive and slow like it was before. I'm not a huge fan of the magic system (it's very simplified and uncomplex) as it doesn't feel very epic or powerful. It's useful, but not flashy, and I like flashy magic.  I've got almost 120 hours in the game and I still haven't finished it. Never seen an ending, but I'm close.  When I look at my world map, at least half the points of interest are still undiscovered. I've done a GREAT DEAL of the side quests, but my quest log is still full to the brim with stuff to do. Overall, one of the best RPG's and best games in general I have ever played. An absolute masterpiece of creative digital art.  Good -Easily one of the best story lines I have ever played. The main game's story line is epic and will always keep you engaged. I would easily compare it to Skyrim in terms of epic scale of different quests and plots. While the Hearts of Stone Expansion quest feels like a very good side quest, the main game quest is the main show and the Blood and Wine storyline is a good final farewell and encore to the game. If you like fantasy, action, medieval battles, the Lord of the Rings, Warhammer, medieval monster stories, Game of Thrones, and old European folklore in general, you will sink your teeth into this game's story. Like a very good book, it will keep you engaged. In fact, I believe this is some of the best writing I have ever seen in a video game. The writing is better than many movies. -The game is utterly gorgeous. Much like an Elder Scrolls game, it is easy to get lost in the beauty of the game world. Velen provides a war torn ravaged land. White Orchard is a small farming community. The Skellige Isles are a tough, harsh, and ultimately beautiful snowy and maritime frontier. Novigrad is the ultimate fantasy Eastern European themed city. Toussaint is a beautiful fairy tale esque land akin to the French and Italian wine producing regions.  -The soundtrack for this game is epic. Like the entire feel of the game, it is rooted in old European folklore. Expect exceptionally varied tracks among all environments. You can expect bagpipes in Skellige and trumpets in Toussaint. -Combat is very well done. While not a simple button masher, it is still incredibly well balanced and can be picked up quickly yet rewards more experienced users. Arguably the best combat of the series. Especially considering the raw amount of foes you will be facing, the combat is never boring and never gets old.  -Overall, everything about this game is good to the point where it's better for me to jump into the bad, as they are the only negatives.  Bad -your ability to navigate terrain can seem chunky at times, especially when mounted on the horse. Overall, this is no where near a game breaking note. View this more as a simple heads up that you wont have as much freedom of movement as in say Skyrim. Seriously this is the only thing I can really think of as a bad.   Neutral -My biggest note of the game where I think things could have been changed is the leveling system. While not necessarily a bad thing, it's worth noting. While the game has many open world 'regions' it is still generally designed with the intention that a player follows a certain sequence of quests. In other words, some quests are locked at certain levels and some equipment is also locked until a certain level. While this provides for balanced gameplay throughout the experience, it is definitely a generally restrictive/micromanaging option compared to other open world RPG games. Skyrim for example automatically adjusts the level of all enemies and quests around the player, with more difficult enemies and quests just a tad bit higher than the others in relation to the player's skill. This keeps challenging missions challenging but allows a player to write their own story. However, it's not really a bad thing in the case of this game. While Skyrim lets you create your own player and write their story, the Witcher 3 is meant to have you writing Geralt's story.   Should you buy? -If you like action games, fantasy, monsters, melee combat games, and general top tier games (This is one of the most critically acclaimed games we have seen in a while - average score 9/10, with Gamespot giving a 10/10)... buy it. Period. -If you see it on sail, buy it. Period.

Ive been a witcher fan since the first game, i loved the very adult and believable world of the witcher where people are neither good or evil but shades of grey.  The witcher 3 pros Beautiful and believable world and people, even the ugly ones. Excellent voice acting. Interesting story ( so far ). Nice minigame. Horse autorun to targets. Big world.  The witcher 3 negatives. Combat and movement are unacceptably bad, really clunky, this for me is a game killer when the gameplay is so bad i stop playing and wait and hope for a patch. Walking into houses and ransacking while the AI owner standing right beside me says or does nothing. Stupid AI. Villagers speaking too much, they actually drown themselves out. Messy and confusing crafting and inventory. Geralt putting sword away in battle.  I love the world of the witcher and the witcher 3 is impressive and atmospheric, but it feels like the makers of witcher 3 spent all their time on graphics and story while not treating the actual gameplay of this game seriously enough, or maybe they just didn't have the skills.  Edit, ive played and practiced the clunky controls far more, i still stand by the statement that the controls are a bit clunky and geralt turns like a bus, but with practice you can somewhat compensate for it, and it becomes okay but could of been better affair. So i'm giving this a thumbs up now, mostly for the world and characters.

I think the decision to focus on a more free-roam approach was an interesting one- if not entirely necessary, it worked heavily in the game's favor. Able to see the events caused by actions taken in previous titles, and able to see the terrifying and grotesque world of The Witcher in its full glory, it indeed worked. Characters were incredible, voice acting was fantastic, facial movements were spot on, all-in-all, a brilliant experience. 59 hours on first playthrough, and I didn't even do everything I could have. I would say I am incredibly impressed, especially as someone who was, though excited for this title, skeptical, thus the hesitation.  If you like open world(-ish) RPGs with interesting, very adult-themed plotlines, do yourself a favor and play this game. Recommend you play the previous titles first, but even if you do not, this game does a pretty good job of standing on its own and making events of prior titles pretty clear.

TL;DR:[/h10 IMO, THE most immersive RPG game I have ever played. Looks really good, all the quests are unique, you almost never feel like you're just playing the same quest again with a different name. Most of all, it actually got me to FEEL something for its characters, who were really well developed throughout. It's an absolute masterpiece, at least I think it is. [h1]The Longer Bit[/h1] I honestly went into The Witcher 3 expecting the experience I got from Skyrim. A huge game with annoyingly repetitive quests and inspired not even the smallest ounce of emotion from me. In other words, a game that I would quickly get bored of and play only to pass time occasionally. Let me tell you this, I couldn't have been more wrong. The Witcher 3 was one of the very few games that actually made me feel something for the characters, made me actually grow attached to or despise certain characters. It's numerous sidequests, are possiblly to most well designed of all RPGs. Not because they're different to other games, but because they're different to eachother. Almost all sidequests have voiced cutscenes, an impact on the game and best of all, you don't go 'wait a second, isn't this the exact same as that other quest I did 10 minutes ago, but with a different name?'. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying it's flawless, the combat could have used a bit more work, the map/interactions too, but nothing that really got me instantly bored of the game. Also, a fair few of the sidequests are similar, obviously they can't make everything completely different, but what they have done is included small details and subtle additions to quests which, overall, make them feel completely different. One of my favourite things about the game is that you actually get to develop YOURSELF as a character. Most RPGs, I'm probably gonna keep using Skyrim for specific examples, dont really give you the feeling that you're developing as a character. For example with Skyrim, sure things you did affected the world as a whole and some people didn't like you anymore, but none of it really felt like it affected you. With The Witcher 3 it all actually feels like the choices you make affect yourself, the plot and what people think of you. You actually feel like your playing as a person in that world rather than some guy that can do whatever he wants and is really distanced from everything. Going on to specifics: Characters - Like I've mentioned they're really good, well developed and you actually feel like you have a specirfic relationship with them, regardless of what that relationship may be. You also feel like your character is an actual citizen of the world. Visuals - Really good as well, while you're running around you'll find awe-inspiring scenery evry step of the way. While individual detailing and whatnot is great, but not jaw-droppingly so, what really makes the graphics amazing is how smoothly it all fits together. Sound - There's not a huge variety of sounds, not that many games can boast this, but what's there is done really well in my opinion. Nothing too much I can say about this. Gameplay - Combat could have used a bit of work, and the map/ quest interactions too. It's quite easy to go about a quest wrong and as a result not be able to progress properly. Apart from this though, it all seems to flow pretty well. I'm sure I repeated myself quite a few times, but the point is, it stands out so much from similar games. It's just so immersive. Like I've said 3 times, I think, you ACTUALLY FEEL LIKE YOU'RE A PART OF THE WORLD. The things happening directly affect you! In the end though, this was just the impression I got. So if you ask me, it's easily worth the money you pay for it and, in my opinion, is the BEST (serious) RPG game out there, so far.

This game is incredibly good.  The story is interesting. You are basically on a search for a person, but you're not just 'going to where the person is' like other games would do it. You start off knowing literally nothing about that person whereabouts. Neither the character you play or you yourself know anything about it, which makes the story way mor interesting when you finally find a new lead. The story pulls you into the game, you really want to continue playing.  The only things i would consider bad, or poorly made is your equippment. Let me explain. You can use two swords. A steel sword for humans and animals and a silver sword for beasts.  Most silver swords look way, way too simmilar, but so do the steel swords. The inventory pictures have very little that makes the weapons destinguishable from eachother, so you have to hover over the weapons to find out which one is the better one. But not only that, when you have the swords equipped, there's nothing that shows you that you have the 'weaker' sword equipped, because they look almost the same.  Let's take Skyrim for example. In Skyrim, you have several different 'brands' of weapon: orcish, elven, dawnguard and so on. this makes the weapons VERY destinguishable. In The Witcher 3, you have only one brand per weapon type, which means that in total you only have two brans: Steel and Silver swords.  That's boring.  But if you can look past this small, but annoying flaw, the game itself is still fun.
