Disclaimer: I haveabout 150 unlogged hours on this game, as i played without internet during vacation  Massive gameworld, amazing side charachters, and visually stunning landscapes are coupled with epic quests, decent combat, puzzles and some amazing bossfights.  How would i describe this game? In a word, epic.  Too keep this short and sweet, let's get into pros and cons:  Pros: -Horse can autopilot (you have no idea how fun this is) -Fully fleshed out, consequential main quest: actions actually make impacts or change the way quests work -Main charachters all have personality and life in them -No 'fetch me this X times', 'kill X monsters' quests, making each quest feel unique -Gameworld of believable scale -No loading screens necessary unless you're changing between the 5 different main areas -Decent/ engaging tutorial -Some beautiful endings, epic and emotional -Graphics are very good, in almost all instances. -Caves look phenomenal -World really feels 3D with caves/dungeons connected to the main map without loading barriers -Interesting charachters -A few really engaging random encounters. -Decent bossfights -Amazing cinematics -Two controllable charachters -Witcher senses -You need to prepare potions and signs for each fight- really fun little feature -Random explosive barrels, beehives, and flammable gas swamp for bonus fun  Cons: -Clunky movement at times -Combat becomes very one dimensional at lower difficulty settings -Certain charachters dissapear after game end -Sometimes you never get to finish some quests on time, then don't recieve xp as a result of being overleveled -First ten levels are hard to come by, the rest are much easier -Finding components to craft swords or armor is very difficult -I completed the game without ever crafting witcher gear, as some very powerful gear can be more easily obtained by wandering the game world.  -Very difficult to get over level 40, simply no quests are your level anymore once you get this high -Nature can feel a bit rubbery sometimes -Portals don't have depth!!! -Some 'holes' in the game world can be seen sometimes -Crossbow feels like crap  Final verdict? Graphics: 10/10  -Not going to nitpick on the small stuff here, the game has a great feel and atmosphere due to its graphics Gameplay: 9.5/10 -Combat needs some work, as does movement, but overall very satisfying for an rpg Roleplaying: 11/10 -Will cheat on Yennefer again, the control freak lady better calm the f*** down when she's talking to me. I don't take orders! Atmosphere: 9/10 -Great landscapes, but some repetitive dialogoues, faces and actions can take away from the feel a bit.  Overall, 10/10, a mustbuy, musthave, mustplay. Seriously, this game topped any rpg I've ever played, and I've played quite a few.  Word of advice- don't finish main quest until you've done most of the other quests, because you'll be making jumps of two levels or more if you do, rendering the side quests way too easy. Finsishing main quest early makes the world feel very empty.   Anyway, time to finish all those quests i haven't done yet- that's easily another fifty hours!

This is hands down one of the best games I have ever played. I'm astounded at what CD Projekt has accomplished here. The game has the scope of something like Skyrim, but where that game's inhabitants are hollow and superficial, this game manages to populate its world with a cast of characters overflowing with personality. The most surprising and rewarding thing about this massive open-world monster hunter RPG is its deep humanity. This extends from the side quests and contracts (where the monsters are often given more presence than Skyrim's major NPCs) to its protagonist, who seems at first like a standard gruff fantasy hero but reveals himself over time to be a warm, funny and soulful human being.  The writing is some of the best I've ever encountered in a video game. There are at least five different scenes* in this that I don't think I'll ever forget. The voice acting (I played the game in Polish; can't vouch for the English dub) is superb and really helps sell the nuances of the script, as does some surprisingly subtle animation work in the faces.  (* Thinking here of the funeral attended by the baron, the witch hunters' compound with Triss, the ritual for Uma, necromancy with Yennefer and trashing a laboratory with Ciri.)  I will be back for the expansions. I will be back for whatever else CD Projekt does for the foreseeable future. Cyberpunk could not be in better hands.  Play this game slowly. Take the time to soak in the world, to get to know its characters. And try it in Polish; the actor who voices Geralt turns in one of the best performances I've heard in a game.

When i finished this game, i was left sad and a with a giant end-of-game depression. Not because the game was bad or lackluster in any way, but because i knew i will probably never play a game this good ever again. The general gameplay is fun, dynamic and engaging. The graphics are absolutely phenomenal (even on medium settings), and the combat and movement feels fluent and engaging (except for your horse, Roach, wich is the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ animal you will ever encounter).  But the story...oh my, the story... Never in my life have i been this caught up with a story in a video game. From start to finish, i was blown away and at times, i couldnt stop playing because i HAD to know what happened next. It's exciting, thrilling, well-written and depressing all the way throughout. Even the side-quests and witcher-contracts, i couldnt bring myself to skip the cutscenes and dialogues. Simply mindblowing.   11/10

Mastercrafted!  After more than a 100 hours, I remain lost in the world of the Witcher. (This is before I've even started the 2 Story DLC's, revisiting the Witcher for the 2 expansions is like being reborn as you explore the game, its world and mechanics once more)  The Witcher 3 combines Artistic Wizardry & A Mesmerising Soundtrack like no other game before it, creating an experience that has you in awe at all times.  The attention to detail is staggering, just walking around the environments, soaking in the atmosphere, hustling trees and soothing music discourages fast travel. It is a beautiful game. Most side missions rival main missions from other AAA games.  The fighting engine is what I'd like to see in a modern Zelda game. Geralt moves, dodges, counters & strikes gracefully. Powerful potions, weapons and armour can be crafted by alchemy or by finding blueprints (diagrams). The game also has you playing Detective in many missions, where like Batman, the Witcher scans environments for clues and puzzles to solve mysteries and find treasure.  CDRed have created an RPG for a generation, its also the perfect adventure game - 9.5/10  When all is said and done, Witcher 3's Blood & Wine DLC is my nomination for Game of the Year 2016

Pam Paraam, Pam Paam Paraaaam  ...  There are many, many good things about this game. If I was to choose only one it would be the masterful work in creating an immersive environment. I'd never want to live in Velen and I feel sorry for everyone who does.

All in all, I do like this game. But that said, there are some details about the game that are not to my liking. Specifically, these are as follows: 1) when you find a flower, or kill a creature, invariably you have the option to pick the flower for ingredients, or loot the body of the creature. Naturally, you want to do these things. The disturbing aspect that you ALWAYS must be facing the item to be picked up. They designed that aspect to be 'realistic'. In my mind, something that is within a couple of feet from you should be able to be picked up, regardless of which direction you are facing.  2) when you are in a battle, and one of the opponents is shooting arrows at you, you can be standing behind a tree with a 4 foot trunk, and the arrow will come through the tree as if it's not there. So much for 'realism'. At least in Skyrim, you could easily take cover behind objects such as trees and walls. Not in Witcher... those things are there for atmosphere, not for actual use. 3) There are at least 2 maps in Witcher 3. It appears that once you 'graduate' to the second map, there is no way to go back to the first map to finish the quests you missed, and/or, not finished. 4) You cannot climb trees in this game. But your opponents often do. If you try, you jump and bounce off the trunk. Yet those arrows can still hit you. Getting to creatures in high spaces means you have to find a way to get up there. In one quest, a creature is up high, and you are to throw a certain kind of bomb 'in the room', (cave), but when you try, the bomb just bounces back then blows up. The supposed smoke doesn't have any effect because the crack into the room is too narrow to throw into. (perhaps I missed something here, I do not know) 5) Most quests are pretty straight forward. You search for the creature(s), attack them, kill them, loot the bodies, then go collect your reward. But then there are those that can drive you nuts. One such quest involves going through magical gateways, searching for a couple of hours in darkened caves, burning off toxic gases with your igni power, fighting beasts that are very difficult (at that level)... all in all, I spent about 2 hours on that one underground quest, only to get to a point where I was not adept enough to kill very fast creatures in an enclosed magical dome, where the battle often ran through the dome wall, causing even more damage, etc. After a couple of hours of fruitlessness, I gave up and restored to a save game that was just before I went into that area. (and I might point out that I was at the proper level for that quest). Point is, that with so many straightforward quests, to get one that takes a couple of hours is somewhat tedious.  All that said, the game is still fun, and I'm continuing to plow through the good and the aggravating.

Note: this is my first time playing any Witcher games, and I am really, really picky about singleplayer games. I am a pvper by heart.  CHARACTER/STORY: So although I feel Gerald(or whatever the witchers name is) is sorta annoying and too wannabe badass all other aspects of this game and its characters/stories is fantastic and near perfect. Absolutely having a blast in this game and it is very large, I doubt I will be beating it any time soon.   SLUGGY-NESS: I had issues with the controls and stuff at the start, but was remedied by turing motion blur OFF, v-sync OFF (limits frame rate if you didn't know), turn ON desktop cursor, set frame rate limit to 60+. All other settings maxed on my pc but set to your own liking/ capability. [note: this is one of the few games I have ever played that I don't need v-sync on, I get zero screen tearing with it off.]   CLUNKY-NESS: After doing that most of my issues were gone, the only thing that bothered me a little was that it felt a bit clunky on PC and seemed like a Console port however after a few hours in-game I don't really notice it anymore and it feels quite fine, also I recommend pressing CTRL and walking everywhere and using shift to run when you want, makes everything feel better graphically, realistically, and keyboard controling-ly... This game has it all. By far the most well rounded RPG experience out there, without anything even coming remotely close(not even the elder scrolls games).  Fantastic graphics, perhaps for the first time I've ever seen characters in a game which weren't flat(not talking ♥♥♥♥ here, but actual gradually changing personalities), extremely rich world filled with potential interactions.  The real downside is there's very little variation in what you're actually doing gameplay wise, mostly due to the fact fancy magic spells are just far more interesting than using different proc effects on your sword. This leads to the game becoming very tedious at times, but given the quality of it all you always know it's worth going on.  Exceptional game.

The game is almost perfectly build, there is still some flaws, but the game is a must play for every gamer that enjoys a good RPG or even a good hack 'n slash game.  Prós: Graphics 10/10; (nothing to say about that, just feel) Story 9/10; (as i said, almost perfectly build, i gave this note because of some of the choice influences from the Witcher 2 and because it lacks some of the books content) Environment 10/10; (The game have a lot of scenery variety, and Geralt helps to give a literary feeling in the weather with dialogs like 'Winds howlling' or 'Looks like rain', it feels pretty dumb some times, but if you look at it in a poetic view, it really feels like an adventure from the books, and helps you to get immersive in the character)  Cons: Well, the graphics are flawles, but if you are aiming to play it on the pc at 60 fps, be ready to spend some heavy money to build a monster pc; Roach is the dummest creature from the universe (you'll see); I dont know if everyone experience that, but the game usually crashes my drivers from time to time, and some times my pc just reboot for no known reason (i think its because my pc isnt that good)  PC Specs: CPU: AMD FX 6100 3.3ghz 13MB Cache; VGA: GTX 650TI; RAM: 8GB (dual 4GB);  I run the game in some sort of a medium/high spec at 1366x768 (native).

This is how storytelling is done. This is how games should be developed. This is what we should all expect in terms of quality.   CDPR did what they are good at, and they did it fantasically.   The storytelling in this game is nothing short of superb. The voice acting, the characters, the cut scenes, the pacing, are all that of a big budget 5 star movie. The game is a masterpiece here.   The gameplay is fluid, well paced, and overall fun. Fighting monsters is what a witcher does, and they portray that well throughout the game. The only downfall is that it can sometimes feel repetitive and fighting humans never quite feels the same as battling beasts and monsters. I recommend that you read all of it,the game is worth the money real time beard growing boobs buy it now and this is a Spicy Malvani Chicken Curry recipe    INGREDIENTS  1 kg chicken, cut into medium sized pieces   For the curry:  80 ml of water  3 Tbsp of refined oil  3 onions, finely chopped  A handful of grated coconut  A handful of coriander leaves   For the malvani masala:  1 bay leaf  1/2 nutmeg  6-7 cloves  6-7 dry red chillies  10 black peppercorns  1 large cinnamon stick  1 tsp cumin seeds  1 tsp coriander seeds  1 tsp red chilli powder  1/2 tsp turmeric powder   For the coconut masala paste:  3 green chillies  5-6 garlic cloves  1 grated coconut  3/4th inch of ginger   METHOD   Dry roast all the ingredients of the Malvani masala in a pan and coarsely grind them.  Then grind all the ingredients of the coconut masala into a paste.  In a kadhai, heat oil, add the onions and the ground coconut masala.  Stir and cook for about 10 minutes.  Add 3-4 tsp of the ground Malavani masala, red chilly power and salt to taste.  Mix in the chicken and then water.  Cover and let it cook on low flame for about 40 mins till the gravy thickens and the chicken is tender.  Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and grated coconut.  Serve hot.

Pros:  - Eyecandy - Feeling badass - Grinding unnecessary - Awesome combat system - Crafting and Alchemy are very nicely done - Exploring the world is an amazing feeling since every object in the world is placed manually - Very balanced game although I'm absolutely not a fan of balanced rpg's, I prefer Do-whatever-you-like rpg's more... - Best learning curve I've ever seen in an RPG. It's very clear right from the start how you can outsmart your enemies and easy to comfortably slip into the know-how of every aspect of the game.  Cons:  - Quite often feels more like an Interactive Meta Movie  - Quests can sometimes get boring/annoying cause of too much talking and transportation - First half of the game consequences and effects are hardly noticable after decision-making - Can't exploit the game mechanics like in elder scrolls or fallout (ie. saving someone for reward and then killing them is not possible). Player isn't free to mess with the balance of the game. - Awesome swords & armor that you can't have cause you're low-level.  Recommended: - if you're a fan of the series 'or' a huge fantasy-lover with a boner for semi-realism - Playing on a hard difficulty (if you're good at outsmarting rpg systems)

I've tried for a couple hours to ignore the fact, that the controls are worse than the gas mileage of a 1970 Challenger R/T 440... but eventually the nice story and cool ideas just couldn't balance it out.  The saddest part is that the controls are absolutely crucial to a video game. Mess up the graphics and the game can still be fantastic - it'll just look a bit less epic. No good idea for a great story? Never mind - many of the greatest games work without any story at all. But if you mess up the controls it'll just drain a huge amount of fun out of the game and in some cases the good sides of the game just won't be able to make up for it.

After finishing the main storyline and a few side quests, I must admit, I'm a bit disappointed. Maybe my expectations were sky-high after reading all the extremely positive reviews and seeing how many awards it got. I liked the game, but I liked many other games much more than this.  I've played for about 65 hours, most of it being the main quests. I spent about 10 hours on side quests. I played on the default normal setting and apart from the first 10 hours or so, the rest of the game was a walk in the park. I only used alchemy, potions and crafting a few times and the impression I got is that all these are redundant. I never had to use any oils or potions. I could get by just by looting food/water and in the end I had plently food items for another run. I died a few times in some boss fights, but that's it. Fights were very easy, to the point they felt more like chores slowing down the progression, rather than challenges.  I liked the story, however I thought it was very long. The quests are pretty standard fare: go get this, free that guy/gal, kill these guys, etc. Given how easy all these fights are, I would have liked to complete the main story in half the time. Instead, at times, quests felt like filler. I understand that games should offer a decent amount of entertainment per dollar, but this is a bit ridiculous. I'd rather have 20 hours of quality gameplay, than 60 hours doing boring tasks. After completing the game in 65 hours, I felt quite relieved that it was finally over. I have no plans on getting back to it for all those side quests littering the map.  Some people will definitely disagree with me and praise the game's huge lore, character stories, huge map, numerous quests and the deep alchemy/crafting systems. But to me these are all secondary. I just didn't like the gameplay that much. Maybe I should have selected a harder difficulty level, but I mostly play all my games on the default setting. Facing more difficult foes, might have pushed me to learn and actually use the alchemy and potion system.

Don't get me wrong I love RPG's but for some reason, I couldn't quite get into witcher 3. The quests felt tedious and annoying, the story felt slow and like it wasn't going anywhere. Overall, I don't see what the hype is about and as someone who's played skyrim for more than 1500 hours (console included) I may not be able to see what's good about this game. If anyone could give me a reason to keep playing. I'd love it.

What I really like about the game is the world and the monsters. Almost every monster and fable creature I know of is in some form or another present in this game. The Beastiary is fantastic, and I love that you can prepare for fighting a certain monster.  What I dislike is the repetative gameplay. Sure the monsters change, but the basic mechanic remains the same. When you level up, it only feels like a slightly stat change - where the different abilities you gain doesn't give much in form of alternative fighting style. Sure you can take over the mind of an enemy, but it doesn't feel that significant...  Whether or not to recommend the game boils down to one question: Have you played the Witcher 1 and 2? Because I haven't and I couldn't care less about the characters in the game. Every single storymission or major secondary quest pays some form of tribute or revolves around characters, that it thinks I already know... I don't... And I couldn't care less about Dandelion, the sorceresses and the different kings I must have met in previous games.

Short Answer: I do not recommend this game as it is incredibly boring. I fall asleep during the cinematics.  Long Answer: Maybe the storyline is for some people, but not for me. I defitely appreciate the graphics and the work that went into producing this game. No disrespect there. But with all the hype and awards that went into this game I was expecting something a little more epic. At no point, so far, did I get that feeling. It is a struggle, forcing myself to play this, hoping that it gets better.   I play max settings with the hair works on. Maybe I'm too old to understand what all the fuss was about. The graphics and the textures are superb, no doubt about that. But it is what I would expect from a game released in 2015.  Quests are repetitve: Go to _____, talk to ______, now kill _____ and retrieve ______. Rinse and repeat. The opportunity to make decisions is interesting, but the result of your decisions have very little impact from what I can tell so far. I chose to spare a guy, collected my reward, then killed him anyway. Profit?   You can reach the end of the map and it forces you to turn around. You can do side quests but they are predictable. Open the map, see a bunch of icons of tasks to do, complete them, then onto the next area. It feels more like chores but without enough action.  There's too much travelling. Get on your horse, and ride to a far away distance, oh wait, to complete the quest now ride to the other side of the map, oh wait, once you get there now ride back to the other side of the map.  As a character you're basically stuck swinging a sword and casting spells. The spells have a cooldown so you have to wait to cast again. You do get a crossbow that is meh.  Combat with the sword is kinda annoying. You attack your target, then they back up 20 feet so your next swing misses. As you work your way closer to them, they lunge at you and hit you. Basically you hit them once, then they somehow magically get out of range. I don't understand it. You can block and counter which is nice. There really is no gap closer besides your spells. I usually flame my enemies and attack them while they are burning.  I had a lot more fun with Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor. If you're looking for a medieval style game full of action at every turn, then that is what I would recommend. Witcher 3 is worth trying, but I regret buying.  I will continue to play and update this review if I can make it through the game.  Update 3/24/2016 - Game is uninstalled. I could not stand to play it. Way too boring. I have no idea how this game has gotten so many good reviews.

Also the game has no option to turn off the effects in the witcher sence inside the game which is HUGE for some people including myself because almost immediately i start to feel sick when turning it on, not only does it lower your FOV it adds a blur effect to the edge of the screen that makes it much worse for me. There were mods your could get that would remove this effect entirely however with the most recent patch 1.12 no mods that i know of work so ye...  And here's the reason im not recommending the game, earlier i said this game had issues and i've already stated a few but there is one issue stopping me and that is that sometimes NPC's become invincible during quests... Yes you heard me right what happens is that they spawn with -1 hp and you can't kill them no matter what, i've tried killing them with the console reloading the save, everything and nothing works. Unfortunately this happened to me on the main story on the boat right to skellige so i can't continue the quest line at all which means i have to put the game down until the issue is fixed but as of right now they seem to be fixated more on the DLC than the main story which you have to play to get to the damed DLC  Thanks for reading and when they fix the NPC ill update the review however until then this game just isnt worth buying in my eyes

This game is designed for a very specific group of gamers. It's NOT A BAD GAME but it has a crap ton of QUESTIONABLE game design ideas for players new to the Witcher Genre.   The menu user Interface is ♥♥♥♥ for starters, for an open world game you'd expect there to be some sort of method you can open the world map and quest journals without having to go into a seperate screen to read thru the ridiculous amount of text to find information on your current objectives. Navigating between your inventory, bestiary, character biography, alchemy, blacksmith crafting, talent selection, quest journal and world map is a EFFING nightmare.

The game is a 7.5/10, nothing more. Seems like some idiots (IGN Included) want to throw out a 10/10 though...  It's up to you regarding what your interests are and what you spend your money on, but I cant honestly recommend this for everyone; It might grow on you with time, but the combat system is definitely in need of some polish, and I've tried it with both keyboard and controller...  I dont regret purchasing it and will continue to play it, but a 10/10 is an atrocious exaggeration; I've seen better games score less.  Story ignores it's logic:  Turned a demon into a spirit that was supposed to be able to find two people I was looking for since they 'shared blood'. The spirit essentially led me on a seek and find where I had to use the Witcher Sense to figure out what happened. Then the spirit ended up leading me NOT to the people it was supposed to, but instead to some NPC's who couldnt tell me much else than 'gone here'. Historical Evidence shows the Witcher should of been able to track 'clues' on his own to this location...but plot convenience right? Anyway, the spirit actually leaves and doesnt find anyone. In short, the spirit was supposed to do something it didnt do.  Later, fought some werewolf and apparently he couldnt control himself and killed the girl he 'loved', but at the good/bad choice the ending, he talked in the cutscene and was 100% in control of his actions. After which he selectively killed someone and then, on his knees, begged me to end him - all while remaining a werewolf. So ♥♥♥♥ logic/lore I guess.  The Story is typical, which is fine, but the combat & movement in the game is sloppy. Sadly, the mind-numbing and boring combat systems from Arkham and Assassin's Creed did parry/dodge better than this...  I think the reason Geralt is all scarred up is not because of 'He's done and been through a lot', but more so because 'Developers designed a bad combat system and Geralt was forced to suffer'.   Combat is 80% dodging/parrying - When you fight stuff at a lower level than you, it's not as big of a problem, but you can be stun locked and killed, (even those 1/3 of your level)...Many fights take place in small areas; you constantly get stuck on small items (Candles, Fruit, Baskets, Roots, Etc).  Camera is bad in small places.  BONUS ROUND:  Geralt retained 0 information about monsters in the codex from previous games.  There are car racing games that have better handling than Geralt.  The game is not open world. The leveled system brings down the game:  I killed some level 8's in a spot. I went to another '?' not 100 meters away and the mobs were level 19; drastic climb.  If you can find mats to make stuff, you're often not the level to use it. If you have the level and mats you might not have the crafting skill; by the time you have all three skills there are good odds you dont need that gear anymore.  You're limited to 12 skill slots, skills need to be slotted in order to use. The fact that you need to 'Put X amount of points in a tree to use stronger skills' mean that you're going to waste a lot of skill points; skills that you dont slot are just skill point dumps.  Changing the game difficulty changes stat modifiers, not skills/mechanics.  There's no area loot option, sometimes it seems impossible to target the one object you need to loot behind some others. (I'm honestly not sure if it's procedural generation or an idiots deliberate placements)...  Fall Damage is insane.  Some doors are wooden and you can break them, others are wooden but you need a key.  Dialogue options are sometimes too vague.  Swimming controls are very rough; I also surfaced under a boat and got stuck in the boat.  It's not clear when you're stealing vs when you're looting.  Biggest complaint is that this game scored a 10/10 when it's clearly not perfect.
sht game, fallout 4 > witcher 3, CD ret.a.rd doesn't know how to make rpgs. Anyone who likes this game is a 12 years old f.@.g
What a poorly optimized, badly controlled, unplayable piece of console-born industry. Would it be playable after 3-5-10 patches? Who knows... but the bad mechanics not going to disappear in any case.

Great concept poor execution.  Great characters and story building just too bad the combat is just absolute garbage. Main protagonist is supposed to be this awesome monster hunting/killing badass and appearntly has a glass jaw cuz a gnats fart will drop him faster than a 2 dollar hooker on payday.  Combat is a pointless, one on one he works fine any more than one and hes going to lose. Some badass he turned out to be game simply makes you feel like a joke. If you get hit with anything you will either be off balanced or stunned or whatever you want to call it but during this time you cant do anything block nope, parry nope, dodge nope, just take that hit like a man.....oh wait you cant since your a wuss with one or 2 hits and your dead. and you will almost never see a one on one fight ever. Appearntly his swings, either light or strong attacks, have little weight to them since enemies just ignore them continueing their attack which hits you since you cant do anything while you attack. Even parrying and counter attacking is useless since your attacks have zero effect against enemies aside from reducing their health bar.   So this game ends up taking a massive crap on the batman arkham style combat and gives you a health/dodge system like dark souls hope you all enjoy punching yourselfs in the junk cuz thats what this is.  I was realy liking the story and characters too bad the gameplay is so off putting im going to shoot for a refund.

I have to say this again about the the cut scenes and npc conversations ARE YOU F***king kidding me its litterly a movie that stops periodaclly and lets you move your character 10 feet or swing his sword and *POOF* another 5 miniute cut scene,,,EVEN SOME OF THE FIGHTS ARE CUT SCENES ..you basiaclly sit at your chair and watch a movie..again sad just sad and boring.  Talking to NPC's is depressing becouse after talking to the first few you relize they never stop talking and you are stuck in the conversation with NO WAY OUT GRRRRRRRR.. im talking about 3 and 4 miniute conversations per NPC !!! i found myself mashing the space bar to hurry through the conversations just to try and play the game, then I just stopped interacting with them all together in hopes of playing my charcter ...still i had no luck i got hit with another cut scene..  I litterly only got to play my character for about 15 minuetes in THE FIRST HOUR AND A HALF ... and most of that time i was just riding my horse.. i wanted to puke   dont get me wrong here I love a great story line but let us use our imaginastion after the opening scene and have a cut scene here and there maybe 4 or 5 at the most in an entire game..  this is geared toward the 10 year old mentality wher they must have their hand held and their imagination done for them with endless cut scenes. PROS... game is pretty  CONS.. everything else in the game unless your 10 year old or brand new to gaming   READ ALL THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS THEY ARE SPOT ON !!!

I'm certain I'll get flamed for this but this is one of the hardest, most annoying (aka not entertaining), games I've ever played. The mechanics (on PC at least) are puerile making it hard to react with any certainty. No power. No money to get weapons. Ineffective skill improvements (making leveling a futile disappointment). Game mechanics where your horse gets stuck on a pixel-high rock is frustrating. Frustrating is not fun. Imbalanced quests where the only way to win is to play over and over until you 'figure out' how to beat the quest is not fun.  The narrative is spot-on. It's a compelling story with interesting ideas that really progress natural thinking but the mechanics of the game really diminish all that. It's like inventing time-travel with the worst user-interface imaginable.  The artists who created the game should probably consider firing the people who programmed it.
Poor controls and camera make this game a chore to play, and it's way too heavy on cutscenes.

Victim of hype and reviews :(  I never played the series before, but was bored with all my other gaming options and wanted to try something new. Made a rash decision after friends raved, watching a few demos, and reading a few reviews to purchase this 'game.'  However, I have played PC games for 20+ years and I have somehow never fallen in love with these console type games.   'Played' for 20 hours now, and I have seen very little combat - and when it has occurred was underwhelming, found little use for crafting armor, weapons, or alchemy. What I have done is sit in my chair and basically watched a very long scripted CG movie that I have had little interaction with and no effect on its direction.   I have the 'choice' of playing the only chracter that I can and tweek a little bit towards one thing or another, I have 'choices' in conversations that all ultimately lead to the same conclusion - another 10 min cut scene. About once an hour I get to swing my sword a few times, or engage in a 20 second horse race, or play a stupid card game.   After a few hours of playing, I realized what this was, and resigned myself to it. So now I just 'play' the game by sitting back comfortably in my chair with my popcorn and soda, and watch the rather uninteresting movie play itself out. The occasional inconvenience of putting my popcorn down to lean forward to hit 1 for a dialogue response or left mouse button to swing my sword is infrequent enough that it doesn't disrupt the flow of the movie too much. Sadly, my mind does wander from time to time, thinking...hmm, I could have bought any number of games instead, even re-subbed to WoW for 4 months, maybe I'll start a new Skyrim character - ooh a mage with a shield - and so on.   Thus, if you are an old school guy like myself, this is not the game for you. If you're the kind that like your games to be 80-90% scripted movie with very little choice for...well anything...then this is for you.   I've never thought of asking for a refund before, but I might actually try with this.  Update: refund denied, so I'm trying to burn thru the game as quickly as possible. Rapidly spamming the space bar during ALL conversations has reduced the movie/game time from 90/10% to about 70/30% =(  Update 2: Tried to keep going but just way to boring, quit in the middle of some quest I could care less about and went back to playing insurgency/starcraft/etc.

GOOOOOD does it get dull as dishwater....I've spent 37hrs on it at this point and keep hoping it gets better! Combat is bad but not a killer as far as game play..The fact you can spend upto an hour on a side quest and get between 10 and 50 exp for it is the real killer!!! I will go on about the sheer sillyness of some of the quest's...Being forced to be a kids classroom visitor in the mold of 'what does Daddy do' and the boredom brought on by the constant need for every single quest to have more elements than the periodic table involved saps the strengh of will straight from your soul... One real bugbear was that as I've not bothered to play the other two games in the series there are large if not massive parts of the game that don't make sense...Near the begining after a mere ten hrs of play I found myself in a bath being asked a whole range of questions obviously designed to set up your character based on decisions made in previous games in the series and as I've no clue who they are asking about or the quests my guy has done before I had no idea how to answer! These questions obviously played an important part in who I get to interact with in the game...I like to play as a nice guy in rpgs, sometime with a little ambiguity depending on the situation, but these blind choices have me labelled as the butcher of somewhere and other such things...People are always popping up saying 'remember me, you killed my wife/son/brother/dog and so on...plus I'm supposed to know every single npc i come across which can be confusing as hell..... The monster hunts become repetitive and really not worth the time it takes to do them (back to the 10-50 exp mentioned above) Don't even ask about the bloody horse! I abandoned it after two hours of sticking to every tiny bit of scenery!!! All i really want is a couple of giant dungeons to go wander around, but even the couple I've come across need another npc to do them. Then there is the pure misogyny of the whole game, every women has her knockers out! The cut scenes don't really bother me its the stupidness of quite large elements that bug...I have tracked down a cross dressing elf, wrote a bloody play, played find the ghost and many other things that just detract from the gameplay...I spent another 16hrs just wandering around looking for question marks and gained a single level! To sum up I just wish the bloody game got on with it already!

Hype train leaving the station. Woo woo! Ignore all of the acting and the open worldness and concentrate on the fighting. The fighting SUCKS. Play Amalur if you want to actually control yourself and have interesting weapons. You walk like you are in a Tilt-O-Whirl at all times. Take a step forward and you skid to a stop after three. Try to turn around and you take two steps and turn a three foot circle. The swordplay is ridiculously stupid. The hanging guard is perfect, but for a simple light swing you spin (!) in a circle with your sword high above your head (!) and take two (!) steps forward. It is the most ridiculous, uncontrollable thing in any RPG ever. Oh, and your weapon choices consist of sword. Amalur has nine, and you can use two at once. How did this game come out after?

I don't think this game is good, and I know that this is a very unpopular opinion...  I played skyrim, loved it. So, i thought that this game would be a good one for me, however, the vision blur sucks, even though i turned it off something still feels wrong with turning in this game. I expect AAA games that i spend 60 dollars for to have refined controls and game mechanics, vision blur is something you should have the choice to turn on, not be forced to turn off.   Also, I thought that this game was supposed to be an open-world choose you own adventure type thing, like skyrim. If you're looking for that i would run because this is not it... this is the most story-based open world game i've every played, and even though the trailers would like to say otherwise these are the facts. This game is insanely linear and story based (yes fanboys, I did play past the tutorial) but if you are into that sort of thing along with fantasy games, I would recomend  Also, the games use of the xbox controller makes me wonder how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the console version of the game is. upon plugging in your controller you will find that you only have acess to 1/8 of the things you can do in the game... (there shouldnt be that many controls anyways) and I am aware that there a shortcuts included that you have to work around in the controller... but this is not that, half of the combat moves are not available, and it is hard to find the menu you are looking for without using a mouse.   Overall I would say that the publisers were eager to get a paycheck, and they knew that the hype would allow them to shove ♥♥♥♥ down the players mouths, and people would still ask for more. If you got to the bottom im amazed that you read this far.. i warn you don't get this game.

Three times ive tried to play this game and like it: on release, some months later and then some more months later.  To put it simple:  If you like tv soap operas like game of thrones...  If you are not freaking fed up of elves and dwarves in every bloody fantasy franchise (this is more of Sapowski´s fault than the game studio)...  If you think that the open world model taken from arseassins creed (basically a sea full of dots with mini events attached to them) is the best way of create open worlds... If you like really uncomfortable inventory systems... If you want to see naked women because its the most cool thing for the sake of it even if its just a way to attract nerds... If you like CSI... If you just take the graphics in consideration... If you like repetitive @nal quests involving using CSI techniques to find a chest full of w@nk or to figure out if the butler is the murder... If you like to spam (literally spam) the space bar button to skip the horrid, boring dialogues -this might be a bit of a contradiction tho since im assuming you will like game of thrones but nevermind me-... If you like fast travel, horses, goats, sheeps, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who look like clowns, lots of swearing with or without reason, wolf meat, an@l alchemy and crafting systems that seem taken from any mmo from the early 2000s, a ♥♥♥♥ ton of main and secondary quests to show the world the alpha male you are...  Then I totally recommend you this game. You will love every single minute spent on it.  Me? I completely lost clue -and worst of all, interest- of what the hell was going on by the time I arrived to Velen.   The things I liked about this game, unfortunately, are secondary characters such as Letho or Lambert, the Gwent game, some aspects of the combat and obviously the graphics (yes those repetitive woods and swamps with the ocassional spot to clean monsters).  Im still struggling to finish the main quest. Would like to add the fact that I have not read the novels and stories by Sapkowski, that they seem to be highly regarded in terms of quality etc, but as mentioned before, im sick of elves and dwarves. Maybe one day I give them a try, maybe even like them then return here and change this review to positive.  So overall: No, just NO.

THIS IS ONLY FOR THE BLOOD AND WINE EXPANSION!!!  At this point I can't recommend Blood and Wine, as I am experiencing so many bugs I haven't been able to play more than a short time without having to quit and restart multiple times. Diving isn't working; crossbow aiming isn't working; Geralt comes out of fast travel in combat mode, triggering all the guards around him; he frequently freezes for no apparently reason; so far I've fallen through the bottom of the world twice and had to reload; my armour set levels changed so I couldn't use them any more. XP went into negative numbers.   I cannot understand CDPR releasing the patch and expansion on the same day, when the last big patch caused so many problems. It's terrible project management.   Hopefully they will get a hotfix out soon, and I'll be able to enjoy Geralt's last adventure but right now, this is a mess. If Bethesda had released this, people would be crucifying them.

Don't get me wrong, this game is a 9/10, but in my case it keep crashing constantly. Sometimes i can play a couple hours, sometimes it crashes 10 minutes after. I've tried several configurations, GPU drivers, disable innecessary SO services... but no improvement. So, if you buy it, do it at your own risk.  edit:  I've found out that crashing issues are pretty common with the game, as lots of people also complain about similar problems in several forums. Finally i got the game running for extended periords of time by tweaking with nvidia drivers (there is a legacy verison out there built specifically for the game) and lowering visual setting down to 30 fps. The game totally deserves the effort.  Sadly, i also have to say that i've run into a handful of bugs (uncompletable quests, swords and abilities not usable in combat, horse riding problems). Not a lot, but enough to annoy.  One feature that i find very unrefined is the game's inventory. It's counterintuitive in many actions you can perform, offers only 4 quick slots for a couple dozens of available consumables, and applying them directly from the menu is clumsy as it often breaks the tempo in battle. Also, you will end up having a lot of similar graphic potion items with different colors which you must constantly mouseover in order to remind the effects. One user here suggested that this is because the game is controller friendly.  On the bright side, the more the story advances the more interesting it gets. Very good plot and well told.

I would give this game 6.5/10.   Graphics: 10/10 This game is visually stunning on a high performance system. I play at 1440P Resolution on a 55' UHD TV with settings on highest and hair works for Geralt, with FPS ranging from 55-75. I started off playing at 4k resolution, but the FPS drop was down in the upper 40's and would go to lower 30's during battles. The difference between 1440P and 4k, aside from FPS, was barely noticeable.   Battle System: 6/10 Battles in the game are fun at first, but get boring and easy as you proceed through the game. The targeting system is rather annoying, especially if using a steam controller. Rather than an auto targeting system of targeting the nearest enemy, you have to switch amongst the enemies manually with an already pre-occupied thumb. This doesn't matter when you are fighting 1-3 enemies, but when you have 20 people on your ♥♥♥, it gets really annoying! Having different types of combo effects would have been nice. Often times, I felt like I was just button mashing attacks, dropping a sign here and there, dodging, rolling etc - boring.  Gameplay: 5/10 Riding the horse sucks. Swimming sucks. Geralt's 'fast' spinning sword attack isn't very fast and leaves him open to getting attacked while in swing. Casting Signs are cool at first, but really don't ever evolve into anything THAT cool.. The interaction with other characters is fun. The game isn't very challenging for the most part, unless you attempt missions outside of your level. Boss fights are pretty lame and easy - if you've ever played God of War 3 you will understand this. Wish you could choose to play the game as Ciri, she is much quicker and more fun to play with than Geralt, at least at the end of the game :). I investigated as many Q marks as I could take, felt like I was running pointless errands and got bored, lost interest in the game. I often found myself falling asleep while playing, or leaving the game on while I did other things around the house. You could probably subtract about 30 hours of gameplay off the listed time from that alone.  Storyline: 4/10 The entire goal of this game is to find Ciri. Towards the end, you find Ciri. WOW who would have thunk? It was often just annoying and dragged on and on and on and on some more. There weren't any plot twists. None, other than deciding how you want the game to end or who you decide to romance. It was so dull that by the end of the game I had zero fracks to give about what happened to Ciri, Geralt, or anyone for that matter. Somehow I managed to push through and beat it regardless of my lack of interest..   If you like games that lack plot, go for it. It truly is a beautiful game, but that is all I can honestly give it.

I was so excited to see this coming out. I was hoping for something that would have me minimalizing my awe for Skyrim; instead, to my horror, I found a potentially amazing game that was totally nerfed. They built this game for platforms! This is the scourge of gaming! This is an issue that plagues PC gaming and this game epitomizes it. I wish they would place in their advertising what platform the game was designed for and then ported to.   This is an AMAZING platform game. I think up there with Red Dead Redemption (love that game… only reason I plug in my Xbox… worthless PoJ)… It has a massive world and a lot to do in it. The story lines are solid and carry over from the previous versions very well. I am a little annoyed with how much they break up the world; but I believe this is needed to accommodate the puny memory of platforms (my PC sports 32gb and I have been itching for a reason to increase it). I love the animations. They have put a lot into the movements and reality of the strikes. I wish they went one step further, such as Age of Conan; but I am not disappointed.   Ok… I’ll ease into my disappointments. Firstly, there are a lot of items to hunt, gather, store, craft, etc. This would be great, but it costs cash to do most of it, and you can only craft at certain locations. This means hauling around tons of junk and having to stop at each bush and shiny item. I hacked money by 5 hours in. Because they allow me to own my own game, and I can hack out these annoyances, I could begrudgingly forgive the developers. I am absolutely disgusted by the cloud based games and software.  The most egregious of issues with Witcher is its interface. An interface should be as invisible to the user as possible. The more intuitive and connective the interface is, the more immersive and, in my opinion, enjoyable the game. This game is trying to please all of the markets. This is the failing of many of the modern games. Let’s face it, I have significantly more options with a standard keyboard (102 and shift and control and alternative functions… so I guess 408+) and use significantly more muscle groups in controlling with a PC vrs controller (2 thumbs and a couple fingers vers my entire arm and fingers). All console games use cheat aim bots or console players would never hit anything; I can hit pixels with my 6400 DPI mouse.  Controlling Wither’s movements or his horse is a lesson in frustration, especially in confined locations. I wish I could zoom in and out of first person perspective and take direct control over my movements. You have to be in the right spot and orientation to loot or interact; which could have been possible without all of the extra movement animations.  I love this game and hate it. I wish I could get my money back. I will never preorder again because of these types of issues. Developers, please stop atrocities like this! If you feel that you must try to own every market, then develop a solid PC game and dumb it down for the platform versions. Yea, the platformers will scream, but they are living in a limited world in their platforms (I can always easily out build platforms, even without using top of the line PC parts). You will find that they will either switch to be a PC gamer quick, or they will buy 2 versions of the game. Games really came to life with PCs, please stop killing the gaming industry by limiting your capabilities to the boundaries of platforms. I have an old PC and still sport a 12 core processor. Please let us use it!!!!

Terrible performance--doesn't look a whole lot better than Skyrim (e.g.) on a 4k monitor, but runs about 1/10 the speed.  Manoeuvring Geralt feels like you're steering a drunkard by proxy--precise movements are absolutely impossible.  Combat is a joke--too much attempted 'realism' with absolutely no clue what that means. I think my favourite 'feature' is when foes can attack instantly after being damaged; that or the way Geralt's hamfisted stumbling makes any kind of finesse during combat a complete impossibility.  Dialog advancement is glitchy; the entire UI lags horribly.  Some hotkeys can't be remapped, or can't be mapped to certain buttons, even when unlocking the controls.  Update: there is a quicksave, but it's not listed in the controls menu. WTF?  Having to 'equip' passive skills is a horrible, horrible idea.  All that said, if the developers actually had half a clue, they could fix all this crap; The Witcher 3 is a horrible game with a good game inside it desperately trying to claw its way out.

6/10 - The game is beyond beautiful in many ways, however in terms of gameplay (combat/movement) and many of the game mechanics such as the repair system and economy in general it feels very imbalenced. I do the in game research for fights and still feel like my best option half the time is to corner enemies and spam quick attack or attack once roll away. It feels more like a chore then a challenge. Also the movement outside of and the camera inside of combat just feels clunky. Still going on though, hoping im just bad at the game, but 30+ hours in and things still seem wonky.

The unresponsive and wonky controls spoiled the game for me. Geralt on horseback feels like driving a schoolbus through a forest and the camera seems to have a life of its own. Controlling Geralt alone doesn't feel much better, especially in combat where the camera manages to do the most amazing and utterly useless things. Geralt sometimes sheathes his weapon in battle, but that's fine. Older guys like him should have a break from time to time.   Items a player can interact with nearly drove me insane, e.g. looting a corpse often ended up in running around the corpse (several times) and trying to find the sweet spot where i might be able to hit a key to actually loot the body.  Please note, that this game has many candles/lights that are unlike the lootable corpses VERY eager to react on the player and love to be either ignited or extinguished.   Oh, i also console-leveled my character, to see what combat becomes when Geralt has good gear and abilities. The combat made no difference to me, except, that low levels could no longer kill me off while i was trapped in animationsequences, which btw is another annoying thing in this game.   No. I did not use mouse/keyboard for the controls but an xbox-controller.  And no: this title is not trying to achieve the same effect as e.g. Darksouls does. Darksouls' controls are the way they are on purpose and they are precise and predictable. The controls in witcher 3 are just sluggish and unresponsive. I do not agree on using witcher 3's technique to make combat more interesting.  After 25 hours of gameplay i simply gave it up, and i probably wouldn't have, would i have been dragged into the storyline during those 25 hours. Unfortunately this wasn't the case, either. Though some characters in this game are memorable and have a certain depth, none of them made me want to learn more about the story/lore and get more involved. Who was this Ciri person again? Nevermind, i don't care. Neither for anyone else of the NPCs. There are indeed a lot of side-quests, but all quests i did felt somewhat shallow and combined with the horrible controls they were not really that exiting.  The graphics are allright for me, especially the charactermodels are nicely done. The world the player can 'explore' looks good and feels vast, although it's often as empty as parts of the falskaar-mod for skyrim. You can ride along with Geralt and his schoolbus, but there isn't much to do or stop for.   The performance is more or less ok on an i7-3770k/16GB Ram and a gtx 770. It sometimes feels a bit laggy, but not unplayable.   Overall a disappointment given the price of this game.

Very disappointed. Way too many cutscenes. Absolutely horrible pc controls. Cant believe the vehicle (horse) actually uses a seperate button to run than the character. Fast travel is awful. Trailer of the making of states that they want to make it as close to life as possible. Never in life have I had to travel to a sign to go to another sign. I have a horse as a method of travel so I should be able to travel from anywhere on the map so long as I am not in combat. Combat controls are awful. Have to hit seperate button to roll in any direction. How about a double tap feature to roll. Also dont try to take on multiple enemies. Your character plays pinball between them till he dies. Spent 5 hrs playing and maybe killed 30 creatures. Very slow progression. I suppose if you have an immense amount of free time and love to watch animated movies with very poor acting that you would like this game. This game was highly recommded to me and I really wanted to like it. It has an excellent story and could have been so much better than it is. It let me down. It let me down so bad that I had to write this review which is the first one I have ever written. YOU'VE BEEN WARNED!

What good is 'next gen' graphics, which are just mediocre Next-gen graphics and great story/lore or whatever when you feel like a leper-gimp with a limp in this overhyped mess... Seriously, in a game this big, how come no one thought that moving the character around was of any importance or let's just say fighting... There's a button for everything, good thing I'm a bass player, cause there's a lot of moving fingers around in weird configs... doesn't help that you can bind your own keys... Just like Crysis the first one, great game if they would have nailed the controls... like the second where they finally implemented situational based controls to alleviate for the many possibilities and only 10 fingers... Do we really need 2 separate buttons for Fast attack and heavy attack, how about holding down the same button for a more powerful blow, I mean Geez... and the thing about the stuffed Unicorn in the beginning, fun for some i'm sure, but Wow that was unneccessary and killed the immersion... Who cares about great RPG elements, when basic things like control schemes feel like they were developed for a text based RPG or something, moving around without it feeling this bad in an exploration and combat... and RPG game should be a non issue in 2016 especially for AAA developers...

This is one of the worst games I have ever played. If the makers of Fable or perhaps Shadows of Mordor cared more about making a pretty game instead of one that is fun to play; this would be the result. I have spent 14 hours of my life playing this garbage and for that I will forever be ashamed. With all the positive reviews I expected it would get better and better but, I was let down. Combat is sluggish and nonsensical. Overpowered enemies wait behind many turns and experience is difficult to gain so quickly avoiding them is the only recourse. Loading screens are long and drawn out and the music is repetitive and annoying after 30 minutes of play. NPCs are so generic it seems like they were pulled straight from other games of the same vain. The main character is boring and the story is uninteresting. The war-torn countryside and the people affected ought to make for a compelling story but thus far the only interaction you have with the storyline is doing the same quests you’ve done a million times if you play these types of games. Clear the monsters out of a house or rescue a brother or protect a merchant. One of the worst parts is a lack of frequent auto saves. Your character is frequently a pushover and death will come, but unless the gamer is diligent enough to constantly manually save, you’ll find yourself transported across the map and have tones of work and travel undone. This wouldn’t be so bad if travelling was interesting or unlocked cool gear or something. However, once you’ve explored the 30th village that looks the same as the last 29, one starts to wonder why? I wish I could have my $59.99 or my 14 hours of gameplay back. You’ll have more fun watching Donald Trump sex tape with you parents and ex-girlfriend. God I hate this game.

Within the first 30 minutes, I can't even count on two hands how many flaws this game has... ranging from huge inconsistencies (e.g., after you save the man from the Griffin, you remark how Witchers help people for free, but then less than five minutes later, when the pub owner lady asks if you'll help kill the Griffin, you say you will, but only for coin), to crashes (my first crash was with the Ghouls, and I have a state-of-the-art PC with the latest drivers), to strange autosave points (e.g., right before the dialogue begins), to numerous other strange design choices, such as the strange turning and the walking speed, which is far too fast.   Highly recommend passing on this.

Less of a review more of a warning.   Regardless of the 9s and 10s, this game is far from worth it. As well as the Steam reviews of people with a handful of hours praising it to be one of the best games of all time.  Suffers with massive performance issues. Graphics were clearly downgraded and are on par with the console versions, even at ultra. Yet you will struggle to maintain 40FPS on medium, even with higher end cards.   Vegetation is terribly done. Grass and small plants are static. Small trees and bushes are made entirely of light, and pass through Geralt with ease.   Game has many bugs and AI issues too.   It's clear not much effort was put into the game performance and visual-wise. Lack of optimisation makes the game far from worth the $60 asking price.  Developers lied about exploration too. Remember when they said 'If you see it, you can go there'? Well... You can't. 'No invisible walls' ring a bell? False too. Whilst they're not invisible walls, if you stray too far from the enclosed map, you get a warning that you've 'reach the world's end' and must 'turn back'. If you fail to turn back, the map opens up and you must fast travel somewhere.   Do not trust CDPR. People always went on about Valve being for the gamer, and yet they aren't. The case is the same with CDPR.  Finally, to put things into perspective: My rig:  i5 4690k GTX 770 OC'd (2GB VRAM) 8 gigs of RAM, and all the rest.   I get 40 FPS at most with plenty of drops running on medium at 1080p. The game looks like something from 2013.   Disgusting.

Haven't really played much of the other Witcher's before, mainly as the combat was tedious - point is, this revivew is intirely based on this game, and not really any prior biases.  I just have to say, wow. As for RPGs go, they really did a fantastic job on this game;  PROS  -The graphics in the game (Using Ultra) is stunning - everything runs very smoothly and clearly is very optimised. - Sound effects and voice acting are truely fantastic - The stories themselves, aside from the great lore, are very well done - Consequences from decisions and actions are actually motivating (Sorry all those people died, I just wanted to save some kids! Damnit! Maybe I shouldn't save that one guy, because i killed 4 to save him! What am I doing with my life? - Mobs are actually challenging -> You will fear mobs hitting you - Gwent is stupid fun - The horse isn't nearly as dumb as people make it out to be (or it was patched) - Most quests are very fun, immersive and challenging. - I'm afraid of going in the water, every damn time something sneaks up on me (and again, mobs actually HURT) - I hate enchanting and making pots over and over and over and over; In Witcher 3, you make a pot once and it automitically replenishes when you rest (with material components)  Cons - Yes, there are tons and tons of NPCS - but i have seen the same model of a NPC 3-4 times on the same screen! They needed to fix the way NPC models are chosen and how many of that model can display at one time - Alot of voices are reused (understandble, there's soo many NPCs to interact with - but kind of immersion killing) - They could have done better on gear - everything feels very much the same, with maybe an extra slot or an extra stat here and there (at least there's more than 4 gear sets, such as with skyrim) - Gwent is single player only  - There is some repetition on quests, like the 'go collect this' from WoW (for example) to' go find this and likely kill it' - Cross bow is extra effective underwater (cause somehow that makes more sense than being able to use powers) - Im a Witcher and can't find receipeies for Witcher potions without visiting 1,000,000 vendors first.... - Crafting and Alchemy are much more annoying than interesting  I know im forgetting some stuff, but really this is a great game; and i don't take the time to do reviews very often  So hopefully that says something about how much i think they did a great job on this game

An awesome game, with a massive amount of quests. Ranging from go there, kill that to multistage investigations into a serial killer. And at over 200 hours, i'm still finding new stuff to do.   There a cool crafting system, allowing you to create excellent gear as well, swords and armour to carve your way through you enemies and potions to aid you in the carving!.   Combat wise Initially you'll get frakked up a lot, but as you gain experience, both IC and OOC, it gets easier until those very same early enemies fall before you like so much grain. Which personally i felt was fitting.   The free DLC is a plus, while some is only cosmetic, free is still free, and i love all the finishing animations, nothing about heads going flying ever gets old.  Overall its an excellent RPG, well worth the time i put it, and i secretly hope some devellopers will look at this and remember how it should be done.

On paper, The Witcher 3 doesn't sound all that remarkable. It's an open-world fantasy RPG, and in many ways keeps to the standard tropes you would expect. Notice boards, item crafting, fast travel, it's all there, and slightly marred by what is a servicable - but ultimately uninteresting - combat system and frustrating leveling/reward system that can be annoying.  But The Witcher has a magic to it all it's own. Despite not being really innovative in any obvious way, I love it dearly. It is masterfully crafted. The level of care with which it was made shows everywhere. The open world and the characters in it feel extremely genuine, and as such the game is compelling and immersive.  After three games and around 150 hours of playing as Geralt of Rivia, I am sincerely sad to see it end. I feel richer for having played it, and poorer for having finished it. I think this company is going to go on to do really great things, and for anyone still wondering about The Witcher, I whole-heartedly recommend it.
my pick for GotY at this point. A real work of art. I keep going back to it and finding new lore, quests, and story notes. Stop reading this and buy this game.

This game is simply epic in both scope and in quality. Everything from the insanely gripping main story line to the equally gripping side quests keep you entertained for the full ~80 hours. Each side quest feels as if the quest giver is physically incapable of completing the objective and requires a person with super human abilities (Geralt) to get it done (No 'run this letter to that guy' type quests). I can think of one quest where the giver asks you to go talk to someone for them but it's because you are asking for a favor and just dropped a couple weeks worth of work on them to complete in a single night. The point is that the quests never feel like busy work and a lot of them lead to interesting stories that develop the non-primary characters beyond their roles as quest objects.  Beyond the great game itself, the development team is truly amazing. From the game to the FREE DLC, they have displayed the care and product buy-in that few development houses display. I rarely invest in a season pass but I intend to throw as much money at CD Projekt Red as I can to ensure this development method continues. If I had the money I would become an investor. I hope that future developers use this game as a model by taking their time to create a quality product that they care about.   This has replaced my previous long time favorite game 'Chrono Trigger' (my favorite since it's initial release). 10/10
Best open world ever! (except for skyrum cause thats skyrum)
Quite possibly the greatest game ever made.

I love RPGs, I love open world RPGs. and I loved the first 2 games in the series. So i had VERY high expectations.  They were all met by this amazing game. The sheer size of it gives a new meaning to 'open world'  The map is huge, the amount of content is incredible.  The graphics, the plot and the excellent gameplay are all executed to perfection.  You will feel that character development is somewhat slow - but you will see that it's not so much slow as its just so big that things take time to mature. i am well into my 58th hour of gameplay at this point with no end in sight.  The things that could use some work are: Trading - the conversion rate and prices make trading something you do very little. money is hard to come by and that means you rarely shop. Gamepad configuration - a bit annoying, buttons can be confusing, some issues when selecting items with the gamepad. The limited amount of shortcuts means that you have very little tacticle use of various potions and the lack of shortcuts or favorits for oils means you have to keep going throught the menus. Monster / battle experience - most of the experience in the game comes from quests, it would have been nice to get some more rewards for leveling up through open exploration.  But these are just minor annoyances. the game is brilliant. if you liked gothic (1 & 2 - not the others) , skyrim, fallout 3 or any of the other open world cames - you will love this game., and if you havent played them - go play them. especially gothic 1 & 2... :)
It's pretty damn good!
Absolutely fantastic. A little overwhelming at the beginning but the game does a great job of slowly teaching you all the mechanics. Haven't played a game this good in a long, long time.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is by far one of the best RPGs, perhaps even the best game in general, that I've ever played. The pros and cons can be viewed in any review, but for this one, I will say this: In addition to a well developed plot, beautiful scenery, and an entertaining combat system, the Witcher manages to achieve what few games can- a sense of immersion in a world that is anything but sugarcoated. Gone are the days of a joyful go-here-do-this world. In this game, you'll be required to make meaningful choices that you may or may not regret. Helping some children here may lead to political deaths elsewhere. In summary, choose carefully, and happy hunting.

I use to think that moded Skyrim or Dragon Age was the most fun in RPG i had but boy.. was i wrong. Witcher 3 so far has give me the best experience in RPG i had in a very longtime.  For the first time i actually feel like i'm adventuring when i'm playing this game, the forest feels real, the people feel real, it's incredible. I really recommend people playing this game!. Been playing for a while, yet not finished the game. I absolutely love it! Graphics, Story, the hours of questing and... boobs. those are the pros of the game. Yet one matter that really isn't working for me is the steam cloud. One hell of a pain. I saved the game ALOT. Just before talking/fighting anything, I noticed after 5 hours of gameplay I crashed. (Reason: unknown). And I was like 'No worries, got plenty of saves.' I go on and what do I see? ALL THE SAVES ARE GONE GONE GONE. I had to play back from a save almost 6 hours BACK. Someone please fix that. I turned off Cloud for the good of saves. Would highly recommend doing so.
10/10 will play through it again

The Witcher 3 is a fitting end to an amazing trilogy. It's an ambitious beast, and it delivers its mammoth story with finnesse , and a new, very high standard to which big name RPGs will have to follow  This game is the result of hard work and dedication which started 8 years ago, in a humble small studio in a cold city. If you play one RPG this year, make it this one.  You play as Geralt, a mutated human, pushed through trials and tribulations at a young age to become a Witcher, a monster slaying machine of grey morality and silver hair, in a world that both fears him and is repulsed by his presence...a neccesary evil in a time of war and death  I'm not going to bother talking about its graphics, sound and combat because to be honest they are all up to par, and if your spending your time looking at buying the game based off those you're missing the point of it  This is a game to be felt, to be experienced, to feel alive in.   This game will shock you, move you and make you think about the decisions you made long after you stop playing it  Do yourself a favor and get comfortable, tune out the world, and experience this masterpeice of fiction in all its glory.   Forget what you think you know about big title rpgs.  Bravo CDPR, Bravo.

I have not had one single problem with this game at all. No visual bugs, No glitches, No Frame rate drops.  This game, to me is a masterpiece. 10/10  Great job CDPR.

Very easy to recommend this game:  - The overall game is nicely done and finished. If you are off set by some of bugs that were there at launch, compare to Skyrim : Remember that to be an Elder Scroll fan, you have to be able to put with outrageous bugs on release version, cause no Elder Scroll ever came out properly finished. You just have a good company that bring a fun game and work its ♥♥♥ off to provide fixes & content post release. Here, you have the same thing, with way less issues.  - Really feels like a lot of thoughts and details was put in all the aspect of the game. Potions & concotions, horse fighting & fear level, quest & exploration.  - You get a terrific sensation of 'wide world'. I was able to see, far in the distance, some noticeable scenery (a big city & its lights at night, a huge wicked tree) and know that I would be able to go there and visit the place. It's a great feeling. The game is not fully open world, but it's the next best thing.  The game fighting system might not be the hardest one (I'm playing with the prior to last difficulty level, and it's no Dark Soul difficulty), but fighting 'bosses' still feel Witcher like : You can suffer hell or have the easiest time if you prepared yourself carrefully. The card game is a nice touch, although spending time playing card when you have an emergency such as the wild horde is ... weird ?  But overall a great time if you like CRPGs.

This game can be objectively argued to be one of the absolute best fantasy action RPG video games ever made. The story is memorable and very captivating. CDProjekt RED made no mistakes when writing it, especially because of the fact that it is totally non-linear. All the quests are very smooth and don't drag on too long. Even if there is a lot of traveling involved, I have always found it fascinating to ride through unexplored terrain on horseback, even discovering new towns whilst in the middle of a quest, which I may do upon my own bidding. The characters, you may love or you may hate, but they strike emotion, and that is what makes them unforgettable. The world is vast and filled with a myriad of things to explore. It would take hours for me to bore myself looking around the map, let alone a single town. It is very obvious that there was some inspiration from other games, such as Dragon Age: Inquisition and The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. If you have not played either of the first two Witcher games, I recommend you play at least one to familiarize yourself with some of the core elements of the game.  I am afraid , however, I must address the graphics. If you were expecting to play what you saw in the 2013/2014 trailers, then you may be disappointed. The game was heavily optimized to keep frame rates up. In doing thus, the game has become a lot less pretty and overwhelmingly realistic. The foliage is clearly not three dimensional, the hair (even with Nvidia Hairworks) does not look very kosher, and some of the terrain textures look rather grainy. There is still some very beautiful imagery, but overall, it is definitely not up to par with some of the less recent games, like DA: Inquisition. However, this does not take away from the gameplay.  All in all, this game is a marvelous experience and I highly recommend you try it out, graphical downgrade aside.

Some of the controls need work like horses getting stuck on things and surfacing when underwater is a tad tricky if any obstacles are nearby, but it barely detracts from the gameplay. Checkpoints are a godsend compared to the previous games. The visuals are also stunning, and help add to the immersive atmosphere of the game. Graphics, story, character models and voice acting all gel together to create an experience better than any RPG of this type I've played to date. 10/10

Although the open world is huge, it differs from Bethesda's games in that most of the gameplay is located on the surface, rather than in dungeons which are few and far between.

Playing this game gives me the sense of the people behind it. CDPR is a group of people who've understood and mastered their craft. The amount of effort put into this game is staggering and apparent.  This is arguably the best single-player RPG ever made...and to me, CDPR is the Apple of gaming.  This game rises above Skyrim, Dragon Age, and even Baldur's gate, IMO.  - Unmatched depth and length of story - Unique side-quests. Never repetitive, no cheap cookie-cutter quests. - Beautiful voice acting - No expense spared in cutscenes, camera direction. This is as much a movie as it is a game - Unobstructive and appropriate music - Well thought-out UI - Engaging, challenging gameplay. Definitely not a hack-and-slash game.  I'm grateful to have experienced the incredible craftsmanship in this game.

Also, the fights require that you figure out the weaknesses and patterns of the monster(s) you are fighting. The skill system is simple, and lends to some distinct playstyles; you can re-spec with an expensive potion, but putting points into combat skills is pretty much a given. LOTS of side missions and monster hunting; which is well worth it for the weapons that you can acquire during the side missions. The world is MASSIVE, and having fast travel and a mount makes it manageable. Overall, I am about halfway through the main story, and loving every minute of it! A great game 10/10!
