so i haven't finished the story yet but as of now is this game worth buying to you? are you into story driven games? : if yes this game is by far for you. this game is rich into story and every quest and choice you make goes into the game. they story as of now (not gonna spoil anything) for me is amazingly done and i'll keep seeking for more and more of this story as time comes by. this game wont be beaten in one day so you will not have to worry about that at all. i already have 6 hours into this game and i feel like im still just at the begining of the story.  for the combat? i like how the combat is in the game but if you follow the story you'll be taking awhile to see some this game is big into taking up a lot of your time into listening to what you'll need to be doing. if you're not into that either you have to skip what they say or not buy the game at all. to me im fine with it since i love the witcher story but others maybe not like the build up you'll be awaiting.  the graphics in this game is very demanding so if you dont have a great video card you wont get to enjoy the amazing graphics that this game provides atm with a gtx 760 sc and a amd fx 8350 with 16 gigs of ram i can only handle this game on medium quality without having lag come into play. so if you're wanting top end graphics you should probably upgrade your graphics card since this game is very relient on it. if you're useing anything lesser then the gtx 760 im not 100% sure you should buy this game since you might experience a lot of lag.  overall i would recommend to anyone who agrees to what i've just said and it is so far a real worth while buy and since the game is not an online game you'll never need to worry about being stuck in a lobby of a dead game (aka cod aw).

Contracts and side quests are interesting and fun, especially when your task is to retrieve a frying pan. All in all, if you need a game to hold out for you over this summer drought, the witcher is perfect. I never was a fan of release dates. I intend to add on to this review once I can make a proper judgement, but there's simply no reason to lie: This game is wonderful! As a Witcher veteran I can say without any doubt that this is the best game in the series to date.   As of right now, I recommend the game based on this simple fact: It is outstandingly optimized! My PC has a GTX 660 with an i5-4960. I can crank this game up to high and easily hit MY playability threshold (as a person who used to play solely on consoles) of 30 FPS at 1920x1080. CDPR has put painstaking amounts of love into their magnum opus, and it shows in every nook and cranny of the beautifully realized Northern Realms. I intend to make this far more extensive as my adventure unfolds, but as it stands today, my recommendation is quite simple: BUY THIS GAME!  **Edit: May 24, 2015**  IT JUST. KEEPS. GOING! I have NEVER seen a game so deep, rich, and bursting with things to do. Nearly 20 hours in at this point, I have played only 3 story missions. This world is massive and beautiful, yet has a strange way of feeling cramped and horrendous. Life is not easy for the Nordlings, and I, as Geralt, can only do so much to help people. The world's main city, Novigrad, is big enough to be an open world in and of itself. That this game has been defamed by some in the community because it *GASP* doesn't look as good as it did two years ago is a crime. This game is too good to be criticized for something so minute that happens to every game. Yes, it's still beautiful, and the patch released earlier this week improved performance greatly. Especially for those of us who have a mid-range graphics card.  If there is one MINOR criticism I can levy here, it's that leveling up can be quite difficult and tedious at first. Take my advice and go questing before you begin your exploration. You enter the main world at around Level 4, and can quickly find yourself outmatched. Such a criticism really is only a nitpick. This may be the best game I have ever played.

after about 33 hours of play over the past few days I have to say this game is one of the best if not the best games i have played in recent memory. Everything works wonderfully and builds upon itself. the cities, towns, villages, woods and caves all feel natural, dynamic and the scale is immense. in comparison to the previous Witcher games this, in my opinion, is the best one and a great improvement on the other games.  Looking at the negative comments, that are actually about the game and not about crashes (i only crashed once in the first 5 hours and no problems since), many witcher 2 fans are complaining about the combat and potion mechanics. In my opinion the streamlining of combat and potions is a welcome one as Witcher 2's worst aspect was the fairly clunky combat and infuriating potion mechanic where you could only take potions before combat even began (or more likely after you died and had to restart since its hard to predict when you will enter combat). I still love the witcher 2, but the improvements to witcher 3's combat system is what has kept me so engaged in contracts (I love contracts) and hunting down question marks in the search of loot. its also not as if the streamlining of combat/potions ruins the complexity of combat and hunting, there is still a lot of thought that has to go into how you fight and use potions on the higher difficulties.  problems:  if i had a complaint it would be that the way they 'block' you from certain regions is to have incredibly strong enemies block your path which is a smart way of doing so, except that you can get around most of them very easily due to your horse and players who don't take the hint will spend endless hours attempting to complete quests/question marks they are simply not strong enough or good enough to complete. It is the souls approach to telling players they are not ready, but these regions are in areas where fairly low leveled players can easily get to and the difficulty is pretty much one hit you die, so its not really a big problem and i probably wouldn't change it because the other options is invisible walls which is even worse, but still this could have been implemented better.  another aspect i really disliked was how choices were some times (very rarely) to ambiguous and what Geralt did in response was not what i wanted to do. for example, i wanted to save this certain character but the options given were 'I can't let you do that' and 'its suicide', i thought the first option was me saying i can't let you kill yourself while the latter was letting them walk away and most likely die, however the first option started a combat section where i ended up killing the character i wanted to save. I scum saved, the first time i really felt i had to do so because the game didn't make the decision clear, and picked the latter which led me to having the ability to save the character. this is a rare thankfully as most choices are for the most part clear on what you chose and what you are going to do, but it gets annoying when such ambiguous answers are given to you.  these are the only two problems i have with the game and they are very minute, the rest of the game is fantastic from story to game play to graphics (the game still looks amazing even with the 'downgrade' and the performance more than makes up for it, it is probably more important and why the downgrade happened). i highly recommend it as a must buy, even if you are not an RPG fan, you will find something you like.  you might also get addicted/enraged at playing Gwent with NPC's who cheat like dirty....i won't get into it.

This is an update on my first review of the game which i did about 1-2 days into the release. Now that I've completed the game once (and plan to play it again) i feel like i can do better justice to this amazing epic game. Yes there are small minor bugs and there are performance issues for lower end systems but that's to be expected for newer games these days. At the same time thought CDprojekt red is doing their hardest to keep this game relevant and supported for anyone and everyone who is trying to play it on a machine that meets their minimum requirements with constant updates. At the time of me writing this the game is currently on patch 1.04 and they just released two new pieces of free DLC, one cosmetic and another a quest.   What makes this game fantastic is quite simple really, aside from the cutting edge graphical fidelity and the amazingly well crafted open world that the game exists in; the main things that really keep you going are the story and the characters. When i talk about the story I'm not just talking about the main storyline either, which by the way is top shelf, I am also talking about the game's numerous side quests and side missions. Unlike say, dragon age Inquisition's version of side missions, TW3's side quests have many different elements to them that put them well beyond MMO-style quests. Many have interesting and deep plots with twists and turns. For instance, I found a woman who was looking sister. While trying to find her sister I find out that that sister's husband is a werewolf who accidently killed his wife because her sister (the one who gives you the quest) took her to see him to try to scare her away from him so that she could take him all for her self. You than are left with a series of choices that truly beg on your morality as to what to do about the entire situation.   Each of the side quests and the main quest have so much depth that you can tell that some one sat down and put a ton of time and effort into all the minor details to make you feel emotionally invested. When you do engage in a side quest, (no matter how short), you easily get emotionally invested enough to not think its a waste of time to do so. As far as the main quest goes, though the plot is rather simple, (Gerald is looking for some one) the actual execution and story telling is very rich and non-linear making it feel very much like a sequel to the other two witcher games (which it is). If you aren't familiar with the witcher series you can easily get lost with the main story, but this isn't a bad thing because this is after all a sequel. If you haven't played the witcher 1 or 2, I recommend you start there before going on to play this game, to not do so would be robbing you self of some truly unique and great experiences in gaming.   There is a very deep and well made crafting system, a collectible card game that can rival standalone card games like hearthstone, an alchemy system that is just as deep as the crafting system, a well made skill system that makes how you level a choice and of course an extremely detailed open world. TW3 is imo one of the best open world RPG games simply because of how much attention the developers put into the details of that open world. Games like skyrim and oblivion sacrifice the depth of their main storylines in favor of having more content rather then more quality content, while TW3 strikes a nice balance between these two. Not only this but small things like bandits coming to attack a caravan on the trail while you are riding by or monsters attacking a village truly make the world feel dynamic because you can choose to deal with these problems or you can choose to ignore them and the world will keep changing either way. Also, the fact that they chose not to implement a level scaling system for the monsters really helps make the world feel more menacing and keeps the game more difficult. You can easily stumble into an area with monsters that will destroy you if you stray too far away from the path and if you are skilled enough you can still overcome some of these obstacles if you so choose to.  Overall, TW3 is an RPG that no one should miss out on and much like its predecessors, it goes above and beyond all that has come before it in many many ways and sets the bar extremely high for future games.

I don't usually write reviews but i felt i had to for this game..After purchasing this game i have become truely lost and immersed in this beautiful world. It's so huge and open, you just get overwhelmed with the scope of how large the world is! It's not just a large world but a world with so much content...I mean you could just be going for a little ride on your horse and the next minute you will come across a terrifying monster who is guarded something you really want! you could come across a bandit camp...a treasure hunt...a person in need...the list is endless..you can literally get lost in this world.  All the monsters in this game are incredibly terrifying..i mean spine chilling..hair raising terrifying...the way they move, scream and stare at you! It's so beautifully made and horrifying at the same time. The creators of this game deserve so much credit for their art direction  The music wow...the soundtrack of this game is one of the greatest i have ever heard...actually it could well be number one (it's this or skyrim).   Every battle is tense and the gameplay mechanics are superb..every battle is tactical and needs to be thought out, what oil to use? Potion to drink? which signs? Play this on the higher difficulty for a rewarding experience!  Overall, i have to say that this is one of the best games ever made...i seriously recommend this to any gamer who wants to appreciate and get lost in a horrifying yet beautiful world...a world in which they must survive.

The Witcher series is one of my favorites of all time, so I was thrilled to finally play the third installation after what felt like a very long wait. I certainly was not disappointed, and I can easily say that this was my favorite game in the series by far. The Witcher 3 pretty much improves upon everything that the first two games did. The game still keeps its strong narrative and character development that it is known for, as well as adding open world features and refining the combat system. I'd recommend playing it on one of the higher difficulties, because at the lower levels it can be a bit easy. As far as sidequests go, the ones in this game are surprisingly good. I tend to avoid 100% completing games because of how dull sidequests can be a lot of the time, but I enjoyed them all and had no issue with going around and exploring every inch of the world map. The one thing I neglected to do was play the card minigame, Gwent, which just didn't grab hold of me because I don't really enjoy card games in general, but it's definitely worth a try if you are into that sort of thing. Overall, I'd highly recommend this game to anybody that enjoys RPGs. It's a masterpiece.

The Witcher 3 is as dense and deep as anyone could ask for, and the overwhelmingly massive open-world environment has at once made the depth that much more intimidating, and in the long run, more rewarding. It’s not easy to express just how huge and open this world is: verdant, rolling fields liberally dotted with swaying foliage of every shape and size fill the space between loosely connected, ramshackle townships where people struggle to scrape by. A full day/night cycle and dynamic weather pull it all together, cementing The Witcher 3’s landscape as one of the most authentic-feeling open worlds; feels better than Elder Scrolls ever did. There is a handy minimap that points you to where you want to go, which might seem like a crutch, but honestly, without it, I’d have been hopelessly lost. Though the straightforward and fetch-quest-heavy main story is a bit much, the option of joyfully adventuring through a rich, expansive open world was always there for me to wonder around in and goof off when I started to burn out. And while the plot isn’t too terribly interesting overall, the many characters that play a part in it are, and along with the excellent combat and RPG gameplay, it moves The Witcher 3 to a new level few other RPGs inhabit.

I wanted to write a lengthily and detailed review about how much I love this game. But I don't think any number of words can truly captivate how much I enjoyed this compelling and beautiful experience.   Dislaimer: I did not play the Witcher 1 or 2. You can still pick up and enjoy this game with no prior experience, especially if you do a little reading on the previous games.   Breath taking environments. Atmospheric. Gorgeous.   Quests -- both main and side -- that make you think and make hard decisions that can shape how the game plays out. I've never been so engaged in quests. I paid attention to every single one I came across, even the seemingly insignificant side quests. Some were brutal. Some were tragic. Some were sad. Some were humorous. And some were even happy. Emotions were evoked.   Much of the dialogue is clever. The characters are well crafted and interesting. They often respond to your actions and choices with their own persona. The voice acting is great. And the colorful language used is hilarious in its own right.   Ciri. My favorite thing about this game was the vibrance and attitude of Ciri. And Geralt in the Feline armor set. And his hair. And Ciri's eyes. And the story. And the quests. And all the question marks on the map to find. And the fluid animations. And Roach. This game was my favorite thing about this game.  But truly. This is a masterpiece with so much thought and love and care put into its creation. It is master story telling. Gripping. Engaging. Provoking. Every time I took a 'wrong' turn I was devastated. At the very end I repeated to myself what I wanted the ending to be and hoped for it because it meant that much -- after 100hrs I needed a good ending!  My only gripes are minor. Some of the controls are clunky when you are in tight spaces or trying to loot boxes. Occassionally there is a graphic glitch -- like seeing people walking in the background during a cutscene with their hand's missing. Or Ciri missing her scabbard in some scenes. Or some decor on characters vibrating/jiggling. All of which are forgivable and don't break the game. The dev's release patches every so often, which is always a good sign. Speaking of signs, I will agree with others that the combat is a bit repetitive. But there are times it feels truly epic and challenging. And this combat isn't meant to be flashy with tons of flourish and effects and combo button mashing.   10/10 would spend another 100hrs lost in this game.

What's wrong with Witcher 3: - Horse riding isn't as much fun as it could be. The horse stops on every small bush and getting it running again takes time. It's in seconds, but when you do it often, it gets tedious.  - There are a few invisible walls here and there which is ridiculous that we have them in 2015-.   Everything else is AWESOME. Especially playing Gwent.

Not just a game,but an experience.  Pros- +100 plus hours of content.Not much of it is filler. +Consistently good voice acting and writing.Gone are the days of one note voice delivery from witcher 2.  +The plot isn't terribly interesting.But a few flashback missions in Ciri's shoes do give a sense of motivation,and help to understand why Geralt wants to find this woman and why she's worth it. +All of the characters are superbly done.These aren't your typical two dimensional characters.Their dialogues and their reaction to your decisions give them their own personality. +Intimate and funny moments. +A vast land with a unique feel to each. +Choices and their impact are visible throughout.Even the side quests have a bearing on the main quest. +An excellent,long and well paced campaign. +Side quests are typically excellent and feel that they been crafted with the same love as given to the main quest. +Monster Contracts.They bring about that 'batman/la noire' detective feel which usually culminate with a satisfying battle with a monster. +Gameplay has been hugely improved.Signs,swordplay and dodge make a satisfying combination to take down enemies.Fights are at their best when they are in an open ground. +Rewarding exploration. +Looting and crafting gears and potions. +Meet 'gwent'.Probably the best minigame I have played +16 dlc's free.  Cons- -This is not quite a negative as the game has a difficulty scale but the it is pretty easy on the normal difficulty.You wouldn't be quite needing those potions and ingredients that forms a major part of the gameplay.  -Annoying witcher sense camera which locks on to an over the shoulder view. -Horse controls *facepalm*.  Score-9.5/10 It is not without it's flaws but Witcher 3 is a must play and absolutely deserves to be picked up at full price.

After playing the first two games and reading all the books I was finally ready to play The Witcher 3 and it was an amazing experience, CDProjekt Red really outdid themselves on this release, the game has won several GOTY awards and really deserves them. This is the best fantasy single-player RPG so far, the story is a strong point in the game and storytelling flows really well, characters have strong identities and show life-like emotions and the universe is heveily influenced by elements of Eastern European folklore. Gameplay wise it is a smooth experience, combat is really fluid and character movement feels great when set to alternative mode (please DO NOT use the default mode unless you want to feel as you were playing an overweight bear sliding on ice), the equipment system is greatly improved from the previous games and armor sets gives cool bonuses compared to other items. The crafting system is also improved and has been made easier for the better, some may find it too casual but the way it is really encourages players to use potions and oils during fights, which are really useful in higher difficulties.  If you look for a rich story in an open world and a solid gameplay experience you could easily spend several dozens of hours enjoying The Witcher 3 and its latest expansion Hearts of Stone which adds roughly a dozen of hours of gameplay aswell.  There is a NewGame+ mode which allows to restart the game keeping your character progression and gear including money and alchemy recipes.

I just finished Witcher 3. Here's what I thought. (tl;wr: Everything Fallout & Skyrim wishes they could be. Dark, realistic world, engaging story, VERY accessible to players new to the franchise. This is how open world should be done. 9/10)  The world is dark and realistic. You are a Witcher, a monster hunter, wandering a war torn land as astride your trusty Roach. You travel from town to town collecting bounties for slaying forktails, breaking curses, and knocking off the odd griffin while searching for your 'daughter'. It's a huge, expansive world, yet it feels full rather than big for bigness sake. Each side quest has enough of a story to make it interesting and fit with the world. You are often confronted with choices, but rarely is it a choice between clearly good and clearly evil, i.e. 'A) Save the orphanage, B) Light the orphanage on fire'. The choices are more often 'You can save the orphanage, but by the way one of the orphans is Hitler.'  Not many developers could make an RPG this story intensive yet still accessible to new players. In fact, coming in on the third episode I had no right to expect to have any idea what was going on. I was pleasantly surprised. The story unfolds in an organic way that gently guides you into this world. It gets you invested in these characters, hinting at enough of the old history so you have your bearings yet not drowning you in monologues. The world is dark but not oppressive.  The way the ending you receive is revealed in a similar way to the old Fallout 1 & 2 games. The choices which influenced this ending were not usually broadcast in neon lights or big signs (a la Mass Effect, though I do love those games too) but instead just kind of felt like you playing Geralt the way you thought he ought to be played. It felt very satisfying.  I'd give this game a 9/10. Objectively, I'd rate it as a better RPG than FF6 or KOTOR and that's saying something.

Updated 1/25/16 to be a little less... jaded. Now, it goes down smooth with less bitter aftertaste!  TL;DR: I found this game to be quite button-mashey and cutscene-heavy. I still call the first 1/3 of the game a semi-interractive eye-candy dispenser with a 'B movie' story; it LITERALLY feels like an episode of 'Hercules: The Legendary Journeys.' If you're a fan, you've already got this game, so why are you reading this review? If you're into Swords, dragons, wizards and scantilly-clad brunettes, this will do a smashing job of tantillizing your medieval receptor cortex.   The Long Version:  I recently finished a 300hour marathon of Fallout 4 (not the best game by a LONG shot; dont' get me wrong here, it catered to a different audience entirely), and was itching for something newer than Skyrim, set in medieval times. This looked fun, and was on sale, so I gave it a play.  The first thing I noticed about this game was how insanely long the cutscenes are. The first 30min of the game are nothing but boring movies. Oh, they're gorgeous, in-game-rendered movies, but movies none-the-less. Now, I don't mind a cutscene here-or-there, but I REALLY don't much care for cutscenes in games; they rip me out of the game world and take whatever feeling of immersion I had, and toss it aside. It's not just the beginning of the game, either; cutscenery is very prolific in this world. Basically, the main quest appears to be a mildly-interractive cutscene, reminiscent of the FMV games of yore, but with vastly more gameplay.   The second thing is that the names of nouns are difficult exclusively for the sake of being difficult. I'm not going to remember that Riverghaagdakstead is North of Lokriouamshijiar. I'm not going to recall that I recently acquired a Karmorgaluptilation Sword, am wearing Helengahasdiohtor armor, Jilijimijiuiniji's Boots, and need to eat a Krheim Tussel to heal. Perhaps the names are real places in history, with a real language behind them. To a yankee-doodle like me, the names are just difficult and strongly detract from my gaming experience. When my friends tell me about their adventures in this game, they always go 'I got this one sword,' or 'I found this piece of armor,' or 'That one place with the crumbled red-brick castle,' becasue the names, however authentic, aren't something we're easily able to remember. IT MAKES TALKING ABOUT THIS GAME HARD!  Gameplay-wise, it controls okay-ish. Honestly, I feel that the controls are rather clunky feeling. I rationalize 'the clunk' as the developers attempting to simulate actual human/equestrian movement; you're not just a camera on a stick, no, you're Geralt of Rivia (or a horse), and you can't just move on a whim in whichever direction you please, thanks to inertia and animation-limitations; no, you move LIKE A REAL, LIVING HUMAN (or horse)! That's excellent attention to detail on CD Projekt's behalf, but in reality, this all boils down to rather extreme input lag. Frustrating input lag. Nevermind that Geralt only walks calmly when he's in a bit that requires him to; The rest of the time, he goes from 0 - full jogging-speed, no inbetween. Obviously, that's a binary keyboard control scheme. So, I plug in y'old Logitech F310, and give it a try. On the analog sticks, he has 2-speeds on the stick. NOT analog movement; 2-speed. I sincerely hope this is/was a bug that will/has been rectified; we haven't had awkward 2-speed controls since the days of the PSone transitioning to analog sticks.  Combat is very dazzling and acrobatic. Geralt autotargets whichever enemy is within the detection circle, or whichever he is most facing. Battle, although at times requiring you to use special potions/salves/whatever magic is called in this game/items rapidly degrades into what feels like an auto-aiming 'Devil May Cry' button-mash, with Geralt suddenly whipping, spinning, whirling, dancing, flipping, jumping, hacking, slashing and eviscerating the n'er-do-wellers. Tactics (ambushing, hiding) are very difficult to pull off, since everything is 3rd person (not that this game is about such nonsense, because it isn't!) The real challenge is trying to figure out what 'trick' you need to perform to beat the baddie(s); what's it weak against, and do I posess any?   Grumble, grumble, grumble... This game is exclusively 3rd person. I strongly dislike this aspect; it serves VERY little purpose, aside to show-off the hairFX. It instantly makes any aiming or precision movement a very delicate and involved task. Geralt takes up considerable real-estate on the screen, too, so it's not just a slight nuisance, but a real problem. Most of the time is spent navigating the camera so you can see what's going on in front of the protagonist, since his gloriously rendered dorsal fin is always in the way. Goodness, imagine if you could only see things that were 20-feet in front of you, because you had something Geralt-sized blocking the lower-region of your peripherary.... that'd be awful, and is in this game, too. Just an opinion; a preference; a flavor. If staring at Geralt's manly backside doesn't bother you, or if you actually enjoy it, good for you; standing in a checkout/lunch line must be the highlight of your day!  The item system. Let's boil it down real simple-like: Sword 1a does 10-15 DMG, and Sword 1b does 9-16 DMG, and sword 1c does 11-13 DMG. They're the same sword, just different DMG, Diablo style! *SPECIAL* sword 1 requires a SPECIFIC person to forge it, rendering it almost obsolete by the time you get it, but TOTALLY gives you cred with the smitty crowd. Herbs and spices make potions, bombs, different herbs and spices, and forging materials. Master Hunter Diapers can be weaker than normal Hunter Diapers, Diablo style. It was explained to me that 'if one person made many items, they could be of different qualities, depending on how he felt at that time, or how rushed he was.' honestly, it feels like the item system is a rather early alpha test of the Diablo system, that got hacked and pirated somewhere in China, then got marketed on eBay as the latest version. The item system suits its purpose; it stops the game from becoming a grind-fest, and it gives you the motivation you need, in order to hunt down monsters. Although.... it would have been SUPER cool if it had a true Diablo item system (prefix, item type, suffix, item modifier [legendary/magic/set/unique/common])... but I can't be critical of something it CAN'T have (right?).  Overall, this game feels like it has had a LOT of effort put into it; lots of attention to details, which most games are missing these days. It Seriously NEEDS A STICKER that advertises the fact that it has at least 2-scoops MORE LOVE than the competing brand. That being said, I suppose there is some sort of triangle to be had, between gorgeous graphics, a deep story, and excellent gameplay mechanics; you can pick any 2 you like, or interpolate a tertiary mixture thereof. The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt seems to be shifted strongly towards graphics and story, and somewhere in the middle for gameply. Not a bad game; there are many, many, many worse abominations called 'games' that never should have been produced. Everyone lauds this game and CD Projekt One, but I personally wish that Rockstar had worked their GTA5 magic on this one; it might have played better and been seemless, still retaining the cutscenes and curly-haired goth gals, et al. Then again, Geralt may have been transformed into a medieval middle-aged man having a mid-life crisis in middle earth, while in the middle of his bathing session, or something to that effect. B+

Cons:  -The game can stutter from time to time and optimisation could be better - Has a LOT of side quests. Truly a marvel of an RPG, sitting proud with the kings of the genre.  An engaging world with unique and interesting characters around each corner, terrifying monsters, side quests that pull at your heartstrings, some even spanning the length of an average AAA title at times.  The main story line itself is filled with moments of joy, sadness and laughter, it's hard to know what to expect with each step of the story.  The world has incredible attention to detail and surprisingly not a single repeated voice actor for any quest NPCs (seriously Bethesda step it up) which is a huge achievement and helps with immersion. The first moment you enter the isles of Skellige and see a sunset over the snowy mountaintops is breathtaking.  The gameplay is enjoyable and fluid, far more so than the prior game which had issues with animation locks. The addition of a small sidestep helps to avoid attacks where a roll is unecessary, and allows room for brutal finishers. Or you can just forget that, grab some bombs and go full alchemist and blow everything up instead.  Seriously an absolutely incredible achivement which would make even the harshest video game critic admit that games are an artform. Must buy for any RPG fans.

159 hours, that is what it took me to beat The Witcher 3, plus Hearts of Stone and the Blood and Wine expansions. I've never been one to play a single player game that long without becoming bored, but The Witcher 3 somehow managed to keep me interested in this world. This is hands down one of my favourite games. There's way too much to this game to get into any detail as to why I think this one of the greatest games made. One thing I will say is Blood and Wine was an amazing finale to an amazing game. In my opinion if you ever play The Witcher 3, playing through the Blood and Wine expansion is a MUST. Geralt is placed in this beautiful new world to explore and the main questline is a huge step forward from the rest of the game. The final quest is by far my favourite, so please keep playing to the end! It is definitely worth it!  To the developers CD Projekt RED I cannot thank you enough for what you have created here. It is truly a masterpiece! I will look forward to see any future games you guys make!

However shortly after playing post install of the DLC I suddenly had massive frame rate drops and lags, sometimes with several seconds looking at the same screen. I was previously running the game on Ultra with no issues and nothing I have tried, lowering graphics, verifying the cache, several solutions from posts around the internet and reinstalling the entire game, has worked. It breaks my heart as this is an incredible game that has been rendered completely unplayable thanks to my wasted $20. If you are a gambler get he DLC it seems like it should be a ton of fun but if you don't want to risk spend $20 to ruin an entire game then steer clear.

Holy ♥♥♥♥! I remeber back when I played the Witcher 2 how I had hoped for an open world Witcher Game, that combines a lot of characters and plot from the previous game, while still innovating on the origional 'Witcher' design. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was not expecting this! The Witcher 3 is a masterfully crafted game, where most if not all choices affect the ending. One of my favorite aspects of the Wither 3 is the progression in how you craft items, brew potions, and increase your magic ability. In the beginning, you feel a little underpowered for such an infamous man. However, as you get farther into the game, you start to really develop your magical ability, weaponry, and armor, you start to feel your place in the world. You are not the most powerful person in the world, but you definately influence the area arround you. towards the beginning of the game you start to have to figure out what role you want to play, whether you want to focus more on magic, or get most of your power from potions, or if you want to do what I did and get everything. I reccommend taking your time with this game, as progression is slow, but very enjoyable. As for the story, the story was phenomenal. Each mission was unique, fun, and had some tie-in to how you would affect the end of the game. Now, I reccommend doing ALL of the side quests right when you can. At first I went to fast and skipped over and missed several side quests. For those who dont know, after you progress far enough into a crucial plot moment, most of your sidequests will be marked as a failure, so do them while you can. As for end game, there isnt much to do. All the sde quests are finished, and there is no way to go back and do them, unless you've been saving along the way. The only thing left to do are the monster hunts, and gwent. The monster hunts get kinda old after the first one or two, however if you are loking for that 'full game completion' they are necessary for that achievement. Gwent has just been given its own stand-alone game due to the love people had for it in The Witcher 3. I am not one for card games, although I do think it's cool that the devs actually came up with an all new game, with tons of unique cards to play with. Overall, I would rate my experience with The Wither 3 Wild Hunt a 10/10! I loved the story, the sidequests are tons of fun and are shrouded in mysterys sometimes. There is so much to do and explore, and I never had any hardware issues with the game. It has ALWAYS (from day one) run perfectly. So, if you havn'e already, pick up this game, GET IT. I know its not the $60.00 retail it used to be, and it is definately worth the investment.

I played Fallout 4 straight after this. It was okayish, but not more. It flatout paled in comparison to The Witcher 3. After that, i played Dragon Age: Inquisition in order to get my RPG buzz back on. Well, it was a dud and i couldn't bring myself to care at all for the nameless inhabitants of what ever this world is called. Geralt of Rivia just showed up, suckerpunched my bland whatshisface-hero from Dragon Age and then silently retreated back into mist of that part of my brain that is usually reserved the memory of my great moments in life. Geralt probably did away with some of those too - Goodbye, Tour through North Africa, see you, memorys of Las Vegas, don't hit the door on your way out, first girlfriend - everytime i try to think of you now, i see a whitehaired dude in armor giving a frying pan to a grandma...   I played this twice. I enjoyed the hell out of it twice. I skipped work i REALLY should have done more often than that because of this game.   And what do they do? They push out two DLC which are even better than the main game at times. Just producing the best antagonist in Hearts of Stone that every saw a screen while bottleflipping.   CD Project Red, congratulations. You just shot yourself in the foot by setting the bar so high that even CJ with a Jetpack can't get over it. Have fun doing your next game where you have to meet skyhigh expectations which you probably meet and ruining RPG's of the next generation, too. Maybe not just RPG's.   Don't, i repeat - DON'T play this game if you're still planning on having fun with other RPGs.

The Witcher 3 is an adult themed action adventure role playing open world game with some changes to the traditional RPG formula, overall this is a near perfect game that exceeds in all aspects, the map is huge with a sheer amount of content, the quests are vast and different from each other, game length wise you are looking at about 50 hours for the main story, a 90 hours for all the side quests, over a 170 for the dlc main and side quests, doing a completionist run can easily take you about 210 plus hours, there are a lot of memorable characters and moments through the game (both funny and serious), and it features CCG minigame that its becoming a thing on its own (gwent/gwint).  The adult themed part it’s something that you should really consider, a lot of games decide to take a childish but safer approach, whereas The Witcher 3 really took a risk that not only worked but separated it entirely from his competition in a good way, it’s not edgy nor it feels too serious.  The game has two expansions, Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine, originally priced as $10 and $20 US dollars, both expansions are bigger than most single player AAA games on the market.   -Hearts of Stone it’s about making reality some impossible requests from a character, that has, in a way, made a deal with the devil, including attending a party while being possessed by a ghost, and making a heist in The Witcher 3 style, both are epic and worth remembering, it features two different endings that are up to your own interpretation.  -Blood and Wine, gameplay wise this is a huge expansion with a lot of content that makes you feel like starting the game again, story wise this new peaceful-esque land were honor and heraldry are part of everyday life serves as a contrast towards the previous game lands with its different ongoing conflicts, but with some twists already happening but no one noticing, this expansion also serves as an epitome to the Geralt character as well as his proper retirement (he’s 90-100 years old).  The developers of the game (CD Project Red) have delivered us a turn point of what a videogame should be, they have also raised the bar of how you should treat your customer; 16 pieces of free dlc no problem, worth buying dlc and mod support sure, delaying the game to polish it more absolutely, they even made a DRM free version of the game.  You mention near perfect, what about it? IMO there are three minor flaws the game has;  -The overall navigation of the game menus; its a huge game, all entries will be full and its going to be bloated and tedious to navigate later on. -Unbalanced Witcher gear; the game features different sets of Witcher gear with different proprieties, the problem is, that, this particular kind of gear has superior proprieties that most of the game gear, even rare pieces of equipment, however, there is a mod that fixes this. -Fast travel system (I know this one is a bit controversial); you cant just fast travel anywhere, you need to be near a sing post, and while there are many out there this can be annoying on higher levels since you are going to be carrying a lot of loot while being in the middle of nowhere, and walking/galloping towards the nearest sign post can be a bit of a pain, again there is a mod, but be careful because it breaks some quests if you fast travel on particular areas were you shouldnt have been able to do it.  TL;DR: The Witcher 3 is a masterpiece with some minor flaws, the expansions alone are worth more than a lot of games out there, its devs are awesome and delivered what they promised.

Okay I guess I'm really late for a review, and this will probably be forgotten in the depths of the steam community praising this game. But c'mon, it's the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The most awarded game ever to this date that this review was written. Think about that for a sec. That means something doesn't it? So, enough chattering.  Music, graphics, mechanics, story, gameplay, minigame, DLC. Just a few things that really surprised me for being really good. Well okay, graphics was obvious from the screenshots I saw. The music is beautifully made to the atmosphere in most cut scenes. As well as the voice lines. Also, surprisingly well made are the mimics of the characters in the cutscenes. However somehow Geralt never freakin blinks when you're actually plaing. What a beast.  Gameplay is very smooth. Here and there you might see some bugs, but for an open world game of this size it is acceptable. Today's standarts are still low right?  Story was hearttouching, cute, awesome... yeah just all in all really great. The overall variety of feelings I've experienced during the story were more than I expected. I mean, who cries over a video game right? Okay it was me... Ain't gonna spoil anything though.  So I just wrote a bunch of stuff that really amazed me, made me play through the whole game. Made me collect stuff and buy the GOTY edition. Seriously, if you buy it, then buy the GOTY edition. The DLCs are so cheap compared to what they deliver. Especially Blood and Wine. It's a shame there isn't a third one (yet?). Praises to CD Projekt Red. They deserved all the attention and money they got from this game. I only played it once though, so gotta have to play it at least two more times, like I did with Skyrim.  10/10

Simply put, this game is one of the best games made, ever. Some quick Pros and Cons off of the top of my head.  Pros:  * The game is quite lengthy. If you are somewhat of a completionist, it can take 100+ hours to finish just the base game! A great value for what you pay, especially since this game frequently goes on sale.  * The game gives you characters that you will be emotionally attached to.  * Your decisions in the story aren't black and white and easily chosen. Sometimes, you'll sit back and think about the meaning of an event in the game a little more than you would with other games. * Extremely beautiful game.  * Soundtrack and Voice Acting is also quite amazing. * TWO Bonus DLCs (if you buy Game of the Year Version, or Season Pass) which will add a whole lot more hours to your game!   Neutral: * Combat system is not great, but it's not terrible either.  * Riding your Horse (Roach) can sometimes be slightly annoying, but not a huge deal.  * You may or may not feel the game gets a little repetitive, as it is essentially open-world with lots of collectibles/treasures and side quests to complete. This may be something you like, or it may be something you dislike.   Cons: * The ending of the story was not finished cleanly, in my opinion. (Endgame felt rushed, loose ends hanging. It felt like the story rapidly reached its conclusion instead of slowly easing into the final parts of the game).  * Loading times may be slightly on the long side, especially after dying (usually from falls), although this is probably not a problem if you have an SSD. * Start of the game is really really slow (in terms of level progression), but QUICKLY speeds up as you progress. The leveling and item system can be a little confusing sometimes as well.   Overall, this game is a masterpiece, especially given how many big AAA games released nowadays have many issues such as framerate or graphics issues, gameplay issues, releasing half-finished games with the other half as DLC, etc.  Witcher 3 is a clean game where you'll be happy to see that you get (vastly more) than you paid for and expected. A true gem, and a great game fully deserving of all of its awards and praise.  Final Rating: 9.5/10

I purchased this game last month, and I've just not got around to writing a review for it after about 70 hours of gameplay. This is without a doubt, the biggest masterpiece of a game I've ever played in my life (and I'm 40 years old). After 70 hours, I've just completed the main quest, have seemingly infinite amounts of other things still left to do, and still have all of the DLC campaigns to go! I honestly cannot believe people are so talented that they can create a game such as this. The quests and new content just never end, everywhere I go I find something new, a new quest, new characters, on and on. To get the best experience, do like I do: don't fast travel much, and make it a habit to walk to the majority of your destinations. You will find so much content by doing this that would otherwise be lost by fast traveling. Seek out and explore all the question marks (?) on the maps, etc. I honestly cannot think of one bad thing to say about this game, it's the absolute pinnacle of human gaming development. Amazing.

So, I thought I was well versed in RPG's and great storytelling. I was wrong, very wrong.   After dabbling a little in the great but clunky Witcher 1 and 2, I found myself back in the shoes of Geralt. I went into the game expecting more of the same, great story but was apprehensive about the gameplay and boy was I blown away. Combat flows like an elegant dance, as does the story.   Dialogue options have weight, I've become wary of how my actions might unfold later into the game and I couldn't be happier, it's what I've wanted in a game from the offset.   Graphically, the game is astoundingly beautiful running on Ultra settings on my 980ti with a buttery smooth framerate, and performance as a whole is fantastic, the game takes almost no time at all to boot up to menu on HDD and although initial load times can be a minute or so further load times (on death, large area changes) don't seem to hit the minute mark very often.   I couldn't recommend this game more and hope somebody finds this useful in some way.

What to say that hasn't already been said... Alright. I think I've got something.   The adventures of the grim-faced double-sword toting man with a heart of gold and eyes of a... something, whom I named Poppycock, started rather meagerly. I collected every bit of scrap a monster dropped, horded like I was auditioning for Horders, and generally tried to craft everything myself. But even crafting with just a wee bit o help from crafters becomes frustrating because gold always seems in scarce supply.  'But Poppycock,' I hear enthusiasts for the game cry out, 'You can get gold from questing!' And indeed I could... If I hadn't decided to play mega-paragon and decline every gold offer I had the chance of turning down - which was a surprisingly large amount. It astounded me how many times I could say no to a quest reward. I suspect there's a point in the game where gold becomes a quest-required thing, so this probably isn't the best idea, but the feel-goods shouldn't be in there if they're just meant to punch you in the gut later. *Side note, THANKS FABLE 3 for killing all my citizens. Thought I had 100 days more to sort out the mess and become a bard made of gold, turned out I had 0*  So eventually I figured out the in-between path, where I sold everything that isn't in some way magical, or a relic, or whatever that jar of purple stuff is I keep in my pack for some reason. It works, and in all honesty I have no regrets. Only thing I ended up crafting these first 10 hours was a pair of swords that did ungodly amounts of damage, and all the scarce materials that I needed I had. Sure I had to buy iron ingots but... meh.  Anyway, Poppycock and I will keep you updated. I could talk about the difficulty of turning 180 degrees in this game, or the finnicky way the camera requires you to face just the right way and distance from something to pick it up, but I feel that others could say it better.  Chapter 2: Poppycock's Dark Age  So Poppycock left the beginning hamlet, and came upon Yennefer. Only for her to leave again. Back to adventure!   *Record screech*  Roach? When did you come back? You're... alive? YOU'RE ALIVE! OMG I CAN'T BELIEVE THIS!  *Dismounts Roach. Leaves him there forever.* Bye horse!  So Poppycock continued his adventure. He went to meet a spy, dug around in a dead man's shoes, met a big fat drunk man, and went looking for some girl. I dunno, she probably matters.  He saved his file at a friendly bonfire. Seemed familiar.  And so Poppycock went to fill the edges of his map. And so he did. The first ? was a camp full of bandits and -  Poppycock woke again at his bonfire. Go anywhere but south, he promised himself.  12 hours later, he had killed many enemies, acquired numerous weapons, and he returned to that bandit camp. With a smile. And death. Many songs were sung about the Devil's Pit. Some believe it got it's name for the big bloody hole in the center. But others whisper of a devil named Poppycock. He who slaughters all, and will kill you if you speak his name aloud.  At level 12, Poppycock found a level 24 tree man. And they fought. All went well until the tree man called a pack of level 24 wolves. They promptly devoured him.  He then liberated a fort which was quickly taken over by soldiers. They seemed happy enough, until he looted a sheepskin from a nearby chest. Then they beat the life out of him, stole half his coin, and sent him on his way. What a strange way to treat your savior. Poppycock dismissed it as a local tradition.  He then unleashed a kindly girl spirit into the world. She seemed innocent enough. I mean, if you forget the whole boyfriend-killing thing.  He also killed a talking tree. Wood don't got nothing on the Poppycock.  And finally he remembered. He had to save the girl.  Stay tuned for chapter 3!

There is nothing new in this game. Everything was already in the other games.  HOWEVER, the overall attention to the details is just mind blowing. It was made by people with passion. The Witcher 3 was their beloved child. You can feel this in the storyline. You can hear this in the music. You can see this in the visuals.  Yes, there are some glitches like the steering issues. And it could become repetetive if you skip the main quest and just start exploring the map. But then, you meet the drag queen elf, who is the clothes designer and want to sell you something from his summer collection. And you are back in the game.  Masterpiece.

First off, if you're considering playing this and haven't played the first two I strongly suggest you play the others first. Many parts in the story are MUCH BETTER experienced as opposed to just being 'caught up' and you'd also be missing two great games. In a summary, W3 is an open world RPG that has a very rich story line. As opposed to Witcher 2, you are not limited to which zone you are in as long as you've unlocked the others through story.   Combat: (4/5) I think this is by far the best in the series with combat. There are a few issues of course (auto-sword selection and terrain difficulties during combat for example), however I've never really felt challenged in the former 2 Witchers. In this you'll find enemies constantly trying to flank, multiples attacking at the same time, and you actually need to prepare for quite a few battles with potions and reading about the enemy type. Swordplay is pretty smooth, plus a very nice selection of the standard witcher spells, and an array of bombs and side arms is at your disposal.  Character: (4/5) Character creation is pretty detailed and you get the standard choice of Swordplay, chemically enhanced, magical, or a mixed Witcher. The game works off the usual level-up perk and armor system, though your mutagen enhancements have been changed and imo improved. I don't think the perks are as strong as W2, but that could be part of the added challenge that I've been enjoying so much.  Story: (5/5) Geralt has always been one of my favorite characters and dialog wise I would put him close to the original DMC 1-3 Dante. Not quite as spirited, but just as funny and sarcastic. This will be a rich adult rated story. There are quite a few moral decisions, though don't expect the simplicity of Fable on these. Even the most honorable intentions can lead to horrible results.   Beauty: (4.5/5) I'm being a bit elitist with this rating, but I want it to be accurate. This game is gorgeous with character detail, weather, and creatures. I playing it on my brand new rig on Ultra detail and I was very impressed, until my brother pointed something out. Unfortunantly, still on Ultra, the trees and landscape have a tad bit of 2D look to them. I personally wouldn't have noticed, but whats a good review without accuracy...  In summary I would highly suggest this game. The Witcher series in general captured me a long time ago and I am very pleased with this one now. Much more freedom in game combined with the same great story we've come to know. If you're like me this won't be measured in game hours played as much as play-throughs completed.

MOST RECOMMENDED   It's simply the best RPG around. The Witcher games always topped with graphics and the more mature story-telling of a world that ain't shaded in black and white only. This time it's an open world to explore and even the side quests are as entertaining and well done as the main quest (some even better).   Of course there are the usual generic map objects as in all open world games: monster nests, ruins, hidden treasures etc. but with one big difference: you don't need to collect em all to get to a whopping 150+ hours of playtime! I just did those on my way and those needed to clear for witcher school armour and weapon sets.  I assume that I cleared about 33-40% of these markers but I did every witcher contract and secondary quest (but Gwent collector) and ended up on 163 hours premium gameplay.  If you're into RPGs you probably own the game already and if you're just curious then this is the best RPG to start with.

This has been my GotY -- I'd need 10 pages to go into detail about all the things I love in Witcher 3.  I'm currently getting going on my second play through now that New Game + has been released as DLC. I love the combat, I love the story, the game itself is gorgeous... but one of the things that keeps me coming back is the incredible sense of immersion and atmosphere. The wind, the weather, the way the light creeps through -- playing Witcher 3 makes me feel like a kid again, working my way through my grandparents' 60 acres of woods. It's just enjoyable to hop in the game, even if I only have 15 minutes to spare, and do a side quest or two while enjoying the combat and scenery.   I don't know how many hours I'll spend in my replay, but I want to see everything this game has to offer. I'm guessing I'll still be playing Witcher 3 a year or two from now.

This game won game of the year for a reason. One of the best modern RPG's to date. It reminds me very much of Dragon age series, and Skyrim.  There are too many good things to mention, so instead I will make a list of areas that needed improvement.  -Targeting, interacting with a specific object when multiple objects are close together is a pain. I got pretty fed up with turning candles on and off.  -Repetative sidequests. Some of the sidequests had compelling stories in their own right for sure, but plenty of contracts and other sidequests were very go to X location kill Y thing, return for a tiny unexciting reward.  -After completion of the main quest, the most important NPCs are all missing and the game world is treated like you havent completed the mission yet. Other than the cutscene after you complete the game, none of those choices have an impact on the game world.  -Movement both in combat and out feels slugish. I know that it is part of the style, but honestly if I am standing on a ledge and want to turn around I don't normally have to take 3 steps to accomplish this. The same is applied to hoarses, I feel like I am driving a tank sometimes that cant seem to navigate around rocks and sticks even though a real horse would dodge those types of obstacles without your intervention.   I am very much annoyed that Geralts story is over. I enjoyed the game immensely and even though CDPR said this was not the end of the series, it is indeed the end of Geralt.

It is a well made RPG(Game of the Year worthy of course) and should be given a try to anyone who plays games on a regular basis.

This is easily the best RPG I've ever played, if not the best game I've ever played. There is an insane amount of detail that went into making this game. NPCs react to the weather and actions you do, fresh food will not be found in dungeons, the trees sway in the wind violently. I could go on and on, but I want to keep this short. The graphics are some of the best out there. The combat feels great, and flows well. You can easily switch from your sword, to your signs (spells), and back to your sword. Now for the best part of the game: the story. The story telling in this game is great. One of the best out there. It easily ranks up, if not exceeds Bioware's and Telltale's story telling. I got really attached to Geralt and the people he met through his travels. So prepare for a feeltrip in this game. There's so much content in this game that it puts other current title's content to shame. Even he $10 DLC has more content than most $60 games out there. As of 93 hours played when I'm writing this review, I'm still no where near done with this game. I still have a lot more to do, and I wanna play the story all over again. To wrap this up, this game deffinitely deserves your time and money. You will not regret buying this game. It deffinitely deserves to hold the title of Game of the Year.  Edit: Fixed grammatical and spelling errors.

As I write this review, I'm straining to think of a single major fault with this game. Quite simply, it does everything it needs to do with style and aplomb. Diverse skill trees, a well told story, challenging combat that's never unfair, three-dimensional characters, and pristine presentation all culminate to give you a game that is well worth the asking price, and then some.  This is the unqualified best game of 2015, and easily the best open world game I've played since Skyrim.

Unlike in Other Rpgs, Witcher 3 : Wild Hunt revolves around siding between Evil or.. well Less Evil. The game will be testing you of your morality to which is the perpetrator and which is the victim. Choice is yours if you want to roleplay geralt; the main protagonist as a Anti-non human or as a Bridge between Monsters and Humans, he carries 2 swords with him  A Silver sword(for Non-humans) and a Steel sword(for humans) but one thing is certain both of them are for Monsters.  Build Geralt as a Potion/Spells- Witcher or as a Sword/Archery or WHY NOT ALL?!  The game might limit you to not been able to customize Geralt but the game is more focus on the experience of YOU being in the Shoes of a Witcher,so sadly no facial/booty customization

Absolutely an outstanding game.   I've made it to level 7 and can't put it down. The story is immersive and draws you in. I usually find myself skipping the story, but not this one. The open world side quests have not felt repetitive. The graphics are AMAZING from the terrain to the character faces. Combat is challenging. At first I was frustrated with 'operating' my character, but I've found it just takes time to build the skill. Load times between deaths are long, but that's the only penality you face for dying. I'll take that as my punnishment for dying over many other alternatives.  This game is in the same class as Assassin's Creed 2, but better. The only reason I reference AC2 and not the later ones is I have yet to play them (they're still sitting in my Steam Library).   Get this game, you won't regret it.

I haven't enjoyed an RPG this much since Morrowind. The Witcher 3 (and the entire Witcher franchise) isn't afriad of the gray ambiguity of actual life. You will not always be able to be the shining knight who can do no wrong, and even the most corrupted vile men can be redeemed.  Pros: -Great story. Bloody amazing. Made me want to cry about three times. -Beautiful combat. I love the difficulty of it all.  -Great cast of characters. From the stunning Triss Merigold to the reaistic Bloody Baron, this game brings it all. -Graphically astounding. I don't just mean high-end textures and meshes. The amount of emotion in Geralt's facial expressions really amazed me. Also, his hair grows over time. -Big world. Skellige is probably my favorite region. It's like going back to skyrim, except everyone's scottish and even angrier.  Cons: -You will eventually finish the game. Maybe. If you beat it in under 100 hours, you're doing it wrong.

Great game, honestly, bought it a few months before it was released after playing the witcher 1 and 2 and being really content with my experience there. Controls and monsters is great and the story is gripping, yet honestly, it gets a bit too big after a while, sure it is good to have much exploration to do, but some players involunatarily spend too much time searching for worthless stuff and small quests that, as an afterthought, was freaking worthless and not worth the time. I guess the crossdressing was good enough to compensate for that though.  Being something of a kleptomaniac, even after reaching 150k+ currency I just couldn't stop stealing everything I saw, without ever buying anything or actually needing any of the normal loot. Seriously, just running around stealing stuff from under the guards noses and everything else, exploring most of what there is to explore, I probably extended the game by over 200+ hours... it gets really boring after a while though, but I feel like I'd lose something if I skip out on that box in the corner, it might contain some goodies, like a recipe or something. Damn it, towards the end I would've been ready to pay the price of the game all over again to get rid of all but the most essential boxes. The only other thing that I really want to remark on is Roach. Seriously, I can't count the times I've wanted to send the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ horse off to the glue factory. What the hell is up with that programming? everytime you even get close to an edge, roach neighs and stops. Every time you walk across a bridge, every time you get remotely close to anything blocking your way, the same thing happens. What. The. HELL.   So, if you're not a kleptomaniac(if you are, you might want to reconsider using your time in other games with less worthless loot) and you love ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ horses that can't cross bridges without stopping for 10 seconds at every bridge, sometimes multiple times, and likes to spawn inside houses where it is warmy and cozy, then sure, go for it, you would be a hard pressed to find a better game that is truly worth the price due to the sheer playtime, story and visuals you get. Thumbs up, 9/10, too many boxes, worthless loot, crappy gear and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ horses to get a 10/10...

Base Game - 9.5/10 Hearts of Stone Expansion - 9/10 Blood and Wine Expansion 9/10  All together makes for one heck of a game!!! 10/10 - Masterpiece. That's all you need to know!

I have never played a sword fighting game or a RPG game. I tried Skyrim but it's combat system drove me off.   This game however is unbelievably good.  The graphics, Soundtracks, Story everything is just so good. So I went back and played it again so she turns a Witcher.    The characters in game are great. I really don't have much to complain about.   The Side quests are pretty awesome too.   I have got the Expansions now so going to play those too.   Now about the problems in this game. There is just one but it gets really annoying.   ROACH!   Stupid Roach. He gets stuck in trees, in fence and doesn't comes when I call him multiple times. It's Very annoying.   Once I just decided to run a distance of 900 footsteps and while running I kept calling roach to see if it can catch up and comes close to me so I can climb it and I continuously did this for 900 footsteps but he never even came close to me just ran a bit and then stop then spawns somewhere else and it just repeats.   It really is annoying.   Completing the base game and exploring all locations took me about 130Hours. And I am sure Expansion packs are going to take 50 or more.   Loved the game and I will get anything by CD Projekt red in future.   Get it already!   :)

To start off this game is well worth the money and time commitment required to beat the game. I've played through the main story two times so that I can see the best and the worse endings. I have to say, I have not longed to play a video game more than this in a long time. The game, when run on high and very high settings for long periods of time, will be taxing on your computer. However, the game is gorgeous and I can see the amount of time and care the developers put into the graphics and the multi-arc subplot and the multi-arc main plot.  The characters are all relatable and have interesting dialogue choices that impact the world of The Witcher in their own unique and wonderful way, however not every choice will be a good one and will impact the world in an unique and horrible way. The best feature of games like The Witcher III: Wild Hunt, is the ability to choose. The player can choose either to give Geralt a heart, with some emotions, or a heart of stone. The player also chooses how the world will percieve Geralt and even how the game will end, by the in-game dialogue and actions Geralt can make.  I give this game 9.93/10. The game does have a bug every now and then, but it is minor and can be overlooked or easily missed if one is not looking directly at it. This game is a most buy for anyone who is a part of the gaming brotherhood, or even just starting to get thier feet wet in one of the greatest inventions of mankind.

I would agree that this is one of the best role-playing games ever created (and I've played many of them over the past 20 years)! I have 174 hours played in it so far, including both extenstions and it's not over yet. At first it looks and feels like Red Dead Redemption set in a fantasy world with swords and magic, but then you recognize that it has way stronger plot, more features, and a lot more humor in it. I like sand-box games as a genre, and this one is as good as GTA V. Fights are mostly as easy as in Fable series, but variability of monsters and other enemies you face is absolutely impressive. And I extremely enjoyed a card game there named Gwent. Overall game is pretty easy to play by following obvious hints, but every now and then I came across interesting puzzles (no spoilers here!). If you like RPGs, you should try The Witcher 3, I strongly recommend it.

This is an exceptional work of art with an exquisite story, cast of characters, music, and gameplay. This game's story will make you laugh, cry and awe for the badass Geralt of Rivia; his journey is comming to an end and what an end it is. There are 36 different ways to end his story, but three major ones. Furthermore, this game has easily 200+ hours, and if you buy the two expansions, its easily 400+ hours of gameplay. The fact that CDProjectRed was able to make this game with a staff way less than Rockstar is insane. Yes, the Witcher 3 is a definite buy at full price and with its expansions. Also, this game comes with 16 free dlc, the complete soundtrack, an online artbook, an online comic, and wallpapers.

What can I say that hasn't already been said about this game?   Pros: I can't say whether it is the greatest game ever made, since I have played all the games that have ever been made, but I can say unequivocally that is the greatest game I have ever played.  Incredible, immersive story, compelling and realistic - often deeply flawed - characters, great combat and an absolute visual masterpiece.  The two DLC components are also absolutely worth the comparatively low price, and the final Toussaint DLC is long enough and complex enough that it could have stood completely alone and still been a much better game than 90% of the chaff that came out this year.  Cons: Combat isn't 'perfect'. I'm not a fan of the Gwent stuff, but you don't really need to participate in it. My only real complaints though are that a.) it eventually ends, and b.) You never get a chance to go into the high temple in Novigrad - still want to check that place out!

Edited review 29/05/16  A full year after first launch I finally found very specific graphic settings in-game and NVidia control panel to enable the game to run on full screen without a crippling loss of performance or crashes. In its current state the game finally runs as it was supposed to when it first came out.  The game still lacks in optimization regarding dual core CPUs and causes the performance to spike to 100%, freezing the frame every minute or so. This, however, could fortunately be fixed by running Battle Encoder Shirase on the side while running the game.  The content of the game itself did not disappoint. Even if I'm now playing it a full year late.

tl;dr: awesome game, runs smooth, story is solid, no creepy invasive DRM(!!!!!!!), good graphics, fun gameplay, some holes in the story if this is your first witcher game.   I will be telling you about my experience, it will be divided in little parts: A. Performance B. Gameplay C. Graphics D. Overall game  A. Perfomance wise, I would never thought this game would run on my 5 year old laptop. Well, it does. And it runs smooth. So smooth, that I don't even need to upgrade my hardware. I experienced 1 crash in 48 hours of gameplay. Unlike other popular games, fiddling with the settings actually works on even old machines. I love that!   B. Gameplay is fun, but like other witcher games it can become a bit of a mess when you accept too many missions. This game however, plays much better than the other witcher games. Everything feels refined, and works as it should. Sometimes you miss out on action buttons, or start conversations you aren't meant to start yet. This sometimes leads to frustration, or failed missions (when you're level 15 and run head first in to a level 24 mission by talking to the wrong person for instance). There is room to improve, but all things considered, this game is good. Gameplay is fun, well balanced and inviting. The missions all have stories, that are sometimes funny, sometimes interesting, sometimes just plain weird, but always a blast. Sure, somtimes you try things that you know will not work.. Then you'll get your horse stuck underneath a barn, or yourself stuck underneath a barrel in a tub. ♥♥♥♥ happens. The fact that you can save whenever, and wherever is great! Especially since conversational choices play such a large role.  C. I run this game at the lowest possible graphics, and I'm completely fine with that. It still looks better than FC Primal and the customization is endless. You can tweak nearly every little thing. The weather however, starts getting weird during winds at low graphics; trees just flip the F*** out whenever the wind blows.  D. I've never liked the witcher games. They were boring, dull, endless, you needed to read a lot.. They sucked. This game is different though. Reading is optional in most cases, and the missions are more fun to play. Summon a horse, and you'll travel around 100 meters in 15 seconds. Everything fits like a glove in this game. However! There is a big downside when it comes to the story: characters from previous games are incorporated, along with their stories. If you haven't played the other witcher games, it can be quite frustrating to not know who you're dealing with. Since the choices you make in conversations have a large influence on the rest of the game, I would like to see a proper introduction of characters in the future. This way, a player can estimate what the consequences of a choice would be. If you're a fan, you could incorporate previous witcher saved games and let the choices be made for you, or you might just remember who somebody is.. If this is your first time playing, be prepared to miss some of the story's parts. Apart from that, this game is awesome. If I had the money, I would pay the full price. But I don't, so I bought it on sale.
One of the best games I ever played

I think this game deserved all the praise it recieved. It is extremely rare for me to bother completing an RPG game. This one defintely was worth the time. There was never a moment where I thought 'ugh can we just get on with it!' The story is interesting because it does have the main focus of finding the ward but there are many encounters with different characters that were perfectly woven into the storyline to make them worth caring for. There was a characte you meet in Novigrad that became a part of the story and I didn't realize I cared for the well being of them until something happened to them.   The graphics are great and fits well as a next gen game. I found myself stopping to gaze at the scenery all the time and every new weapon I equipted had a new design to its sheath and I ended up staring at that most of the time I was running around. Even the monsters you face are disgustingly amazing to watch. When I was being attacked by the specters and the different kinds of beasts I just wanted to stand there and stare at their designs. It's just so amazing to see that amount of detail in the characters and monsters.  The audio in this game is even better. I don't have anything against reading when progressing through an RPG, but the fact that EVERY encounter with an npc was scripted and voiced made it a little more special. It just added that extra care that I was happy to receive. Hearing the water, mud splashes, snow crunching, and wood thuds as Geralt takes one step after another. I just love that extra bit, and I heard it everytime and its the main reason I didn't bother listeing to my own music while playing this game.   I personally didn't have any issues with the mechanics of the game. For me the fighting was fluid. The magic switching was not a problem and all the extra bits that come with were silk. I didn't care to use oils much but I enjoyed bombing the monsters. Being able to call Roach(your horse) almost anywhere was really nice and useful If there was any complaint I had I guess it would be in the mechanics of Roach. I found him getting stuck on tree's many times when I called him. I tried to keep the area clear when I called him but sometimes he would get stuck on a blockade of stone and I just got tired of using him. I ended up only using him if I had to get to an area far away.   Overall I love this game, I already completed the Hearts of Stone expansion and now I'm just eagerly awaiting the next expansion. Probably would give it a 9.5/10. That 0.5 was deducted because of my issues with Roach.
