On release day, my friend bought the game and recommended that I do the same. Neither of us had ever played a Witcher game, but we heard that the last couple were good, so we gave this one a shot.   I thought this game would be good, but instead it exceeded every expecation I had in spectacular fashion.  Gameplay - fun, challenging combat, fantastic quests (the side quests are just as interesting and fun as the main quests), and your choices matter, thanks to the game's ridiculous amount of endings.   Story - every good adjective I can think of. Andrzej Sapkowski's vision of a lore-filled and vast fantasy world filled with so many interesting characters is masterfully given form.  Music - solid all-around soundtrack that adds life to the entire experience.  Graphics and Performance - a beautiful game even on low-medium settings, and it runs like a beauty as long as you don't get overzealous and crank everything higher than your build can handle. I recommend turning the fancy hair graphics off completely, and then it shouldn't take much tweaking to get good performance.  Marketing - thought I'd include this because CD Projekt Red is the super hero of game developers. They charge $60 for a game that has a ~60 hours camaign and loads of other hours in the form of side quests and activities, not to mention the quality of all those hours of content. Then, they make a kickass DLC with about 12 hours of content and charge $10 for it. The next DLC costs $20, and it delivered upwards of 30 hours of the same quality content (plus a feakin' entirely new zone) I had already experienced from the base game and the first DLC (for some reason they called it a DLC and not The Witcher 4: Blood and Wine).  Negatives - very few, and overall the good FAR outweighs the bad. Your player does move a bit clunkily (movement is clearly favored towards consoles), and you aren't able to customize your character or do crazy, random actions the way you can do in similar games like Skyrim. Although I do not think this, some say that they feel the combat is clunky, too challenging, or just not fun. There have also been a decent number of bugs in the game, but most have been ironed out through updates by now. **WARNING: This game is NOT for you if you have little time on your hands and/or do not enjoy taking breaks from the action to engage in dialogue and story. Some dialogue scenes are lengthly, and although the dialogue itself is superb, many gamers may be turned off by the idea of dedicating so much time to the story and plot choices.**   Unless you dislike every good aspect that I have just described, do yourself a favor and purchase this game. It's worth it.
The greatest game ever made. Zelda Ocarina of Time held that title untill this game came out. It's fantastic in every single way, buy it!

If you enjoyed either of the last two games in the series from a storytelling perspective this should be near the top of your to-play list. Even if you haven't, the game does a decent job of getting you up to speed on some of the important plot threads but you may lose some context on many others.   Mechanically the game is an overall improvement from the last game and doesn't detract from the game overall, but still has its flaws/bugs of which there are more than I could realistically list. The nice part is that CDPR has tried really hard to fix many of these. Combat after several hours in the game can seem repetitive but is overall fairly dynamic even if towards the end of the game your build becomes a bit powerful for most things.  Visually the game is stunning and if you have the GPU to run it on higher settings you won't regret it.  Some might recomend that you should turn off the soundtrack in game to enjoy the ambeiance in the game and while I do think you should try it for a bit, the soundtrack is really well done and doesn't devalue your experience.   I also highly recommend getting all of the free DLC that is available (adds extra content) as well as the two paid ones, Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine. The last two are quality DLC and worth your time and money.   Overall, it was easily the best game I played in 2015 when it came out and is one of the best games I have ever played.

In The Witcher 3: Card Hunt, you play as Geralt of Rivia, a professional Gwent player. Decades of practice, drinks of dubious origin and past Gwent thrillers have made your hair gone all but white, yet you press on to achieve your goals: Travelling the lands to collect all the Gwent cards available in the basic edition and, ultimately, winning the renowned Gwent tournament taking place in a famous brothel called the Passiflora.  The way you´ve chosen is not an easy one. Voyages are dangerous these days, with mad knights challenging you for duels and your horse Roach rather eating apples than trotting on. Great chickens fly the skies. ♥♥♥♥♥s are expensive, your starting deck sucks, and hostile Gwent players don´t give a damn, playing overpowered cards like Mysterious Elf (Avalac´h).  However, you don´t surrender. You know that you will make it. For you are Geralt of Rivia, The White Spy, Destroyer of Gwent decks and Saviour of Cards!  10/10 Villentretenmerths

Played on XB1, replaying on PC because DAMN it looks better. Have not reached the Blood and Wine DLC yet so reviewing everything before that.  Stellar and immersive, the combat feels right after you start to understand how to fight monsters and humans with different tactics. The world just feels like a real place that you might wander through and have adventures. The casual dialogue as you pass by peasants and highborn nobles all really add to the experience.   Combat is not repetitive or boring, the game casually introduces more and more monsters, strategies, abilities, potions, and magic as you advance, allowing you a high amount of character customization and a hell of a lot of control over how you want to face down the enemies in the world of The Witcher.   Hearts of Stone was a hell of a ride, in my humble opinion a better story than the main in the end. If you reach the level required to play it I recommend dropping everything and playing it to completion.

I've plunged 110 hours of my life into the abyss just completing the main story. Side questing galore, little tidbits of lore to make the hard-core fans giddy, and grills are also in abundance. I wanted to write a review for W3 a long time ago , then i thought wait till the DLCs are released and do a complete review. First off its definatly the best RPG that is available in this genre...hands down, and thats coming from an die hard fan of the TES Series .What W3 does storywise (and for me personaly combatwise) it absolutley hits right on target , right between the eyes so to say. There are loads of characters in W3 's story and none of them is shallow ,boring or unnecessary. The whole Story of the game is nearly perfectly fleshed out Mainquest and Sidequest are alost eye to eye on the quality front wich makes it easy to do the 'im gonna play every nitbit of this thing'. I dare to say other Developers have learned a lesson on what realy matters in a modern RPG after W3.  The Thing with the Witcher Series in the past was always the combat . Now this time they invested a good chunk more into that , with the NG option ,difficulty setting options ,better enemy AI ....and a more way regular patching of 'WTF' oddities .Is it perfect ? na nana nana na :), but very enjoyable   The Graphics are great and eyecatching (some moaned bout it , you know where those coming from ....owning +5k machines and hang out with the russians on the space station on weekends )  The DLC's are more or less standalone in the whole thing ...but it realy doesent feel like it . They get an extra rating because they dont feel like common DLC's ,CDP definatly raised the bar here   Final Rating   out of 10 for story = 9.5 ...and thats because 10 would be perfect and nothing is perfect out of 10 for combat = 8 out of 10 for replay = 8 out of 10 for DLCs = 9 out of 10 for overall state of the game (bugs , glitches ..patching service)=9 out 0f 10 for graphics =9

I originally bought this game just about as soon as it came out. I played about ten hours of it, then from then on I neglected in until about two weeks ago. I liked it initially, but just lost interest after those ten hours. I now realize how much I missed out on.  I started playing it again recently, and it his been an experience like no other. First of all, the game/gameplay itself is just fantastic. I have clocked in around 120 hours of it in the past two weeks and I have not become even remotely bored of it yet. That is a lot coming from me because I cannot get sucked into these big games like I used to when I was younger.  The thing that really gets me about this game is the story. For whatever reason I love the family bond between characters in a fictional story like this, and it is near perfected between Geralt and Ciri. The whole game is essentially about Geralt searching for Ciri, and combatting the forces that are chasing her, in an attempt to use her 'gift', that is, Elder Blood.  I have never seen such a powerful and compelling story in a video game before. Not that I'm surprised, because CDPR has not delivered anything less than a masterpiece as of yet. That said, easily one of my most favorite games of all time. So good that it has blinded me into making a review that is less about the game itself, and more about the absolutely fantastic story/lore behind it.  Too many thoughts on why this is an amazing game, can't write anymore. Buy now.

I would suggest this game for the story alone. Even without the solid gameplay it is worth the experience. It felt like a novel at times and had an emotional experience to it. The story is structured as a dark fairy tale. Otherworldly people hunt Geralt's (our protagonist) foster daughter. Geralt must chase her as she is chased by the Wild Hunt. Along the way a well developed caste of characters is interacted with all having their own complete stories with arcs, choices, and themes.    The experience of playing Geralt and Ceri is incredible. The gameplay for Ceri is different enough to be interesting and the time mostly spent with Geralt is rewarding in terms of Combat, Monster Hunting, and crafting. Ceri's missions are more like an action game. Ceri's section take on a small portion of the game. It is ultimately a very romantic tale about the relationshipss that a grown man has, even one who wouldn't normally have family and loved ones.   Geralt's time outside of these character moments is spent preparing for and hunting monsters or human opponents. Preparing for fighting a monster revolves around crafting alchemical potions and body enhancing mutagens which give you different edges hunting monsters. Crafting is simple and not grind oriented. I was satisfied with what I was able to make with how little effort I put into it, only sometimes having to look for something. The more I put into it also the easier the hunts were.   The next edge Geralt has in kit is his Witcher Senses, which essentially give him a detective mode to examine hidden clues which lead to secrets or advance the hunt further. Many investigations are just a way to advance the story with a simple puzzle. Somtimes however they are optional and can give you an edge in the story or in combat if you pursue it correctly.   The combat is the weakest part of the game but still solid. Selecting weapons, potions, and bombs to fight different monsters always felt interesting. Learning how different kinds of monsters behave and adjusting my tactics was important in making the gameplay set itself apart. The effects and animations were well done and never felt really akward.   The swordplay is more intuitive than in past itterations of the game. Some people will need to increase the difficulty to enjoy the game, as it can be easy. In particular the last few battle with the Wild Hunt at the end of the game felt easy. They were tedious fights that relied on memorizing simple patterns.  Over all I recommend this game to anyone who like fantasy stories, fairy tales, or romance (in the literary sense). I would also recomend the game for people who like rpgs or openworld games.

8/10 - Amazing universe, great storyline, and lots of side-quests, but also a repetitive/easy combat system and a long, grindy, and sometimes discouraging main storyline (takes a while to finish).  Awesome game, really elaborate and beautiful universe, and you never run out of stuff to do. I really enjoyed this game, and the amount of details they put into the universe consistently surprised me. I'd try to do a storyline quest, and next thing I know I discovered some monster dungeon, stumbled upon some really deep side-quest, and have yet another witcher contract to kill some huge scary monster. But, aside from the depth of the world, not to mention the great plot, the game did get redundant at times, and especially the combat system was repetitive and easy. Overall, a solid 8/10 game -- I'd love to give it more but it wasn't very addicting to me, it was just a nice game to play to pass the time and admire the plot and environment.  Pros: -Amazing universe. The amount of detail they put into the universe, into side quests, into monsters, etc is astonishing. -Great plot. It's hard to get a firm grasp on the plot just from the Witcher 3, but it's still interesting, even if you haven't read the books. -Lots of stuff to do. There's always something else to do, another side quest to try out, a witcher contract to take on. -Gwent (side game) was boring at first for me, but got pretty fun once I understood the mechanics better. -Loved the dialogue, and the dialogue choices. Not sure how much of an effect the choices actually had on the plotline (it seemed to have some sort of an effect), but it was still engaging and interesting. -Characters were also good. I mean it's based off a really good book, so I'd assume the plot and characters are good.  Cons: -God the combat system is awful. And it's not 'bad', it's just especially since it's easy to spend so much time on the game, the combat system never really changes, and so you're left with the same fighting throughout the game. And they could have made it better - in fact, I enjoyed the few times I got to fight as Ciri, but they never gave Geralt that kind of mobility and all. Wish they incorporated more diversity with the combat system and made it a bit more challenging. -This con is also a pro, but the plot line is long and the universe is huge, and so sometimes I'd just get tired of it and take a break for a few weeks. This game, on and off, took me around 3/4 of a year to finish because it seemed very grindy at times. Especially with the combat system, I'd have to force myself to progress through the story, and once I thought I was reaching some sort of climax, there would be another story development and I'd feel like I had so much left to do in the game.  Anyway, overall, great game and probably one of the games I spent the most time on. I just liked the universe and the plotline (as well as the dialogue/characters) and really wanted to finish the game eventually. But, again the combat got old fast for me, and after getting through maybe 1/2 the game I figured it out. I played on the highest difficulty since then but the combat was never fulfilling for me since it was just too easy and repetitive, so I just got through the combat as a means to an end to continue on the storyline and such. But I still would recommend the game, though I'd say don't get too stuck on the side quests because the main storyline is already long enough. :)

HOLY ♥♥♥♥!!!! This game is a movie, a book, a fairytale and most important, the best freaking game I have ever played. I've spent 112 hours (and counting) on this game, and I would say it was and is worth every minute. Because everything you do in the main quest, and some secondary quests will have a impact on how the game will play out in the future, which I think is just soooo fun and interesting. Now, this was only one reason why I love this game, and why you should buy it and love it too, so here is some more reasons:  -Great story and gameplay  -Breathtaking graphics (especially in Blood And Wine DLC)  -Characteres you will love and hate  -The setting, place and timeperiod is just perfect for the game  -The size of the world you are in is just amazing  -If you like Skyrim this will most likely give you a similar feeling (I might be wrong, I have never played Skyrim, hehe)  -If you like open world and/or RPG games, what are you waiting for?!  Now, I have to point out the creative mind of the author of the books and the team that made the game, it's mindblowing how many different creatures the author and makers have come up with. And I can see that they have gotten inspiration from different faiths, tales and mytlologies, which is pretty cool. But I've noticed some placesand people are taken out from different folketakes and tales, some examples are on Ard Skellige (in the game) where some places/ villages has Norwegian names (I pointed this out because I'am from Norway) like Lofoten (North in Norway), Fyresdal, Sund (county in Norway), Dovre ruins (Dovre is also a county) and Larvik. This masterpiece is definately worth picking up. It is my favourite game of all time, and it will be hard to fin a better one. So what are you waiting for? Geralt Of Rivia is waiting.

The Witcher 3 is one of THE best western open world story-driven RPG out there in almost every aspect, and pretty much the game of the year. Also it has one of the best protagonists in videogames history. Geralt is probably the only videogame character EVER that I've grown incredibly fond of out of all the games I've played and even when it's you making the choices, Geralt delivers them better than anyone else you could imagine. Doug Cockle is a brilliant voice actor and really makes Geralt who he is.  Let's sum up what makes the game good: -Brilliant storytelling and writing -Every mission feels unique -The world is beautiful ( Graphical quality is top notch ), fluent, rich, alive, colorful, yet serious -Voice acting is phenomenal ( when it's not the same guy voicing the hundreds of randomized NPC's ) -Combat is varied with tons of different oils, potions, arrows and bombs -Progression system is varied, balanced and allows for lots of different styles of combat -Free DLC's that for example, adds New Game+, new armour, horse armour, new missions etc. -The expansion packs are pure bliss to play through and feel much more polished than the base game, tbh -Lots of different enemies and different tactics to take them on -Game is filled with content, treasure hunts, side missions, witcher contracts, random events, monster lairs, bandit hideouts, imprisoned merchants etc.  Here's few negative things about the game: -You'll come across few glitches and bugs every now and then, not game breaking, but annoying -The game is lacking in difficulty, even on Death March, new game+ sets the bar right, but that'll be a second playthrough -Starting a new save is always a bore and takes too long, the real meat of the game is when you get out of White Orchard -As much as there is to do, I want more of Geralt's adventures :(  As they've already confirmed, this'll be the last Witcher game starring Geralt, which is a sad thing, truly. If it were up to me, I'd love to play every upcoming Witcher game as him, but we'll see if the next protagonist will get even close.  But yeah. It's a masterpiece everybody should play through at least once along with it's expansions, Hearts of Stone and Blood & Wine. It's been out for long so the game isn't even all that expensive. As I am writing this review, the game is mere 15 euros on Steam. The price is LAUGHABLE considering how much worth you'll get for the price.  It's really amazing what a bunch of kurwas in a squatting position can make when it comes to videogames. I don't even have to shill for CDPR because their games speak for themselves. Just ♥♥♥♥ing buy the game, you won't regret it.

I've been playing the Witcher games from the start, and this is definitely the perfect catharsis to the trilogy. This was one of the only titles that didn't bother me to hear that the release was being delayed with the reason being that they wanted to make it perfect, because they truly did. CD Projekt Red took the best aspects of the previous two games and merged them into this exquisite piece of interactive literature.  The game world is massive, and not just in terms of size. Almost everywhere you can go will have something worth seeing, whether it be a beautiful scenery, an impoverished village or a bustling city full of unforgettable characters, crime, racism and power-struggles. Of all the RPG's I've played over the years, this is and will be my favorite for some time. If you're a fan of story, I'd recommend playing the previous two, or at least reading a summary of the story, though this isn't overly necessary.

This game is a fun game, however I feel as if it has recieved way more hype than the game deserves. Yes the Witcher is fun, yes the game world is huge, and yes you can do whatever the hell you want in the world, however the game fails in many basic aspects that take away from the overall experiece. The first gripe I had towards the game is its wonky combat system. All I find myself doing is hitting one of the two buttons to dodge an enemies hit, or mashing my left mouse button to strike. There are potions and special abilities to use during a fight, however I always found myself reverting to my trusty sword. I really would have liked if CD Projekt Red created a combat system more similar to Skyrim, where you can block and swing with more control and precision. I also feel as if the developer could have included a first person view whilst allowing the player to switch between first and third person views, like skyrim. I have also noticed a fair amount of bugs in the game thus far. For example, people walking through each other, getting stuck on walls and ledges and holes etc. Anyways besides all of that I feel as if this game is great however it isnt the best. I would still recommend that you pick it up during a sale.

Easily the most story-rich game I've ever played. I love the moral ambiguity of many of the choices the player encounters throughout the game. One of the best games I have ever played, and definitely my favorite game in quite a while. About 60 hours on my first playthrough, could have easily gotten probably about 80-90ish even without the new DLC (Hearts of Stone and now Blood and Wine, as of editing). Playing through NG+ on the hardest difficulty, this is the only game I have even had any interest in the NG+ with. Graphics are beautiful, soundtrack is riveting, story is compelling and gripping. The cinematics are goose bump worthy and the completely open world and free roam feeling flows so well and is just amazing.  The rich story, characters, self awareness and the truly brilliant and believeable world is just astonishing. I can honestly say, having played A LOT of story rich RPGs this is definitely one of, if not the best - in my opinion, and many others. As well as the best in the series, having finished all three.  Over 100 hours of gameplay and I haven't even touched the two expansions or finished my NG+ playthrough. Expecting to have around 200 hours by the time I've done all I want to do. Not to mention all the free DLC that the developers provides to everyone, a truly generous and great thing to do. The free DLCs are actually worth the download as well, as there is even a few side quests included. Considering most games these days charge for special armors, weapons, appearances and whatnot, and here they are giving them out for free.  Couple cons though so this doesn't seem like a suck-up review(though it kinda is): The controls are definitely overwhelming at first and can feel somewhat clunky or unresponsive at times if you are not familiar with the series. Also, if you are looking to play this game on max graphics, you better be packing a nice PC. It is quite intensive for max graphics. However, it is flexible; low graphics don't require anything outlandish at all.  tl;dr: Amazing, fantastic game. One of the best. Couple small oddities and different approaches to controls and such that take some getting used to at first. Overall, 10/10 here.

Combat and inventory system could be better. Combat could be much more tactical, now you basically click all combat buttons randomly and watch how the heads fall. And what comes for inventory, good thing in it is that you don't need to search anything from there. All the required items are always automatically found when needed. But this is a minor flaw. Otherwise top quality game, very enjoyable and you can very easily descent into the world of Witcher.
This game most certainly was worth the money I paid. The DLC is free, the content is massive and leaves you with this guilty feeling that you simply didn't pay enough for a game this amazing.

Fun fact: Roach's 'bugs' were actually coded by the developers on purpose because the original Roach was too perfect and wasn't nearly as fun.   Voted game of the year for a damn good reason. This is the single best game i have ever played. So far I've only played the game once while not doing every single quest or exploring the vast and beautiful world of the Witcher 3 and it still was a very lengthy playthrough. I never got bored even once because the game constantly threw new things at you while still sticking to mainly the core basics of the game so it wasn't infuriatingly (is that a word?) difficult. I recently purchased both DLC has been said to contain 30-50 extra HOURS of gameplay. I've never played a long RPG before because I've always become disinterested but this story was very well written and not as many parts were cliche, far from it actually.   You thought I was done? Sorry bout that...CD Projekt Red has really defined what it means to be a consumer-based company. While most other companies only care about popularity and sales (obviously CDPR do too), but CDPR actually made a game worth playing. And playing. And maybe one or two or five more times again. They lowered the price in other countries (I'm so mad i forgot which) for this game because their government made it so they'd be paying approx $90 in their currency equivilant. Also the DLC is exactly what DLC should be. An EXPANSION. Not this crap COD or any EA game throws at you with like 1 fun or 2 small maps for $15. Instead they gave us hours of gameplay with new missions in a new extensive open world just as beautiful as the existing one for a mere $25 (bought as a pack together). Oh I nearly forgot: 16 FREE DLC. Sure most of them are remodeled characters, but how many other games makes you pay for that? Pretty much every other one right?   In conclusion: Story- 10/10 Map/world- 10/10 Voice actors- 11/10 Gameplay- 9/10 (sometimes movement and swimming was clunky) Hud/menus- 10/10  Overall this is easily a 10 on 10 game.     TL;DR: Best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game, by the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ devs, with the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugs. Spend your hard-earned ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ money on this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game by the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ best devs.

It makes me sad to think that I will eventually finish The Witcher 3.  65 hours into this game, I was heading to a nearby village to meet a man about a drowner problem that him and his neighbors had been having. Trodding along on horseback, I thought to myself, 'What makes this game so much better than every other game I've played?' I slowed my horse's gallop to a stop while pondering this question and spinning my camera around to admire the details of the surrounding environment. It was then that I noticed the crumbled ruins of a small castle tower on a hill close by. At that moment the answer dawned on me. The world of The Witcher is packed to the absolute brim with small details that you might simply walk past without noticing, but if you decide to look a little bit closer at just about anything you will find yourself diving head first into a unique adventure.  I decided to test this theory by deviating from my path just a bit to check out the small, ruined tower that had caught my eye. I approach the waist high stone walls surrounding the fragmented tower, which look like they had at one time been as tall as the neighboring trees. Upon walking into the ruins, I notice the laid out corpse of a dead man with blood surrounding him. Tapping into Geralt's witcher senses, I see monster tracks and claw marks around the man's corpse. Geralt then mentions how the marks on the ground and wounds on the body resemble those of a monster I have yet to encounter in my 65 hours of playing this game, a Fiend.  At this moment I hear some ominous noises coming from something very large on the other side of the tower, and decide to open up the bestiary. A page in my bestiary informs me that a Fiend is a three-eyed relict capable of hypnotism. Having not yet come across a monster that can hypnotise its foes, let alone one with three eyes and antlers, I decide I may as well see what this guy is all about. I coat my blade in relict oil and chug a cat potion as I move around to the other side of the tower to come face to face with the monstrosity. Queue an intense 20 minute battle with a monster 10 levels higher than me, ending in me cutting off its head and strapping it to the side of my horse as a trophy.  I felt validated in my reason for loving this game as I left those ruins, wondering what I would encounter next.

If you still don't own this game... then watch some random gameplay of it on youtube. If you can tolerate Geralt then you shouldn't have a reason to dislike this game. But I can safely declare this my favorite game of all time =) I am simply amazed by this fact.  I understand why some may not enjoy the game... what from it being far too massive to find the time or patience to appreciate it to simply not liking Geralt has a character... it's all a matter of taste imo. This game truly deserves all the hype n praise it gets and that's a rare thing indeed. I have only minor problems with the game of which thankfully are resolved with mods such has trophies all having basically the same frigging bonuses and the bloody censorship of th-- yeah mods are great stuff =)  This game also made me a fan of CD Projekt for offering such great value in this game. They should be praised more for they're clever business practices. If you love a good story, you'll love this game. If you love dark fantasy, you'll love this game. If you love detective/mystery games, you'll love this game. From the story depth and length, to the incredibly fun gameplay, this game is absolutely outstanding.

This game is one of the best, most beautiful and well voiced RPG's I have ever played. I am over 50 hours in while writing this, and I have plenty of story left, not to mention 100s of sidequests and even the two expansions. It is one of those games where you can't move 100 yards without stumbling over something interesting. The only negative thing about this game for me, is that there are not nearly enough hours in the day if you wanna emerge yourself in this game, while still maintaining a somewhat normal and productive existence outside of your room. This is gaming at it's finest, and I can't stress enough how you need to buy this if you are into well crafted, story driven open world RPG's.

Geralt of Rivia as the main character is not only the main focus of this story but the problem of the people of the realm of Witcher 3 also takes a great part of the whole story of this game. The are so many problems that Geralt have to solve in this game from helping local villagers to slaying a monster or finding a missing person, helping friends and his daughter from political issues, fighting against dark lord of another world and so many other problems. But the great thing is that Geralt is not some superheroes that will save all humankind (and elves, dwarves, and other humanoid lol), he just some part of this world too, that have justice and loves to help people when in need and he has some weakness too sometimes he's being too kind and sometimes being too ignorant (it depends on how the player chose). So what are waiting for, get this game and play it and I hope you enjoy it like me :D  This game is absolutely 10/10 game of all time! Good job CD Project Red!

I wouldn’t classify CD Projekt Red‘s The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt as a videogame, in fact, is one of those titles that goes beyond that definition in every way possible.  I know it’s not helping right away, but without going any further I will state that this is the best RPG I’ve ever played, hands down. I was mentioning that you shouldn’t consider it just a game, I’d name it as a deep immersion in a fabulous fantasy world, constantly changing, evolving, awake and alive, a little new universe inside your hard drive.  The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt main attributes are an astonishing sense of freedom, mind-blowing graphics, deep plot, intriguing and compelling characters, challenging, realistic and bloody combat system, hundreds if not thousands of items to craft and collect, massive world to explore (10+ times Skyrim‘s), an alive world in constant change (weather, animals, random events, etc.) and I could continue naming wonders about this game endlessly.  What’s most amazing about this fabulous experience is wandering around when suddenly you realize that each NPC you crossed you path with has been compelling to you, you feel, good, bad, sad or remorse about them, even after one week of gameplay you ride through that village again and you remember that old poor woman who asked you once for help. What I’m saying, if I’m saying anything, is that each dialogue is meaningful in its own way and that’s actually rewarding, that could probably be the most important thing when it comes to an RPG besides plot, graphics or whatnot.  What about the bestiary!? My god, I’ve played for a week and I still discover different creatures each and everyday… each with their own characteristics, weaknesses, etc. not to mention that depending on the creature type and level you should really be careful, come ready for combat and be sure to use the proper signs.  Of course all this remains just a humble opinion about such a massive game in every sense. I could write a book talking about every single aspect that amazed me since the first day I started playing it, but that’s not the point, the point is that this is being such a rewarding experience that I’m desperate to let every single player around the world know about it, it’s even one of the reasons why I decided to go back writing in DWD.  The Witcher 3: Wild hunt is one of those masterpieces that will forever remain in the hall of fame of the videogame world, long to be forgotten or even matched. There’s not a single negative aspect of the game I want to talk about, if so it would be the combat control slightly, but this is such an extraordinary game it washes it away, from its best-of-films OST to its complexity in every way.  Before I go, I want you to know that I’m the kind of player who still thinks that the perfect game won’t ever exist, but in order to summarize: even if you really hate RPGs you should run and buy this masterpiece.  9/10

If you're sitting at home, looking up the steam store and see The Witcher 3 enter your suggested list, or it is on sale or whatever, and you find yourself wondering if this is a game worth buying. Then I have only one word for you;  YES!  Do you want to know why? Of course you do!  Even if you do minimal research of the game, everything from a quick look on youtube, to a fast search on google, you will find lots and lots of content for this game. There is a reason for it to become one of the best games 2015 had to offer.   Take this from one who has been to every crook and cranny of this fine universe presented for us in the witcher. I have done everything from walking the isles of skellige to frantically trying to crush this one barkeep to get his one special card in gwent. Everything from slaying monsters, to human monsters, to just spending time you and Roach together on the road between villages.   Yes, it is right that I have played over 150 hours of this game, and found and completed every achievement that there is for now, yeah you're damn right, all 65, and you now what? It was all worht it! Every penny I spent on this game was worth from the very beginning of the game, where you get a chance to take a quick look on one of the many beatifull and terrifying beasts that has a bounty on their head.   Like even the DLC is great. The heart of stone DLC, offered a very different yet hughly interesting questline there both you and Geralt are put in a spot where the most interesting things happen.*spoiler 'Those donkey ears man, they crack me up every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time'   So to conclude this; Yes! Go buy the game, give yourself enough time to spend with the game, at least 100 hours or so, and enjoy every little thing that The Witcher world has to offer. Remember to take it slow, and let the ambience reel you in, and don't be afraid to take another road, or stop to listen or watch what the different villagers say or do.   But be warned, you must remember to not have anything planned for the next week or so, cause this game will drag you in, suck your life out, and don't let you return to the real world until the game is beaten.   Now I only have one thing left to say;  Happy hunting, Witcher!

Got the GOTY Edition during Steam sales, and after almost 22 hours into the game, i can just say, this game is epic.  At first i have to admit that i actually dont like these kind of games, i've played Skyrim after its release for some hours, but got bored really fast. So i was not sure if this game would suit me, although i've played Witcher 2 for some hours. But god damn, its amazing, i am addicted to it, cant stop playing. The first hours were a little bit dull to be honest, but after that... wow.  Story: AMAZING Sidequests: AMAZING Graphics: AMAZING Characters: AMAZING  I am really amazed about the sidequests, usually in most games the sidequests are repetitive and dull, like 'go there, get that' or 'go there, kill that'. In Witcher 3 the sidequests are fun so far, you kinda know why you are doing the sidequests, they make sense, not like in other games.  Only downsides so far are:  -Horseriding is not fun, its so hard to control the horse, it doesnt do what you want the horse to do, you aim into one direction, but the horse goes into the other. After 22 hours i am not using the horse anymore, either im using fasttravel, or im going by foot.  -You kinda need either Xbox or PS4 controllers to play this game, ive tried it with keyboard at first, but this is definetly a game you want to play with a controller, thank got it has native PS4 & XBOX Controller support.  So if you like Skyrim, i bet you either already own the Witcher series, or you definetly should. Either way, you should get this game, its amazing.

Spoiler Alert: 'Geralt Meets Ciri' : Geralt opens the door. She's there, helpless, lifeless,..  He refuses to accept this, wishing this reality was but another nightmare. It's been a lifetime of searching. It cannot be. He approaches her. His heart palpitating even more with each step taken towards her. He looks at her. Shock, terror, fear... They say witchers are stripped of human emotions. I guess not.  Geralt of Rivia, the White Wolf roaming the North is broken. His mind shuddered...  The hardest and best scene in the game without a doubt! The first moment your heart drops. YOU refuse to accept what your eyes see. Your stomach churns in on itself. Geralt looks so down, and then the music changes.There's life. Geralt embraces Ciri ever so lovingly. Hope and love eradicate the agonizing pain cloaking Geralt's mind. You feel the tenderness in Geralt's action from there forth. SUCH A BRILLIANTLY CRAFTED SCENE!!!! SO GOOOOODDDDDDDD!!!  Definitely Recommend the game AND the DLCS (TRUST ME get the dlc's)  Easy 10/10!!!
